PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Discrimination

To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that WHEREAS the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And WHEREAS the terms of the United Nations Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 115 citizens), Crichton-Browne (from 21 citizens), Sibraa (from 117 citizens) and Teague (from 23 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that United States, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Haines (from 514 citizens) and Macklin (from 33 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Office of Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That citizens of Western Australia view with great alarm the removal of Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare services for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled , should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Allens Creek, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned that a residential suburb shall be built in Allens Creek near Kambah in the Murrumbidgee Gorge Corridor of the Australian Capital Territory.
Your petitioners declare that the Murrumbidgee Gorge Corridor near Canberra in almost unspoilt native forest should be part of the National Estate.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled shall take all possible steps to prevent the building of a residential development in Allens Creek in the Murrumbidgee Gorge Corridor.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

At its first meeting on Friday, 22 April 1983, the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare resolved to continue the inquiry into children and youth under institutional and other forms of care-a matter which the Senate referred to the previous Committee towards the end of the last Parliament. This was the only reference before the previous Committee that was not completed before the double dissolution.

The inquiry into children and youth under institutional and other forms of care was advertised in the national Press on 29 June 1982 inviting interested persons and organisations to submit their views to the Committee. The Committee also sought submissions from private care institutions and associations, Commonwealth , State and Territory governments and agencies, and others. Since then, the Committee has received over 100 submissions together with a large volume of supporting material. Two public hearings were held prior to the double dissolution.

The Committee now proposes to continue the inquiry where the former Committee left off. It is the Committee's intention to proceed immediately with a series of public hearings, inspections and informal discussions in all States and the Northern Territory. Public hearings will also be held in Canberra. The Committee plans to report to the Senate on this reference as soon as possible following the completion of its program of public hearings and inspections.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to the debate on the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech I want to follow briefly the theme developed as part of Senator Colston's speech last night, particularly in relation to elections. I am naturally a little disturbed, having been here for a relatively short time-some nine years on the 18th of this month-to have had to face the electorate on four separate occasions. I am particularly disturbed at the former Attorney-General's statement following the Australian Constitutional Convention last week. Senator Durack was quoted as having said: ' I believe that elections are good for people'. I do not believe that elections are good for people. I do not believe that they provide members of parliament with an opportunity to be members of parliament and working in the best interests of their constituents in the first instance. They are a very expensive exercise to undergo at the rate we have been undergoing them in the last few years. I am certainly not of the same mind as the former Attorney-General. Perhaps that is why he is the former Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just briefly outline my particular situation. I was elected on 18 May 1974 at a double dissolution and served some 18 months prior to the coup that took place when an elected government, the Whitlam Government, was tossed out of office because of the conniving between a former Governor-General and the then Opposition. I was re-elected in 1977-I got the short end of the stick-and was not due to face the people until the end of this year, with my term of office to be concluded on 30 June 1984.

Now, because of the early election, my term of office is back-dated to 1 July 1982, which means that once again I will not serve a full term of office. It is a disgrace to the people of Australia that we allow this situation to develop time and again because of those few people who are elected who believe that they have a God-given right to rule. I, for one, have been quite vociferous in my attack on them for having done so on this occassion. The timing of the election was interesting. It was called at that time, I believe, by the former Prime Minister because he believed that, in accordence with his born to rule ethic, the people would not discharge him from office. But the people have spoken and that is why, in the House of Represenatives particularly, so few members of the Liberal Party have taken their places.

I want to refer briefly, because of the time available to me, to a number of matters raised in the Governor-General's Speech. I refer particularly to the statement made with regard to equality for women. It is heartening to see so many women not only entering this place but also being elected into the State Parliament in my State of Western Australia. Honourable senators may be aware that in the recent State election in February five new women members were elected to the Legislative Assembly and two women members now serve in the Legislative Council. All are members of the Australian Labor Party. It is an indication, as was stated in this place last night, that the statement that women cannot win seats is a myth. It has been accepted by the community that women are just as competent in this House as they are in their own homes and in industry, and that they have the capacity to equal the contributions made by male members who have for so long dominated all houses of parliament. I look forward to the day when the numbers will be much more even. There has, of course , always been a tradition of male domination in the Senate. I have raised that matter on a number of occasions, particularly during adjournment debates-those debates have made interesting reading over the years-because of my concern that women were not accepted as being in their proper place here. To a large extent discrimination was exercised when I first entered Parliament and perhaps that is why I welcome the new female members so warmly.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are even more discriminating.

—I am reminded by Senator Crowley that women are even more discriminating, but her meaning is slightly different from mine. I will speak briefly about the need for women to be recognised in our society. Every day during the short time that the Parliament has been in session petitions have been presented calling for the dissolution of the National Women's Advisory Council. Those petitions contain a lack of recognition of the worth of the National Women's Advisory Council and the work it has done over the years. There has been a lack of recognition, not only in the community but also by the previous Government, of the work that has been done for women by women in other areas of the community, such as women's refuges. I raised this in part in a question yesterday to Senator Grimes, the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In our community, because of external circumstances, greater pressure is being placed on the family unit. There is more unemployment, which causes more stress, which creates more strain on those individual units and results quite frequently in the necessity for people to vent their anger and frustration on the people whom perhaps they love most. Women's refuges are constantly being used to house people in those circumstances. On my doorstep at 3 o'clock in the morning have stood people who have received the most violent application of their partners' make-up because of their frustrations at not being able to provide adequately for their families. Once the initial frustration is over, of course, there is always that contrite feeling-'I am sorry I did it and it will not occur again'. But in the meantime that family unit has to be housed somewhere, and the only places available to them are women's refuges.

SPEECH.PARA: In Western Australia there is gross overcrowding. Because we do not have halfway houses as such and because welfare housing is at such a premium women have to stay in those refuges for such a long time. There is nowhere else for them to go. There is not in the community an acceptance of a need for urgent welfare housing and government departments, as we all know, move slowly. With a new Labor Government we need to channel more funds into that area of our communities to ensure that those women, and particularly those children, have a secure base during that tremendous upheaval in their lives. I firmly believe that unemployment is the greatest single cause of family breakdown that the Australian population is facing today.

I will speak briefly too, as I did in the adjournment debate last night, about human rights and the peace initiatives that have been undertaken by the people of Australia within the last few weeks. Over the years there has been amongst Australian people a growing concern that we have to demonstrate our preparedness to stand up and be counted on matters which vitally affect our future and the future of our children and their children. As a mother and a grandmother, I am vitally concerned to do all that I can to ensure that my children and my grandchildren have a future. If we leave it to the super-powers I very much doubt that that will be so.

I believe that there is in the community a growing concern, a feeling of 'What can I do about all this? My voice will not be heard. No one listens to me when I talk about these things'. I have a fear of nuclear war, as I have a fear of any war-of any conflict. I can cope with verbal conflict. Physical conflict I find extremely difficult to consider. Given that in the event of a nuclear war we would be totally unprepared and there would be nothing that anyone could do, I believe it is the right and the responsibility of all people, particularly in Australia which is a peaceful nation, to support those groups throughout the world, including the women of Greenham Common, the women in America who are now actively speaking out against President Reagan's war initiatives and people in other countries, who are not prepared to sit back and just let events decided by the super-powers overtake them.

Only a few weeks ago we saw in Australia 150,000 people demonstrating against nuclear war. Among them were people, particularly in Perth, who had never before demonstrated in such a way. I asked a number of them why they were choosing this particular time to come out. One of the men said: 'I looked at my son sleeping last night and I realised that if I did not do something he may sleep permanently'. I believe that this Government has the initiative to take matters of peace to their ultimate conclusion, to express its concern at statements made in a much more powerful way than the previous Government was prepared to do and to recognise that we have a responsibility, not only to defend out nation and therefore to set up our defence mechanics, but also to fulfil the Australian Labor Party obligation to establish a research and peace institute. I look forward to the day that I can stand in this place and congratulate the Government on such an enterprise.

Some years ago I was heartened about the establishment of the Murdoch University in Western Australia because it was intended to have a Chair of Peace there, but for some reason that did not eventuate. I believe that if it had been established at that time we would have been in a much better position now to provide information and advice to those governments who are obviously preparing for war, advice to enable them to take the action that would be necessary for them to disarm, to reach detente and to come to a peaceful conclusion to their problems. Right throughout the world, in places such as Lebanon, Palestine, Chile, Argentina, Uraguay and Paraguay, we are seeing invasions of not only the privacy of the individual but also a complete ignorance of the human rights that we believe are so essential to all human beings. I believe that my Government, the Labor Government under Prime Minister Hawke, will make a valuable contribution to the world scene. It might consider acting as a mediator in the areas of greatest conflict. It might be possible for us, as a peaceful nation and because of our geographic isolation, to do much more to bring the world to peace rather than the situation which now exists.

I intend to speak to some of the matters that have been raised by the Opposition senators in their contributions to the Address-in-Reply debate. On looking at my notes I realise that I have not taken the opportunity of congratulating the new senators on their maiden speeches. I will do that now. I thank Senator Reynolds, Senator Cook, Senator Jack Evans and Senator Crowley for the contributions they have made. I am sure they will participate in a very worthwhile way not only in the operations of this chamber but also in its committees and the operations of the Government. I was a little disturbed by some of the comments that were made last night by honourable senators. The former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, expressed his concern at the Government's actions in a particular area that were going to affect people in his State of South Australia.

I sat on the benches opposite for seven years. I listened to members of the then Government blaming the Whitlam Government for all of the ills of Australia. The Whitlam Government was in power for only three years and did not cause the utter devastation to the people of Australia that honourable senators now sitting on the Opposition benches would have us believe. If they raise in this chamber matters of public importance such as they did yesterday, one question is raised not only in my mind but in the minds of all Australians who listen to the debate-not that I believe there are that many-or who read the Hansard and the Press extracts.

If the Opposition thinks the proposals that it has are such a good idea, why did it not implement them when it was in government? It had seven years in which to do all of these things-to have the economy recover and to create employment opportunities. It has not done that, yet it anticipates that in the few short weeks in which the Hawke Labor Government has been in office we will be able to do all things for all people. We have never said at any time that that will be the role of the Labor Government. We have made certain commitments and we will abide by those commitments where it is possible. But what the people sitting on the Opposition benches have to remember is that it was through their conniving, their underhand methods and their distortions of the truth that the Labor Government came into power with such a tremendous deficit. It is the deficit only which is preventing us from fulfilling all of our election promises. Every single member of the Executive of the former Liberal Government knew damn well prior to the election that the deficit was indeed $9.6 billion and that we would not be able to fulfill our obligations. They knew that it was not a deficit of $ 6 billion, the figure that the former Prime Minister and Treasurer were bandying about. I totally reject the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition. I reject it for all of the reasons that I have just stated. I reject it particularly because I look forward to the next seven years at least of their remaining on the Opposition benches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the speech given by the Governor-General in this chamber on 21 April. This, therefore, is the Address-in-Reply debate. A number of factors are normal in the Address-in-Reply debate. First of all, it is traditional that the Address-in- Reply debate is taken as an opportunity for new senators to make their maiden speeches. This has been occurring. I join with others in welcoming all of the new senators on both sides of the chamber. I say how much I enjoyed the contributions that they have made. They showed a capacity and an ability which will add to the experience and the enrichment of this chamber. I congratulate those who have spoken. I welcome them and wish them well for the future. I wish them every happiness within this chamber, which has a unique atmosphere which is quite distinctive when compared with that in the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Address-in-Reply debate also has a number of other characteristics. Traditionally the Speech itself is directed by the government of the day to outlining the policies that it proposes and foreshadows for the years ahead. It is doubly so in the first year of the Government because it would be expected in that Speech to foreshadow to the community of Australia its policies and the promises it has made in the election campaign and upon the acceptance of which it was elected. The fundamental test is whether this Speech outlines the Government's policies and the promises it has made over the past months. Is it therefore the substance of the mandate? Because there are great defects in the Government's approach the Opposition has moved the following amendment:
At end of motion add:
', but the Senate is of the opinion-
(a) that the program outlined in the Governor-General's Speech will result in higher unemployment and represents a callous disregard of the needs of the Australian people; and
(b) that the Governor-General's Speech fails to identify a legislative program for the implementation of the policies promised by the Government during the recent election campaign; for instance-
(i) it fails to develop a viable blueprint for economic recovery and development,
(ii) it fails to honour the commitment to reduce taxation,
(iii) it fails to develop any programs for better industrial relations,
(iv) it fails to develop any policies for the steel industry or manufacturing industry generally,
(v) it fails to honour the commitment to reduce the tax burden on small businesses, and
(vi) it fails to provide any specific measures to assist primary producers who are recovering from the drought'.

The Opposition has moved this amendment and the Opposition will support it. What is more significant is that all information supports it. Let me direct my remarks to this. A cynic who has become well known over the years and who obviously knew the Australian Labor Party well has said that a political platform is like the platform on the back of a bus; it is meant to get in on and not to stand on. Indeed, nobody could be taking the public for a ride more than the present Labor Party. Within days of its election on its platform the Government knew that it would not stand on that platform and it abandoned it. Let me direct my remarks to these factors because they are relevant indeed to this amendment to the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's speech.

I think nobody would deny that Mr Hawke, on 13 February, in the midst of the election campaign, said that jobs and unemployment were the key issue of the campaign. Therefore, he emphasised that the Labor Party's promises about jobs and unemployment would be those essential promises which it would carry out. No one, I think, would fail to remember, although it is embarrassing now, two statements made by the Labor leader of 13 February, in the teeth of the election campaign. The first statement by Mr Hawke was that unemployment could be held at present levels over the next year-that is throughout 1983. He went on to say that he also maintained that he would expect unemployment to be 2 percentage points less at the end of a full term under Labor.

We have two clear statements on the basis of which the Labor Party went to the people and said: 'Elect us because we will resist any further increases in unemployment in the year ahead and by the end of our term unemployment will be at least two percentage points below what it is now'. The fact of the matter is that within days the National Economic Summit Conference was called. Within days papers were circulated-not within weeks or months, but days. What did the papers state? They stated quite clearly that, in fact, unemployment would increase in the years ahead and that unemployment, in terms of the number of unemployed, would be substantially greater at the end of the three-year term of the Labor Party than it is now. So much for the platform and so much for the key promise! Lest anyone has doubts at all about this matter-we are all chided that we should look to the Summit and its papers-I will refer to the key point in the address of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, who, talking about the three projections, said:
Even in the case of projections A and C, the overall unemployment rate on average in 1985-86 is little different from that in 1982-83.

In other words, the rate will be about the same. Clearly, because of the growth in the work force, the numbers will be greater. That was stated, despite the promise of the Labor leader. I will now refer to the National Economic Summit Conference paper of April 1983 entitled 'Projections of the Australian Economy to 1985-86'. The Labor Party, the Government, came forward at that Conference and said: 'We give you three projections, options A, B and C, to see what your choice might be and what course the community might follow'. Essentially, having done that, it implied that one of those projections at least would be the projection that would emerge from the Conference. It could scarcely leave out from its projections the one that it hoped would be adopted, the one that it desired. About those three projections it said: 'These are the projections for the years ahead'.

Let me look at them. I turn first to projection A. It has been said and not denied that that is the projection that the Labor Party favours. Let anyone deny that. In any case, what the Government cannot deny is that one of the projections A, B or C is the projection that it favours. Let us examine what happens under projection A. The figures of the Treasurer show that in 1982-83 620,000 people will be unemployed. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has promised that the unemployment rate for the next year will be the same or lower. The projection for 1983-84 is 700,000 unemployed, an increase of 80,000 over the previous year. What has happened to the Government's promise? Under projection A , in 1984-85 720,000 will be unemployed and in 1985-86 710,000. In fact, under option A, which is allegedly favoured by the Labor Party, at the end of this Government's regime unemployment rather than decreasing by two percentage points will have moved from the base that the Labor Party identified as 620,000 in 1982 -83 to at least 710,000. That is a very significant increase in the numbers of people unemployed. Indeed, the Prime Minister was supported by Mr Keating in his statement that the unemployment rate will remain the same.

Of course, projection B is more horrific. It puts unemployment at 620,000 for 1982-83; 740,000 for 1983-84-an increase of 120,000 when Mr Hawke said that there would be no increase- 840,000 for 1984-85; and 880,000 for 1985-86. Option B, which was put to the Summit for consideration, projected an increase of 260, 000 in the number of unemployed during the period of the Hawke Government. Let us examine projection C. It shows 620,000 unemployed for 1982-83 and 680,000 for 1983-84, an increase of 60,000-what has happened to Mr Hawke's promise?-680,000 for 1984-85, and 640,000 for 1985-86.

So, at the Summit, when speaking about each of the three projections, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister said: 'We will in fact have more unemployment at the end of the Hawke Government's regime that at the beginning'. Yet, the whole of the election was poised on the issue of jobs. The argument was that the Labor Party would create many more jobs than the Fraser government would have created. Now, indeed, the Labor Party has changed its tune; but what an extraordinary change in tune. Having listened to delegates to the Summit and having heard it said by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party that the issue facing the Summit concerned three things, jobs, jobs and jobs-that achieved applause from the Labor Party-we now find that the Summit itself said there will be fewer jobs, fewer jobs, fewer jobs over the three years of the Labor Government. Of course, it will not necessarily run three years. I understand that Mr David Combe has indicated that his view is that an election will be held at the end of the next year. That is an extraordinary situation for a government which is deriding anything but fixed term parliaments.

I looked at the address of the Governor-General bearing in mind that it was written by the Labor Party as a Labor Party document and I said to myself: ' Clearly, if this is to be the policy speech of the Labor Party in precis then, of course, it will essentially be directed towards the relief of unemployment- jobs, jobs, jobs'. One has to search hard to find a mention on unemployment, or any real evidence of job creation in this document. I think that the document uses the word 'unemployment' some five times and enlarges on it in only one paragraph which says that unemployment has increased. The document states that we will have a community works program which will include jobs on local roads. There must be great cheer about that. After all, that is scarcely something that will excite the imagination of the community or give rise to the concept that there will be an increase in skills.

We have an extraordinary situation in which the whole campaign of the Labor Party, based on the reduction of unemployment, is reduced to nothing, turned around at the Summit and subsequently muted in the Governor-General's Speech. In my political lifetime, which extends over the post-war years, never before have I seen such an abdication from the policies of the Government. However, the Government is in no way in any difficulty about this matter because at the moment on virtually everything that it touches it turns its policy around. There is a great noise that consultation, discussion and consensus are the things. My goodness, today members of the Government have said: 'We will not have any pre- Budget consultations at all. We will have an Economic Planning Advisory Council which will consist of a group of the biggies; we will not have any consultations with sections of the community.' That goes out because now that the Labor Party is in government it does not have to worry about those kinds of things.

It has been quite fascinating to watch, one by one, the great outcries of the Labor Party about the purchase of Boeing 707 aircraft for their ordinary purposes of carrying military personnel between Butterworth and Australia, or to be used for refuelling. What will the Labor Party do now? It will not sell the aircraft which it said it would do; it will buy two more. Why will the Labor Party buy two more? It will buy them for refuelling purposes, so it says, even though it derided us for using them for such a purpose. I will be very interested to hear from the Labor Party about one of its former promises. Will the Labor Party say, even though the security people in Australia made it very clear that no Prime Minister of Australia should travel overseas on a commercial aircraft because of the dangers of putting at risk ordinary people on that aircraft, that it will not use any VIP aircraft for overseas travel by its Prime Minister or other Ministers? Will it state that such people will fly on commercial aircraft or on chartered aircraft? How will Mr Hawke travel abroad in the immediate months ahead?

What an extraordinary situation it is now that the Government has changed its policy! How extraordinary it is that the former Labor Government chose a man, saying he was the superlative choice of all people, to be Governor-General of Australia and because he did not do as the Government told him, turned on him when he was appointed to the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation. He was a man much more qualified in the law than others, a man of international status, President and conceiver of the Law Association for Asia and the Western Pacific but it is all right for the people who criticised him to appoint their former Prime Minister to such a position! I do not criticise that. Gough Whitlam will do a good job. What kind of irony is it that the Government should first of all laud a person, then seek to destroy him; to say of a man with no more qualifications that he is suitable and that the other person is not ? So step by step they knock things. There were promises in the election campaign that there would be tax cuts. Where is the mention of tax cuts in this report?

Let me look at the extraordinary issue that ran very strongly in the election campaign. I refer to the Gordon below Franklin Dam. One would have thought that if one were opposed to the Gordon below Franklin Dam one would have fixed policies to ensure that the people of Tasmania had electric power and jobs and that those policies would be in position. It is a little aberration of thought that the former leader to the Labor Party gave an undertaking in writing to the people of Tasmania that this was a State matter and that there would be no Federal intervention. That broken little promise along the journey, was capable of being reported. Now what do we find? We find an extraordinary statement in this document. Let me read it because it is in prospect, not in retrospect. It states:
My Government is also committed to investigating possibilities for alternative hydro electricity schemes and employment-generating activities in Tasmania.

The Government is investigating them while it is seeking in the High Court of Australia to stop the construction and create disemployment. Investigating them? It is committed to doing it. There is no sign of the fact that it had any kind of policies in hand for this matter at all; it will investigate it. Indeed, it is fascinating to read through this report. Honourable senators should look at the kind of matters mentioned. For instance, was there any suggestion or disclosure to the Public Service of Australia before the election that the proposal was to re-enact one of the nasty influences of the Whitlam regime-the creation of a new level in the Public Service; to bring in people from outside, as it did, and create all the troubles that it created in the past? Did the Government do that? No. That was what we call a sleeve trick; it was up the Government's sleeve.

We are looking at the kind of statements and promises that were made. There was to be a national recovery loan scheme to raise money to provide jobs for the unemployed. If it had been embarked upon it would have been disastrous, but it was the key in the election campaign to providing the money. When Mr Hawke was asked: 'Where will you get the money?' He said: 'We will get it largely from the national recovery bonds'. Now, this morning, the Government has said: 'We do not think we are going to have them'. Thank God for that! I could not think of anything more stupid than indexed bonds which would get preference over other lending and which would draw money out of the building societies and savings banks-draw it away from enterprise generally-and put it into that scheme. But no , both the promises about unemployment and about the money to assist unemployment have gone now-gone with the wind.

There were lots of fascinating little euphemisms about how we will get on with the Association of South East Asian Nations. What an embarrassment to the Labor Party it must have been this morning, still flirting with the idea of giving aid to Vietnam, when it was disclosed that the Vietnamese are extensively using chemical warfare on the people of Kampuchea. How can Government senators sit there a day longer without saying: 'We must stop any thought of this because an increase in civil aid would enable the diversion of resources in Vietnam and Kampuchea towards the military and towards the bloody murder of people'? What use is there in people standing up here and talking about peace when they are in fact advocating policies that will encourage destruction? Let the Labor Party look today at the headlines in the paper and look to the fact that it is now on an enormous tiger.

Wherever I look in the Australian Labor Party's policy speech I notice a very interesting thing. I notice a reference to the fact that it will embark upon its stated policies to reverse all the off-shore legislation. Let the Government deny this. The clear statement in its pre-election campaign was that it would reverse all the legislation that had been so painstakingly put through this House. The Australian Labor Party said, when it was talking about the Franklin Dam: 'Oh, no, you mistake us. We are not really destroying the Federal system'. Not much! I know of nothing that will cause more havoc and more mayhem amongst all State Premiers, including the four Labor State Premiers, than to assert the sovereignty of the Commonwealth to low tide mark.

Let any honourable senator opposite get up and say that the Government is not going to do it. We would be very interested to have an admission that that is so . Let any honourable senator get up and describe the centralising powers of the inter-state commission that will be set up. When one looks at the Gordon below Franklin Dam, apart from the aberration and embarrassment of what has been said by the previous Labor leader, one needs to look at all the other centralising activities that are being set up. So we have in a most extraordinary statement a reference to aviation. But does that statement refer to a two-airline system of aviation? Not at all. The whole of the second system of airlines-Ansett Airlines of Australia and the other private airlines-is omitted. The Government has said that it will support further the government airlines. In the absence of any suggestions that the Government will maintain the two airline system, I take it that that is a direct threat-as it always has been-to the twin airline system.

Wherever one looks throughout this statement one sees a running away from the most essential thing that is necessary for the development of Australia which is the water resources program. There is a statement to the effect that the Government will refer the various programs to the Study on the Perspective of Water Resources to the Year 2000. This Government knows, because it was stated in the Senate, that that Committee had seen and approved the list of water projects that had been announced. But there are no projects that could create jobs for the future and all the projects that were ready to go are now being put aside and shelved. I predict that they are being put aside so that the Government can make political decisions as to what electorates will be favoured and what electorates will not. Let the Government now say that it will proceed with projects such as the Splitrock Dam project. Let it say that or let it be criticised properly for hiding behind a pretext because indeed that Committee reviewed those things.

We have a situation where the Governor-General's Speech was supposed to reflect the Labor Party's policy speech. The policy speech had been geared to unemployment and methods of creating jobs. Nothing in the Governor-General's Speech focused upon that. It mentioned casually in passing a number of times the word 'unemployment' but it did not set out in any specific detail at all the key and vital things. It showed that step by step the Labor Government will distance itself from its promises and that it will do so on the most faulty of all pretexts. The Government will say: 'We would have loved to have done all these things but the Budget deficit is too big'. I remind honourable senators that for seven years the Labor Party has said: 'We need great expansive opportunities in Australia. We need to expand the Budget deficit so we can do more and more'. That was its argument in this campaign. It knew very well that a deficit which would be running at at least $4 billion in this financial year would be running at a very much higher figure in the future. It argued, nevertheless, that it would spend more and more. In no way could a Labor Party in this place use the excuse of a large deficit to hide behind broken promises. It has made those promises. It has made the promises on how to fund unemployment. It said it would fund the unemployment in any case with a loan scheme which it is now running away from. Step by step it is now proving that the things that it proposed cannot be implemented. Mr Keating and the papers of the National Economic Summit Conference prove that the Australian Labor Party knows-and knew-that there will be more unemployment at the end of the Labor Party's three years in office than at the beginning. There could be no greater condemnation of any policy speech or any address than that and those facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech to make some observations on aspects of that Speech. A number of us would have liked to have had perhaps a little more time to prepare our observations. There has been some telescoping of debate today. I notice that the 'telescoping' has lost the Australian Labor Party altogether because there are to be three Opposition speakers in a row. We will, therefore, endeavour to bring forward points which are relevant in the discussions of the Governor- General's Speech and to indicate attitudes on a number of general matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to convey to the President-as this is the first opportunity I have had-my warm congratulations to him on his elevation to the Presidency. He has, by his long service in this Parliament and his service as Chairman of Committees, indicated his fairness and ability to perform the duties with which he has now been entrusted by this Parliament. I have no doubt that he will make a very outstanding President of the Senate. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you also to convey my congratulations to the Deputy President. He is a colleague of mine from Victoria and has been a close personal friend for many years. I have, likewise, the same great confidence that he will perform his duties admirably. His great interest in the Parliament and the future of the institution is such that there is no doubt that he will be very helpful to the President and to the Senate in the performance of his duties. I also would like to make some remarks about the new senators who have already spoken. I have listened to most of their speeches. It is obvious that a considerable amount of new and excellent talent is coming to the Senate. Their addresses have been excellent. Even more important will be the contribution which they will make in the committee work of the Parliament. I welcome them and wish them well in their careers.

Criticism has been made in the Address-in-Reply speeches to the Governor- General's Speech which the Governor-General delivered on behalf of the Government. I must say that I am disappointed in that Speech. I will refer to a couple of aspects of it. I hoped it would have more content in the actual proposals being made by the Government. In the concluding stages of that Speech, at page 15, the Government has this to say:

The spirit of co-operation which marked the National Economic Summit Conference last week has, my advisers believe, laid good foundations for a renewed national effort to enable Australia and its people to surmount the present grave crisis and indeed emerge from it a more united, stronger, and better nation.
The comprehensive program I have outlined is designed to further the great national goals of reconciliation, recovery and reconstruction.

I did feel that there was some moving from the high rhetoric which had enveloped Mr Hawke during the election period. I did not think that that Speech indicated very much in the way of co-operation that would be proposed, and which I think is a desirable feature of government in this Parliament. I will not repeat what was said by my colleague, Senator Sir John Carrick, in respect of the lack of reference to unemployment in the Governor-General's Speech. But it is indeed curious that after the tremendous, and I think important, emphasis that was given to it during the election campaign there is so little about it in the Speech and so little indication of the positive steps that will be taken. In addition, and more specifically, the Prime Minister emphasised a spirit of co- operation during both the election campaign and in his statements immediately after the election.

I refer in particular to the references made in the Governor-General's Speech to parliamentary, legal and constitutional reform, which I will deal with in a little more detail in a moment. The Speech states:
My advisers deeply believe that public confidence in the effectiveness and integrity of our parliamentary institution must be strengthened.

I could not agree more with that statement. It is my belief-I have spoken about this on many occasions, both in public and in this chamber-that the Parliament has moved very much away from centre stage; that the Executive has too much dominance in this country. I would have liked to have seen the Prime Minister expand on what he means by increasing confidence in the effectiveness of Parliament. The Speech deals with a couple of instances with regard to legislation. But very little is to be gained from the Speech about the fundamental area of the major role which the Parliament should play but does not play. The Governor-General's Speech states:
The Parliamentary Committee system of the national Parliament will be strengthened to give Members of Parliament a more effective role and participation in the great affairs of this nation.

I understand that it is proposed that the House of Representatives should cease to have merely a few sporadic committees, which has been the case for some years , and will have a more organised committee system covering wider fields of policy. I would have liked to have seen the extent of that proposal. I will make some practical suggestions later about the parliamentary committee system. We in the Senate tend to be very proud of it and perhaps excessively confident in its continued existence and strength. I do not reflect on the committee systems in other areas of the Parliament. I would like to see more detail about those matters.

I have said that the Government made a very strong plea for a spirit of co- operation. In past years in Budget debates, I have made many speeches in which I have made the same plea and request that we should reduce the extent of polarisation, conflict and division which have rent the Parliament for many years. Those ideas were certainly picked up and applied very effectively by the present Government in the last election campaign. I regret that when we were in government we did not do more to achieve a reduction in the polarisation and conflicts which occurred, and did not more positively seek co-operation, which would have had economic as well as useful political effects. One remembers that on the night of the election, when it was clear that Mr Hawke had been elected, he made strong statements about the fact that he wanted to involve all Australians, including the Opposition, in the work of government, in the work of the Parliament and so forth. So far there has been inadequate demonstration that that will become a reality. A small example concerns the Parliament's sitting hours, the possible discordance between the two chambers and the difficulties which will be faced by people trying to organise committee meetings which concern members of both chambers. In this area the previous Government did involve the Opposition in this chamber in discussions about sitting hours. I believe that the present Government has not really done so. The hours were announced to the Parliament. I know that they are operating on a temporary basis only, but I suggest that to a small degree-I do not want to make too much of this-it was an indication that there needs to be more co-operation. Both sides of the chamber have problems with regard to meetings and the proper conduct of their business. I hope that these matters will be given further attention.

Senator Coleman, earlier this morning, had some fairly strong things to say about the number of elections we have had in this country over recent years. Basically I agree with what she said. In my opinion the holding of many elections in a country is not necessarily a good thing. Of course, in the United States, which I have just visited, the House of Representatives, a relatively weak chamber, goes out every two years. The presidential election runs over a year or more. There seems to be a great deal of electioneering all the time. It is not my opinion that long periods of electioneering, instead of long periods of government, are desirable. I hope that we are moving away from a period of premature elections which sometimes brought the two Houses into alignment and sometimes put them out of alignment, as has happened recently. I hope that we are reaching a period when we will know where we stand. I will not go into the question of fixed terms, but I will certainly have plenty to say about that shortly. My views on that subject are well known from remarks which I have made publicly and privately over many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —We certainly need a remedy on both sides.

—We need a remedy and we also need some certainty. We also need to remove from the economic community the insecurity which it has over long periods in that it never knows whether there will be an election now, in six months or next year. The mere expansion of the term from, say, three years to four years will not cure that problem. In fact in some ways it will exacerbate it because it will mean, as we see Mrs Thatcher doing at the moment, that there will be a longer period in which to play with the public as to whether there will or will not be an early election. Therefore, I think we have to find a real solution to this problem in the interests of the economy, quite apart from the interests of Parliament in being able to settle down and clear its decks of legislation, which most parliaments have not done in the last eight or ten years . We have left behind matters which have had to be reintroduced and then proceeded with. The excessive number of elections is widely criticised by the public now and we in this Parliament must do our best to find proper solutions to that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a great deal of discussion about whether we can achieve consensus in the parliamentary situation. To an extent I think the word ' consensus' is an unfortunate one. I think it more important that there be positive attitudes in a parliament. Of course there must be conflict. An opposition seeks at all stages to get itself into a position from which it can become a government as soon as it can. It seems to me very important that in opposition there be a positive attitude towards a government program and that there be a recognition that whenever a government wins an election decisively it is entitled to expect that its program generally will be brought to fruition. If an opposition does not like that program or does not like aspects of Bills, it will criticise details of the Bills and will try to improve them, but if a government insists generally it should have its way. That will be an area of argument to be used against that government in an attempt to turn it out at the next election. But oppositions should not consider themselves governments in exile and I certainly do not intend to take any such attitude in this Parliament .

There has been criticism of the National Economic Summit Conference and support for it. I was out of the country when it took place. I was attending a conference which I will refer to in this speech. From what I can see, I believe the Summit Conference was a worthwhile venture. Obviously, some of its achievements will be disappointing and, in fact, those achievements were not as great as perhaps one would believe at first glance. It should be recognised, however, as an excellent effort by the various elements of the economic equation to get together and to try to find solutions. I regret that political leaders were not also at the Summit. I think in that way it was narrow in its concept. That was a pity. But I cannot agree with those who seem at times to criticise the leaders of our business community for having attended and having made efforts at that Conference. I believe that their efforts were desirable and good and that they should be praised for them. They should not be denigrated for their attempts to achieve things; nor should it be suggested that they were naive in their approaches to these matters.

I believe that there is a lot of experience in the economic community that needs to be brought into operation and which governments should use. I welcome that, along with the further information which the Summit Conference obviously brought out so that people could have a better idea of what are the problems in the economy. So far as attitudes are concerned, in this Parliament there will, of course, be plenty of opportunities for us to examine the Government's possible legislation. I hope to take positive attitudes, although critical on occasions, towards the legislation which it brings in.

One of the areas in which I am interested is that of constitutional and legal affairs. The Government has quite a massive program on that subject ahead of it. I recognise that a number of those areas are areas which we, when in government, did not pursue to the full. There is unfinished business which the last Parliament did not tackle or debate. Amongst them are matters of family law which, quite scandalously really, are waiting to be dealt with by the Parliament . Parliament has not put aside sufficient time to deal with the recommendations which a joint committee of the Parliament made two or three years ago. Many of the recommendations have been added to the Bill which was before the last Parliament but which was never debated by it.

In the same category is the Criminal Investigation Bill. It has been introduced into various parliaments, has been met with a howl of rage from police forces- not the Commonwealth force, but police forces of the States who fear that it may be used as a guide to their legislation-and each time the Bill has then been sent off for further study. I am glad to see that it is coming back into the Parliament and that, at last, the recommendation which the Law Reform Commission made-it must be eight years ago now-will at least have a chance to be debated for the first time by the Parliament. The way in which the very valuable work of the Law Reform Commission has been presented to the Parliament over the years- only to a very limited degree has it been implemented-is one of the failings of the Parliament. It is not a party political failing. It is, I think, a failure by members of the Parliament to be prepared to take up the results of money which has been spent, the work which has been done, and the opinions explored throughout Australia by the Law Reform Commission and to actually see whether they can be brought into force. We have to find better means of ensuring that those matters are dealt with.

In regard to the law reform and constitutional program of the Government, so far as I am concerned, I personally am determined to operate in a positive way towards it. I might feel some disappointment that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee's report on freedom of information, which I had the honour to present to this Parliament in 1979 and which was implemented only in part by the previous Government, is now to adorn the credit of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and others because it is now going to be implemented, largely in its entirety, I hope. If it is not going to be-if the little hints one gets that the Attorney-General is having difficulty in getting that legislation through are true-I can assure him that I will be harrying this Government, as I harried the Whitlam and Fraser governments, so that those things will be brought to fruition and that promises will be kept. I say, as a promise to the Parliament, that so far as I am concerned--

TALK.START.PARA: —A promise or a threat?

—Let us call it a promise. Let us be positive and not talk about threats. My promise is that I will certainly be probing away like mad to see that the Government's promises are kept and that Ministers, once they settle in and surround themselves with their 'Sir Humphreys' and their other public servants, do not find themselves induced not to give away the secrets which are so beloved of public servants.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just been to the United States of America where I spent a number of days in Washington looking at the freedom of information legislation. The Congress of the United States has not yet even altered the United States freedom of information legislation but the Reagan Administration has done an enormous amount to tear the heart out of the practical operation of that legislation by intimidating public servants through presidential directives requiring them to enter into pre-publication agreements and to submit for censorship any information that they have and by threatening them with holograph or lie detector tests to ascertain whether there are leakages as to the various ways in which the United States Government has operated. That being so, the principle of freedom of information has suffered considerable blows in the United States of America, but it is not because of alteration of the words of the legislation. In general I warn the Government that insofar as information relating to national security and other matters of that sort may be put forward as information that ought not to be disclosed, it should be very careful not to draft legislation in such a way that unsympathetic governments or unsympathetic Ministers can manage to make use of these things to deny real freedom of information to this country. I believe that a positive attitude towards the law and constitutional reform is essential. I hope that the Opposition will develop that positive attitude.

I shall just make a glancing remark about that happening last week-at the Constitutional Convention in Adelaide. I found it to be an incredible gathering. It was incredible that gerrymandering should be used so blatantly to concoct majorities for certain things. I really do not think it matters much which way the votes went at that Convention. I think the case for an elected or partially elected convention was made even more strongly by the holding of that Convention . I think it was a regrettable incident to be put rapidly in the past. I hope that very little notice will be taken of the sizes of votes and majorities that took place at that rather regrettable Convention. My main reason for using this example of reform areas is a belief that we on the Opposition should face all the various areas of law and constitutional reform in which we have had some slackness of effort in the past. I believe that we should look at those areas thoroughly and criticise proposals where they are subject to criticism-we should not move away from them just because of embarrassment-but at the same time we should adopt a positive attitude towards those matters which have been put positively before the electorate and largely endorsed.

In this Parliament our numbers are such that there is weakness so far as the Opposition is concerned. In any election where there is a fairly dramatic swing, the people who are lost are often the young and the talented members. Clearly, the Opposition has suffered in this way. I wish to make a reference which I did not make as part of the remarks directed to retiring members last Tuesday evening because I did not want to ruin the atmosphere which was then engendered. A not so young senator, but one of great ability, who was lost from the Senate was Senator Neville Bonner. I deeply regret his loss because I believe that he had a fine contribution yet to make to the Parliament. I believe that I understand what happened in regard to him. I make no reflection, of course, upon my colleague from Queensland Senator MacGibbon who took former Senator Bonner's place. Three honourable senators were retiring and there were only enough Liberal votes for two of them to be re-elected. Nobody can criticise any retiring senator for wanting to be re-elected. But we know that Senator Bonner lost his seat-I remind the Labor Party of this-because of the Labor Party preferences. We know that it will be to the eternal disgrace of the Labor Party in Queensland that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who dropped him from his correct position on the ticket?

—Yes, the honourable senator can say that. I will criticise people in the Liberal Party who, I think, took racist attitudes in Queensland and who are now sorry for doing that. I do not in any way move from that situation. I believe that was a terrible and foolish decision which those people regret. But Senator Bonner was not defeated by that fact because he was 17,000 votes ahead until the Labor Party preferences in Queensland were counted. I have in my hand a document showing the preferences, for example, in Mr Hayden's seat, and they are about the same in every Queensland seat. The preferences of the Labor Party go-after their own candidates and the Democrats-to the National Party, the Liberal Party, the Socialist Workers Party and, almost at the end of the list, Senator Bonner. The Labor Party swept Senator Bonner aside and ignored a serious candidate. That turned a lead of about 17,000 votes into a deficit of 10,000 or so votes. I do not exclude from this criticism the Australian Democrats. It is true that their preferences were hardly used or they may not have been used at all.
—We didn't give preferences to anyone.

—I am sorry but the Australian Democrats did give two lots of preferences on their card. They gave the Liberal Party preferences which, of course, went against Senator Bonner. The alternative was the Labor Party preferences which also went against Bonner. The Democrats did not have a card directing preferences to Senator Bonner. In fact, they gave preferences against Senator Bonner doubly, but actually those preferences were not used. The Democrats were lucky in that they did not get enough votes for preferences to have to be used. I just say that I believe the Democrats also were, to a minor degree, at fault in ignoring the fact that they gave two preferences, both of them hostile to a worthy candidate. To the Labor Party, because it has to take the main blame, I say this: Senator Bonner risked a great deal of criticism. He probably helped to put himself in a bad position in his own party by voting for Senator Ryan's private member's Bill on Aboriginal affairs. He took a strong stand on Aboriginal affairs. He was, in fact, crucified by Labor Party preferences, 19 per cent of which went to him and 81 per cent of which went to the Liberal Party.
—Our how to vote card was designed to reduce the informal vote; that was the sole reason.

—I do not accept that it was only for that reason. I heard the Labor Party's secretary in Queensland being very critical of Senator Bonner after the election day. He was very critical and stated that Senator Bonner might be given a job or might not be given a job because he talked about certain matters. I doubt that that is altogether a true reason that Senator Tate gives. On the other hand, it is still a disgrace because one cannot use that across-the -card business when a serious candidate will be affected. If one does that, one eliminates and ignores a man who could obviously poll well and who could have been elected. Honourable senators opposite must suffer the consequences. One must bear in mind that the Labor Party has besmirched its record in this respect .
—We had a national executive decision to make all of the tickets as simple as possible because in the past it has cost us control of this place.

—Yes, to make them as simple as possible is a good idea but not at the expense of a serious candidate. That is ridiculous. Anyway, I make the point that his departure from the Parliament is because of the preferences of other parties and their actions. The public should never forget that.

SPEECH.PARA: I was going to say something about the Ottawa conference which I have just attended but I think time will not allow me to say more than that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Tate and I were away for some weeks at the conference on delegated legislation which was a very successful conference. No doubt there will be opportunities later to speak about that conference. From that conference came an indication that there are moves in the United States of America and the rest of the world to see that the control over regulations and the scrutiny of them is dealt with in a way which is perhaps better than the way in which we deal with regulations. We deal with regulations in a 'technical' scrutiny sense. In this Parliament we in fact have powers which are greater than those in any other parliament. On the other hand, nowhere in the Parliament do we examine the policies or merits of the regulations, the need for regulations or the best method of considering regulations. I just wanted to make that point in passing. I hope to have an opportunity to speak at more length on that at a later stage. It is an area with which I hope this Parliament will deal. I hope that we will not rest on our laurels because of the fact that we have fairly good control in this area, particularly in the Senate because of the work performed by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. More has to be done in the control of regulations in this country. There are indications elsewhere of the ways in which it may be done.

I conclude my remarks by saying that I hope a bipartisan approach will be adopted in relation to many issues that will crop up in this Parliament. For example, I hope that in the human rights area we will have considerable opportunity to adopt a bipartisan approach. I believe that we are facing a situation in which the world, particularly the United States Government, has moved into a very quiet phase on human rights. There are indications that countries such as the United States and Australia ought to use sometimes discriminating opportunities to exercise human rights powers. Indeed we ought to do more in this direction. This Parliament has many matters with which it has to deal. I have not mentioned dams. I have not mentioned the various other changes. There are many areas in which parliament, I believe, can be constructive if the Government really wants it to be constructive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to talk about organised crime in Australia, particularly organised crime in Sydney. I want to talk about the inability or the lack of purpose of politicians in pursuing organised crime, the extent of organised crime in Australia and, to some extent, the capacity of royal commissions to deal with organised crime. Before I do so, however, I wish to refer to His Excellency the Governor-General, whose Speech we are replying to today. I have looked with great interest at the published correspondence between the former Prime Minister and His Excellency concerning the reasons for the recent double dissolution. I have some difficulty in contemplating constitutional matters because I am not a lawyer and the more lawyers talk about these matters the more confused I become. The reason for my confusion is that as I understand the speeches made by His Excellency when he was a justice of the High Court-these remarks are not necessarily meant as a criticism of His Excellency, the present Governor-General-he believed that the mere trigger of a Bill being rejected twice by the Senate was not enough to warrant the automatic and immediate granting of a double dissolution. I hope that I am not paraphrasing His Excellency incorrectly when I say that.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a chain of circumstances recently wherein the previous Prime Minister requested a double dissolution of the Parliament. The mechanical triggers for a double dissolution were available because Bills-I think 13-had been rejected twice by the Senate with the prescribed three months interval between their rejection. Of those Bills, nine related to imposing sales tax on the necessities of life. Those Bills had been rejected the previous year. That seems to have been forgotten in the debate that has ensued about the recent double dissolution . A Bill was introduced to prevent the dole being paid to the spouses of strikers. Another Bill sought to reintroduce the payment of fees for tertiary education. The rejection twice to those two Bills could hardly be described as making the Parliament unworkable. One assumes that if the Parliament was said to have been unworkable the rejection of the nine sales tax Bills, which represented part of the Budget, must have been the reason. The Bills were rejected not in last year's Budget, in August 1982, but in the August 1981 Budget. The Parliament had worked perfectly well for over a year notwithstanding the rejection of those Bills. What then were the circumstances under which the recent double dissolution was granted? I will not be told that that is not a fair question for a senator to ask. This is a hung Senate, although not a hostile Senate. It is not inconceivable that Bills will be rejected in this place during the term of this Government. It is not unreasonable to assume that some Bills may well be rejected twice with a three-month interval in between. I believe that I am entitled to know-not as a leader of a party, not as a politician, but as a citizen-under what circumstances can double dissolutions be granted.

Honourable senators will remember that, apparently, His Excellency was not satisfied with the original reasons given by Mr Fraser in his first letter and on his first visit. Sir Ninian Stephen requested further information. As I understand it, with my non-legal mind, His Excellency wanted to know whether because of the rejection of 13 Bills Parliament was unworkable or, to put it another way, whether the passage of those 13 Bills was crucial to good government in this country. The then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, said: 'Yes, they were'. Clearly the Governor-General cannot and should not, in my view, question or cross-examine a Prime Minister or argue that point with him. If the Prime Minister of the day says, 'Yes, the Bills are crucial to good government' or ' the Parliament is unworkable because they have not been passed', that should be enough for a Governor-General to say: 'Privately, I might disagree with you but I cannot argue with you. Therefore I will grant a double dissolution'.

That leads me to another point. I would have thought that the present Government would be interested in it, because it is pursuing vigorously, with the total support of the Australian Democrats, fixed terms of Parliament. I commend the Government for this and I wish it luck. God knows we deal with some trivial legislation from time to time. Let us assume that the Government brings in a Bill to make parking in the Australian Capital Territory cost $10 for half an hour, that it is passed by the House of Representatives and that it comes into the Senate and we knock it out. We wait three months, it is returned and again we knock it out. That Bill satisfies the provisions of section 57 of the Constitution. Following the last scenario in which Sir Ninian Stephen and Mr Fraser exchanged letters and conversed the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, could say to the Governor-General: 'I want a double dissolution; I have satisfied the provisions of section 57'. The Governor-General would ask: 'Is this Bill crucial to the performance of your Government?' If Mr Hawke said yes, which would be an absurd thing to say, am I given to understand that from that point on the Governor-General of this country has no option but to grant a double dissolution of the Parliament?

I raise these matters in a serious way. I will continue my correspondence with His Excellency, part of which has been published already. I hope that the responsible media will take up the matter and that it will engender further debate in the thinking sections of the community. This applies not only to lawyers but also to those people who have had a gutful of premature elections.

Knowing that every election now apparently costs $18.5m and knowing that the average time between Federal elections in this country since Federation has been something like two years and four months, this state of affairs, if it is as I understand it, is an invitation to an existing Prime Minister to tell a fib to the Governor-General-I put it no higher than that-if he sees a chance to have a double dissolution which politically suits him or his party. Surely that is an undesirable state of affairs. If I am in any way correct, this argument might be used in the forthcoming debate when the issue of fixed terms is put to the people, I hope this year. I thoroughly commend the Australian Labor Party for its courage, foresight and initiative in going ahead with this proposition after the failure of it in Adelaide. I now turn to organised crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't regard it as much of a turn.
—The pay is better than that for a politician, I should think. I now turn to discuss organised crime. Dr Alfred McCoy wrote in his world acclaimed book Drug Traffic:

SPEECH.PARA: No city in the world could rival Sydney's tolerance for organised crime.

That is a very serious accusation from a distinguished international author. Sydney happens to be in the State of New South Wales about which serious accusations as to its legal processes have been made. Last weekend the Australian Broadcasting Commission's program Four Corners alleged that there had been a conspiracy to pervert the course of justice in New South Wales. It was as clear and as simple as that. On the program it was stated that there were informants who would testify to that fact. The transcript reads:

None of our informants were to appear on this programme but each is willing to give evidence on oath before a properly constituted inquiry as to the truth of the statements they've already made to us.
Further in the transcript this appears:

The magistrates we have talked to, felt that none of the responsible authorities were sufficiently independent of the New South Wales Government of the day. They had little hope that steps would be taken to establish the truth.

I shall join the two statements together. McCoy said that no city in the world could rival Sydney's tolerance for organised crime and a responsible television program stated that there had been a conspiracy to pervert the course of justice . I would have thought that these are very serious matters. Let none of us think that if there is organised crime in Sydney its effects remain in Sydney. If it is the crime capital of Australia, as the Moffitt Royal Commission on Alleged Organised Crime in Registered Clubs in New South Wales established, and it was established for that purpose, the heroin peddled on Acland Street, St Kilda, flows from the organised crime that is running rampant in the city of Sydney today, aided by crooked policemen supported at higher levels by all sorts of other creatures.

I have no intention of referring to political figures or attempting to gain any political capital. All I say is that, as the Senate knows, some writs for defamation have been taken out against the ABC. We know that, under the peculiar , strange or unusual laws relating to sub judice and also the very peculiar laws relating to evidence in New South Wales, the mere fact that those writs for defamation have been issued precludes all public discussion within New South Wales and, to some extent, in this chamber of the allegation made on the Four Corners program. It also precludes discussion of any kind in the New South Wales Parliament until the writs have been satisfied. Has any honourable senator in this Senate ever heard of a writ for defamation being heard within a reasonably short time or am I correct in assuming that sometimes it can take up to two years or three years?

What does a writ for defamation do? I am not saying that these are the reasons for the writs that have been taken out. If those kinds of aspersions had been made about me I would have had a writ on the ABC quick and lively also. I am not being critical of that. It is a politician's right to do that, but it means that any real discussion about these accusations will not be able to be held for one year, two years, three years or whatever. It is pathetic to think that people who had the courage to say last weekend that they were prepared to give evidence on oath as witnesses will to some extent be softened up one year, two years or three years from now. I remind the Senate that this is happening in the city of Sydney which is unrivalled in the world for its tolerance of organised crime. Does anybody in this chamber really believe that those witnesses will be as enthusiastic about giving evidence of a conspiracy to pervert justice two years from now in a city which is as notorious for hoodlums, gangsterism, violence as any in the world?

TALK.START.PARA: —If they are so conscientious you would think that they would have made the allegations six years ago.

—If Senator Ray has any information which will throw light on this matter I will yield to him so that he can produce it. In fact he will have an opportunity during this debate. I believe that we need speakers to jump up and give us the benefit of their knowledge and experience on the matter. I would be grateful to hear the honourable senator on this matter. That is why I was dismayed at the Attorney-General's response to me last Tuesday. Clearly, the writ for defamation on the ABC was properly and rightly lodged by the Premier of New South Wales. All that it seeks out, as I read the transcript, is whether a phone call was made by the Premier to Mr Farquhar and the contents of that phone call. It does not go to the issue of whether there was a conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. The Wran writ cannot go that far. Where does that leave us? In two or three years we will let that question go by default. I regard that as an extraordinarily serious matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to another matter concerning organised crime. Sometimes I despair and that is why I have asked the Federal Attorney-General to intervene in this matter. I did so virtually with tongue in cheek because other than Costigan, who has been brilliant in opening up the corridors of power and corruption in this country, I am singularly unimpressed with other Federal incursions into fact- finding in the area of crime in this country. I refer to Woodward, Williams and Stewart. With your permission, Mr Acting Deputy President, because I know I am on delicate ground, I will mention those commissions to some extent.
