Over a year ago, in March 1982, in the Senate I had occasion to remark on the report of the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking. The major part of the report was made available on a private basis to the then Senate Opposition Leader, Senator Button. In the course of the debate on the report I made the following points: Firstly, that the heroin street market has been generating profits-profits, not turnover-of $250m a year, emanating from illegal importation. That, by itself, is a greater profit than that made by Telecom Australia in any one year. Equally, there were profits of $250m from the illegal sale and importation of cannabis. Another $100m to $155m in profits was made from illegal gambling, essentially in the city of Sydney, through which at least one royal commission has established, drug money is laundered. This is going on in our own country. I also remarked that with those kinds of profits available, what policeman, magistrate, judge or even politician can be considered safe from possible attempts at corruption. I then stated that in my view the Queensland police force, among others, had been exposed as one of the most corrupt groups of law enforcement officials in the world and that the royal commissions of Williams and Woodward were tragic and useless wastes of money.

During the debate Senator Sir John Carrick challenged his fellow senators and said: 'Look, we all ought to stand up and be counted if any of us have any information at all on drug trafficking'. He recommended that we go to the royal commissioner with information that we had in our possession, and expressed his confidence that the royal commissioner would be willing to take information in confidence. That is fair enough. The Australian Labor Party, through Senator Gerry Jones, voiced solidarity with the Liberal Government in this regard. Senator Jones stated:
Senator Chipp does not have the evidence. Senator Chipp is naming people.
In fact, I named no-one, not one name. Senator Jones continued:

It is very easy to name people in this place. We should allow the joint task force, those commissions and those people investigating the matter, to take the evidence and then let us be the judge. Let us not judge on rumours, say-so, correspondence or a story which someone has told . . .we should let the royal commissions do the job.

I agree with every word he said. It is commendable stuff. I listened to those arguments and I took them seriously and took them at their word. In May 1982 I hand delivered-after giving evidence to the Stewart Royal Commission-to Mr Justice D. G. Stewart, the royal commissioner, on the inquiry into drug trafficking, 376 pages of detailed notes, original documents relating to various matters connected with the illegal importation of drugs into Australia. For my own protection-I do not want to sound melodramatic on this-I asked the then Prime Minister of Australia whether he would take carbon copies of the documents so that there would be some protection of me. He graciously agreed to do so.

The information I provided to Mr Justice Stewart named names. It provided tangible evidence which suggested corruption on the part of very senior officers of the Queensland police force and others. By the very nature of the subject matter of my submission to the royal commissioner this undertaking was fraught with grave risks to the personal safety not only of me but also of all persons who could be traced as informants in those 376 pages of documents. Ten months later the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Stewart, wrote to me. The Standing Orders ensure that I say only this: I am deeply disappointed by his response. I wish the Standing Orders could allow me to say a lot more about Mr Justice Stewart. Mr Justice Stewart's letter fell into two sections. He told me, in general terms, how wonderful the Commission was and how many exhibits, statements and witnesses the Royal Commission had considered. He then said how baseless and untrue were the inferences arising from the submissions I made. The most remarkable paragraph in the letter was perhaps the following. It states:

Only police forces have the basic resources to investigate criminal activities. Amateurs without access to criminal intelligence may cause sensations but they will rarely assist in catching the drug trafficker. The Commission is firmly of the view that any person, whether a member of Parliament, of the press or of the public, who has any material suggesting that criminal offences have been committed should make that material available to the Queensland Police or the Australian Federal Police Force and should reject the temptation to publish the material.

In other words, a person who has evidence against a policeman should not publish it; he should go to the police so that they can investigate the matter. A royal commissioner told me this. I suggest, with respect, that that statement is one of the most ludicrous that can be imagined, when the Queensland Police, including very senior police officials, together with other officials are under suspicion. When the officials themselves stand accused, with good reason, of major wrong-doing, they can hardly be expected to handle accusatory evidence against them and their colleagues in a fair and impartial way. Is it not Ceasar being asked to inquire into Caesar? Only the very amateurs which the Commission has derided can pierce the veil of official secrecy and corruption. In any event , Mr Justice Stewart knew that all of the 376 pages that I gave him were submitted to me by a fully trained former police investigator of the Federal Narcotics Bureau. That was known by Mr Justice Stewart, yet he said to me: 'Don' t give me evidence submitted by amateurs'. I am sad to say, on the basis of what I have seen of the work of the Stewart Royal Commission, that it has joined the ranks of the Woodward Royal Commission and the Williams Royal Commission in making little contribution to investigatory progress. It is a sad day when those persons who are courageous enough to bring the evidence to the one branch of officialdom where it might do some good-the Royal Commission-are made to feel that they have acted foolishly or precipitately.

This exercise has not given me much comfort that the little person has any reason to expect effective action from the Government or its agencies. When we are confronted, even as politicians, with allegations such as those made in the Four Corners program, where do we go? Do we have any confidence at all in the New South Wales Police being able to investigate why charges of fraud brought several years ago were dropped? Does anyone have any confidence that they will be able to take such action? Allegedly, they will not be able to start their official investigation until the defamation writs have been settled. Does anybody here have any confidence that a royal commission will be able to find any truth and get to the bottom of organised crime in this country which, I repeat, now carries profits of over $700m a year? It is not impossible for it to appoint a select committee to inquire into these matters. I will contemplate that course of action unless we receive more co-operation on this matter from the Attorney and this Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, is again about the Royal Australian Air Force photographic flights over South West Tasmania. I refer the Attorney-General to the confirmation in the House of Representatives on Tuesday by the Minister for Defence that he did not give directions for the flights as required by paragraph 14 of the Defence Instructions (General) document which the Attorney tabled in this chamber on 22 April. I ask the Attorney: How does he reconcile the Minister's acknowledgement with the Attorney's statement, as recorded in Hansard of 22 April on page 67, that these flights involved no breach of the explicit language of the directions under which the Defence Force operates in these particular matters? Further, how does he reconcile his statement that these flights involved no breach of the explicit language of these directions with paragraph 17 (a) of these Instructions which state that where aid is provided in a no-force situation, which I assume this was, it must be first approved by the Chief of Defence Force Staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One really wishes that the Opposition would cease behaving like a collection of political down and outs nosing around the back alleys and garbage cans seeking scraps of trivia with which to belabour a government trying to get on with the serious business of running this country. That much said, let me proceed to answer the specifics of the question that the honourable senator put to me. The first point is that Mr Scholes has made it clear on the public record that he agreed to the particular task that was proposed to him. He has drawn a distinction between the agreement which he signified to me and the direct and specific authorisation of a particular task within the terms of the Defence Instructions to which the honourable senator referred. It is the case that there is no such direct written authorisation, although there was ministerial agreement. As a matter of law, since the Defence Instructions are themselves issued at a purely departmental level, as I understand it, there can be no question of their overriding in their effect the force of the agreement given at the ministerial level. So to that extent there is nothing to explain so far as the question of authority is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a real question as to which set of Defence Instructions should govern situations of this kind. There are, in fact, two possibly relevant sets of Defence Instructions. I have tabled only one such set because only one set was known to me at the time; that is, the Instructions relating to defence aid to the civil power. There is another set of Instructions relating to another category of aid. Regrettably I do not have them with me, otherwise I would be only too delighted to table them but I will make them available to the honourable senator afterwards; that is, the category of defence assistance to the civil community. I am endeavouring on this occasion, as on all others on which this matter has been raised, to be full, frank and honest in my dealings with the Senate and to lay out all the information that is available to me, a state of affairs which regrettably was not achieved by the Opposition when it was in government. There is some argument, I understand, within the defence establishment as to which was the appropriate set of procedures, defence aid to the civil power or defence assistance to the civil community. Under the latter set of procedures a quite different flow of authorisations and instructions, not involving the Chief of Defence Force Staff, let alone the Minister, is required. I simply make that point. If the Opposition is minded to make anything of the authorisation process, there is a real question as to what were the appropriate instructions. I by no means--

TALK.START.PARA: —But to which instructions were you referring in your answer?

—I was referring to the defence aid to the civil power about which there is some ambiguity anyway as to how one should read the force and effects of section 14, as I stated in the Senate. I do not think there is anything more I can say on that particular score. There is a condition of some uncertainty so far as the procedures which ought appropriately to apply at all levels of aid to the civil power are concerned, not only in non-force situations of the kind we are talking about but also in situations of call out, of civil violence or of a repetition of the Hilton bombing affair, should that ever recur . There is a very real need for a clarification of the law and procedures that should govern all these situations, a need that I made clear when in Opposition and which I now make clear in Government. I will be seeking a review of this whole area of law and practice with my colleague the Minister for Defence in the hope that we can do something to get all these procedures clearly established once and for all so that there will not be a repetition of this degree of uncertainty in the future.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Arising out of what the Attorney-General has told the Senate, will he table those documents rather than just provide them to me? Secondly, and more importantly, given that he acknowledges that he did not know about those instructions until very recently, at the time he was involved in these arrangements for this flight was he aware of the Defence Instructions generally which he tabled on 22 April?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware of the report to which Senator Maguire referred. I am gratified, as the Government is gratified, that the superiority of a profits based system of taxing extractive industries is recognised by the Chairman of Santos and by many other prominent mining industry figures. The concept of rent and the objectives behind it I think are such that one should not occupy a lot of time in Question Time explaining in full the reasons for the application of a rent-type tax instead of production taxes, as generally apply now. But I would like to say that virtually all mining and petroleum activity does pay taxation now. Sometimes the taxes paid are extremely high, particularly the taxes on crude oil and export quality coal. Almost all of the taxes applied are applied on production, applied indiscriminately to high cost and low cost mines and in times of industry boom and recession. Where the existing tax is a low proportion of market price the administrative simplicity probably outweighs the greater efficiency and equity of a rent-type tax. But where it is a high proportion of market price it induces serious distortions and inequities. The two commodities to which that situation applies are crude oil and export coal. It is in those areas--
—You want to subsidise the inefficient New South Wales producers and put Queensland producers out of business.
—Order! Senator Walsh is answering a question.

—The ignorant comments emanating from the Opposition back bench have almost persuaded me to reconsider my earlier decision not to occupy 10 or 15 minutes of Question Time in trying to educate the economic primitives in the Liberal Party of Australia on the economic rationale for a rent-type tax. —Mr President, I take a point of order. Having been chided once this morning I am perhaps conscious of the use of unparliamentary language. The reference to an interjector as a primitive does not, I think, uphold the dignity of this place. I seek its withdrawal.

The legal ownership of coal is vested in the States and without the co-operation of the States I do not believe that it will be possible to proceed very far. What we envisage and what we have explicitly spelt out on numerous occasions is that we are not contemplating additional taxes; we are contemplating a profits based rent-type tax as a replacement for the existing levies on production.

ANSWER.PARA: New South Wales and Queensland are the two States which are concerned with coal and arrangements are being made for a meeting with those States in June for a general discussion about the problem. As I have said, if the States do not co- operate I do not believe that there is very much we can do. However, if as a result of that non-co-operation and insistence on maintaining the existing taxes on production a substantial section of coal producers is further disadvantaged the State governments will have to bear whatever political odium may flow from their non-co-operation and its adverse effects on the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware that Sydney is commonly held to be the centre of organised crime and corruption in Australia, as evidenced by the Moffitt Royal Commission, and that Dr Alfred McCoy stated in his book Drug Traffic, 'No city in the world could rival Sydney's tolerance for organised crime'? A Four Corners program stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The magistrates we have talked to, felt that none of the responsible authorities were sufficiently independent of the New South Wales Government of the day. They had little hope that steps would be taken to establish the truth.

Is the Attorney-General aware that because defamation suits now before the courts could take up to several years to complete there is a danger that some of the witnesses might lose their enthusiasm to testify? Given these facts, will the Government alter its intention not to hold an inquiry into allegations of political corruption, past and present, in New South Wales or will the Government favourably receive a motion from this side of the chamber calling for a Senate select committee to undertake the task?

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply reiterate the point I made in answer to Senator Chipp when he first raised this question. Matters relating to the administration of justice within a State and involving no larger national issues or allegations about breaches of federal laws are and must remain properly a matter for the State concerned. I do not believe and the Government does not believe that it would be appropriate in the circumstances to which Senator Chipp referred for the Commonwealth to involve itself in a matter which is quintessentially one of States rights.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of representations from some oil refining companies concerning the present arrangements for calculating the coastal freight allowance in the determination of the import parity price for Bass Strait crude oil? As these arrangements, which provide for a notional average freight allowance, actually discriminate against refiners operating in Sydney and Brisbane, can the Minister indicate what alternative arrangements could be instituted which would have greater regard to actual freight costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of representations being made by some companies and yes, I believe that the existing arrangements disadvantage some refiner marketers. The arrangements are complicated but, in brief, they ensure that refiners pay the actual cost of moving Australian crude from the oilfield to the refinery in such a way that the total cost of shipping crude around the Australian coast is minimised, which is obviously a desirable objective. Because of that arrangement some refiners pay more than others for crude oil because they pay the basic price plus freight. In particular the refineries located in Brisbane and Sydney are in that position. The Petroleum Products Pricing Authority sets equal capital city prices for petrol. Therefore, the refiners in Brisbane and Sydney cannot recover the higher costs that they paid for the crude from the market for refined products. The refiner marketers-each of the marketers, with one or two exceptions, has only one refinery in Australia- exchange products between refineries on an equal volume basis to minimise the freight costs of shipping refined product around the Australian coast or moving it by land. That objective also is sensible and is supported by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The refined product in Sydney and Brisbane at the retail level actually has a higher real market value because of the added on freight costs. But the combined operations of the second and third points that I mentioned-the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority and the equal volume exchange-preclude the Sydney and Brisbane refineries from recovering the higher costs which have been thrust upon them. I think there are three options available to overcome this problem. They are: First, to redistribute between companies the present freight costs; secondly, to approach the PPPA to vary the capital city wholesale prices, which would be an imperfect solution for complex reasons which I will not detail at this stage; and, thirdly, to approach the companies to exchange product on an unequal volume basis which takes account of the fact that refined product in some locations in Australia has a higher real market value than refined product in other locations in Australia.

I have approached the companies with a view to having them adopt that fair and efficient solution to the present problem. If a satisfactory response is not received, the first option-that is, some re-distribution between companies of the existing total cost-though it is complex and would be somewhat arbitrary, I believe must be considered by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, follows that asked by Senator Chipp. Is it a fact that, under the guidance of the Attorney-General, the Hawke Government is proposing to legislate using variously the external affairs power, the Aboriginal affairs power and the corporation power, and is even prepared to use the Royal Australian Air Force, in an endeavour to restrict the activities of a State electricity authority? Has he made the same conscientious search for some head of power under which he could have these serious allegations properly investigated? Will he repeat his reply to an interjection that he is a selective advocate of State rights? Can we expect this tender regard for State rights only where ALP governments are involved?

The reason it finally decided to act on the Commonwealth powers available to it is that there has been a very clear perception on the part of this Government, shared by an overwhelming majority of the Australian people, that the matters in issue in Tasmania are not simply matters for the State in question but are matters of national and indeed international importance. It is on that basis that the Commonwealth is exercising the powers available to it. Indeed, it is only because of their importance, measured in those terms, that the Commonwealth will prove to have the power to act in this area. The matter is quite distinct from the other matter which was the subject of earlier questioning.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Attorney -General to address the question I put to him. I asked him whether he had made the same conscientious search for some head of power under which he could have these serious allegations investigated or whether he had simply wiped the matter off.

—If I had any belief, or any argument was put to me, that there were matters involving potential offences against Federal criminal law, or which involved the administration of justice in a way that was nationally relevant or significant, I am sure that a head of power would be appropriately available under section 61 of the Constitution. But since no suggestion has been made by anyone that this is a matter involving other than the administration of justice at a State level, I do not believe that such a search would be productive in this instance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I have received many representations-no doubt other senators have as well-about the removal of many drugs from the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme as a result of the previous Government's revision of the scheme. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates has asked me about the very important changes that were made to the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme by my predecessor who established an organisation to examine the use of drugs under the Scheme. I think it is true, as Senator Coates has mentioned, that there has been widespread reaction to the new scheme that was introduced by my predecessor and began operating on 1 March this year. The opposition comes from doctors, pharmacists and, in particular, ex-servicemen. I advise the Senate that I have had more representations on this issue than I have had on any other issue in all of my activities in public life. As a consequence I have reviewed the decision that was made by the previous Government, which aimed at some control over the use of drugs prescribed by a local medical officer. Whilst I think there is some evidence that a lax attitude has been taken by some of the medical officers in this area, I doubt the effectiveness of the proposals which the previous Government adopted. In other words, it established bureaucratic machinery to deal with what I believe to be a social problem. The consequence of that within the first couple of weeks in which the scheme was in operation was that the Department of Veterans' Affairs was required to process some 18,000 prescriptions which doctors made as a result of representations by ex-service patients. It seemed to me, philosophically, that that was repugnant to the Australian Labor Party. ANSWER.PARA: The pharmaceutical companies were exploiting the fact that drugs were on the list that operated within the Department as indeed they have in respect of those associated with the scheme which is operated by the Department of Health. The net result is that tens of thousands, in fact scores of thousands, of ex-servicemen were affected because of the decision which operated from 1 March. The only other point that is worth referring to is that any new drugs prescribed by local medical officers have to be referred to the Department as from 1 March. But in respect of all the previous prescriptions, the new system that was instituted by the previous Government is no longer operating.

It is regrettable, because there is nothing more to be obtained by this kind of churlish searching after tidbits of this kind. The reality of the matter, as I have endeavoured to explain to the honourable senator-I appreciate there is some lag time between explanation and understanding in the case of the honourable senator-is that the instructions to which she has referred were manifestly not applied in every respect in terms of the procedure of authorisation that was adopted on this occasion. One of the reasons they were not applied was that apparently there was some difference of belief or understanding within the defence establishment as to whether they were the appropriate instructions, or whether the appropriate instructions were the others to which I referred, DI(G) OPS 05-1-if that means anything to the honourable senator-which relate to defence assistance to the civil community and which do not require any elaborate consultative process of the kind mentioned.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not be surprised if the honourable senator, after she has ploughed through the said document DI(G)OPS 05-1, which I tabled, finds some aspects of that document that have not been complied with. It is perfectly possible in this case. But all of those points have been readily acknowledged at all stages of this debate. For the umpteenth time, there has been no question of endeavouring to conceal anything. I hope the honourable senator will appreciate that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is not the truth of the matter that in fact and in law the Attorney-General had no authority at all to direct the Defence Force in this matter and that such a direction was therefore unlawful?
—It is perfectly true that I had no authority whatsoever to direct anybody to do anything. The truth of the matter, however, is that I made no such direction or purported direction; I made a request.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Quite often situations of violence occur when children are handed over from the custodial parent to the non-custodial parent for weekend or out-of-hours access. The effects of such violence are very harmful to the parent and in particular to the children. I understand that the South Australian domestic violence committee chaired by the women's adviser to the Premier put a submission in April 1982 to the previous Attorney-General for a pilot project for the establishment of supervised and secure access changeover facilities. No support was forthcoming. Can the Attorney-General tell me whether he intends to support the submission; whether he will fund it; and, if so, when?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no knowledge of the fate of the earlier submission to which the honourable senator referred. All I know is that on 30 March this year I received submissions or representations from both my colleague Senator Ryan and the Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, requesting $13,500-worth of support for a pilot study of this question of supervised access and changeover facilities for the persons to whom Senator Crowley referred. Within three and a half weeks of that, on 24 April this year, I approved the grant-in-aid in question, demonstrating thereby some greater alacrity on these matters, as indeed on so many other matters, on behalf of this Government. The project to which Senator Crowley referred is, I think, best explained by the Premier of South Australia in his submission to me. It is a project that is to be run by the Life Line group of the Adelaide Central Mission.

ANSWER.PARA: I was told by the Premier that the proposal arose out of a long-standing and grave concern in the community-this is a national concern, not one confined to South Australia-about the harmful effects of violence which sometimes arises when children are handed over from the custodial parent to the non-custodial parent for the purpose of weekend or out-of-hours access. Many makeshift arrangements have been attempted by various agencies all over Australia in the past to provide some supervision of this often volatile moment. But the need for formal security and the demand for after-hours resources in this respect has led to the downfall, I am told, of best intentions in this area.

What has happened as a result of that concern being expressed around the place is that a pilot scheme has been devised by the Premier's Department in South Australia in conjunction with the Adelaide Central Mission which should, I am advised, meet the complex requirements of such a service at very little cost, with the aim of providing hitherto unrecorded data also on the dimensions of the problems and responses to the provision of such a service. It seems to me, and it seemed to me when I received these submissions, an entirely admirable initiative which certainly deserved the support of the Federal Government. As such, I am pleased to be able to advise Senator Crowley that my response in the affirmative to this proposal was very swift indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy and may also concern his capacity as Acting Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Minister seen a report in today's Australian which states that the Victorian Environment Protection Authority has granted a licence to a firm of wool merchants to discharge effluent comprising 170 tonnes of salt per year into the River Murray from its plant in Albury? In view of the fact that leading industry figures and agricultural experts are predicting that many of Australia's irrigation areas will not survive because of the long term effects of water pollution, erosion and high salinity levels, and that in particular the South Australian citrus industry is doomed, does the Minister believe it is appropriate for one State Government authority to make a decision so detrimental to the economy of another State? If the Minister does not believe that this is appropriate, will he move to have decisions such as this made by the River Murray Commission or some other impartial or at least multilateral body? In short, is he prepared to act, if necessary, by amending the River Murray Waters Agreement or the relevant Act to prevent the River Murray from becoming nothing more than a sewer flowing through South Australia wrecking the health and livelihood of thousands of people en route?

—I was aware of that report in the Australian and from other sources was also aware of the case a few days earlier. I understand that the River Murray Commission is appealing against that decision and that the appeal is to be heard in Victoria. That is an important matter because this is the first test case of the River Murray Commission's new powers to exercise some control over water quality.
—Appealing to whom?

—It is appealing to some Victorian authority. I am not sure whether it is an appeal court or whether the appeal is an environment protection authority appeal. I understand that the Victorian Government will accept the decision of that appeal body. The Federal Government has no power of direction over the River Murray Commission because it is a creature of four different governments. Indeed, no particular government has power of direction over it, which is one of its potential and actual weaknesses. I do not know whether the facts stated in the article in the Australian to which Senator Haines referred are accurate, but to put the salinity question in some sort of perspective, 170 tonnes of salt are stated to have been added to the salt load by the proposed scouring plant. If I remember correctly-the load varies from year to year-the river carries down a total of about one million tonnes a year. So, whilst not wishing to trivialise the matter 170 tonnes of salt is a very minor addition to the existing load. I expect that other environmental objections to the proposal relate to dangers other than the salt load. The broad question of River Murray water quality is under review by the Government but there are, I understand, innate constitutional difficulties in any government exercising effective control over the difficulties which the River Murray Commission itself reflects. Among the firm proposals the Government has in mind is to reintroduce-I am not yet sure into which House-the Institute of Fresh Water Studies Bill which was passed by the Senate. It will not be introduced during the autumn session of Parliament, but probably during the Budget session.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the fact that he has consistently maintained that the spy flights over Tasmania were lawful. In so doing he has relied on the Defence Instructions headed 'Defence Instructions (General)', which he tabled. During a debate in the Senate on 22 April, after having been asked by way of interjection about ministerial responsibility, as recorded on page 67 of the Senate Hansard, he answered:

QUESTION.PARA: It involved neither a breach of the law nor any fundamental breach of propriety , nor does it involve any breach of the explicit language of the directions under which the Defence Force operates in these particular matters.

Clearly, the Attorney-General was referring in his speech to the document he had tabled. Is it not a fact that in answers he has given here today he has acknowledged that that statement was not true and that there were breaches of the procedures set out in this document? He has informed the Senate today that there is another Defence instruction called 'Policy and Procedures for Defence Force Assistance to the Civil Community', which in his view as the first law officer apparently is relevant to his claim in this matter. When did the Attorney-General first become aware of this new document?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the former Attorney-General on his persistence but not on the quality of his cross-examination. To restate the obvious is not to serve his cause or that of the national Parliament. I have readily conceded that I may well have erred in saying that the precise chapter and verse of this particular document, which for the record is coded DI(G)OPS 01 -2, entitled 'Defence Force Aid to the Civil Power', may not have been adhered to. Indeed, that was the nub of the objection of the Chief of Defence Force Staff and some of the other people within the Defence establishment to what happened on that occasion.
—That is contrary to what you told us in the Senate in that answer.

—Yes, but having had this document thrust into my hand literally about 15 minutes before I walked into the Senate on that occasion and having had an opportunity only to have a cursory look at it, I quite genuinely believed that the chapter and verse of the procedures there set out had been followed. I do not believe any longer that that belief is entirely sustainable. Equally, I make the point that that does not affect the quality of the basic answer I gave, which is that what occurred was entirely lawful. None of these internal directives can override the force and effect of a ministerial agreement to the task in question. That is the advice I received from the Solicitor- General in answer to a question I put to him as part of a larger question as to the lawfulness of what occurred. There is no question whatsoever as to the lawfulness of these flights.

ANSWER.PARA: I reiterate that there is a question as to which is the appropriate set of internal Defence procedure instructions that should govern such flights. The argument in favour of the civil power document to which I referred the other day is that that document explicitly refers to law enforcement and these flights were part of a law enforcement exercise. The argument in favour of the more generalised set of instructions that I am now in a position to table-I do so-is that they refer in general terms to the kind of assistance to the civil community in relation to such tasks as photography that occurred during the flights. It is a matter for argument as to which instructions are appropriate. It is not a matter for elaborate, neurotic, obsessive nitpicking in either a court of law or a national Parliament of the kind to which we have been exposed today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Attorney-General did not answer my specific question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact, as reported in the West Australian of 26 April this year, that the Australian Federal Police are investigating allegations that a number of Sydney private hospitals were involved in a scheme whereby doctors were offered inducements in the form of low interest loans to ensure that the hospitals maintained high occupancy rates? Is it also a fact that Medibank raised this patient recruiting scheme with the Commonwealth Department of Health in 1981 but was told that there were no grounds for action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Giles refers to a report concerning this matter appearing in the West Australian and in other newspapers. I am informed that in 1981 Medibank Private wrote to the Department of Health enclosing documents on investigations it had made into certain claims lodged by a number of private hospitals in Sydney. It sought the Department's view of whether the benefit was payable. The hospitals referred to at the time were eligible for the Commonwealth bed-day subsidy because patients did occupy beds and because the government assessment of medical need is not a criterion of eligibility for such payments. The payment was then $16 a day and was payable because the patients were admitted by a doctor. There was no other requirement at all. They were admitted by a doctor, they had occupied a bed and this satisfied the legislation at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: Steps have been taken to amend the legislation to tighten this eligibility criteria. The question of whether the benefits paid by the funds were payable is , in fact, up to the funds themselves. They must determine whether they pay their side of the hospital benefit, not the Commonwealth Government. This matter is being pursued by Medibank with the Australian Federal Police, as was pointed out in the article. Other so-called criminal aspects, which it is understood have also been pursued by Medibank with the Australian Federal Police, are the matters of kick-backs to doctors for getting patients into hospitals, secret commissions and conspiracy to defraud. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, following the Hawke Government's conversion to the previous Government's economic policies, the Senate notes the Government's adoption of the previous Government's social security policies, and in particular:
(a) the introduction of family income supplement for needy families;
(b) retention of the mobility allowance for the disabled;
(c) the increase in the over 18 year old unemployment benefit;
(d) the maintaining of the twice yearly indexation of pensions and benefits; and
(e) the retention of other Budget family measures.

I wish to draw attention to recent Government practices of adopting the former Government's policies in respect of social security. Those points are well set out in the motion. In specific terms I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Government, having come to power in recent times, has adopted the previous Government's approach to economic matters and now clearly has adopted that approach in respect of social security matters. In particular, we on this side are very pleased to have seen the new Government take up its role of continuing our policy, as announced in last year's Budget, in connection with the family income supplement for needy families, the retention of the mobility allowance for the disabled, the increase in the over 18-year-old unemployment benefit for those without dependants, the maintenance of the twice yearly indexation of pensions and benefits, and of course the retention of many other benefits.

We have to acknowledge that during the election campaign the present Federal Government made many commitments to the electorate. Indeed, many offers were made and they clearly encouraged people to vote for the Australian Labor Party. We need quote only a couple of statements made during the heady days of the campaign, some attributable to Senator Grimes, the present Minister for Social Security, to confirm that fact. For instance, he is quoted as saying on 15 February:
Labor would introduce an expansionary economic policy that would put people back at work and provide more money for social security spending.

It is part of our history, of course, that already the expansionary economic policy appears to have been put on the back burner, as does the possible increase in social security benefits. We have not seen any clear statement at all from this Minister or from the Government generally as to its policy in respect of social security matters. In fact, during the election campaign the Government promised increases of the order of $402m in social security spending, but there has been no confirmation that that will be proceeded with by this Government.

We look to the Government and to Senator Grimes in particular to assure us that that program will go forward. Part of the reason for my raising this motion today is to try to get some definite reply from the Government as to its attitude and its directions. We do not want justifications by blaming former governments. That is not good enough. The present Government made the promises; it now needs to keep faith with the Australian people. We want firm statements from this Government as to its future direction.

Various commitments were outlined by the new Government during its election campaign. One of those announced on 16 February by the now Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his election policy speech was that the Government would be committed to raising the basic pension rate to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. According to the information provided to me, if that policy were adopted it would cost a further $1,100m approximately, in addition to the $400-odd that I mentioned earlier. Is the Government to proceed with that policy? I acknowledge that its undertaking was to increase the basic pension rate to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings over a three-year period, or perhaps over the life of a Parliament. Nevertheless, the people of Australia are concerned about this matter. There is no acknowledgement by the Government of its commitment in that area. People want to know what is going on and when this promise will be implemented.

Other things were included in the total welfare package. There was to be more money for social security benefits, higher wages and, of course, one of the most significant things, lower taxes-presumably, lower taxes for those at the lower end of the income scales. Can we ever forget that ringing statement by the now Prime Minister during his election policy speech, when he claimed that he would offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the campaign? Yet immediately we were conditioned to think that not only would a fistful of dollars amounting to some $600m, promised people during that election campaign, be snatched back by the Government but also promised social security benefits amounting to some $400m were at risk.

What are the Government's views on these matters? If we consider some of the statements put out by Ministers we find nothing but confusion. The Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, said that the hopes of social security recipients could be dashed by the Federal Government in its attempt to promote growth in the economy. I think he said something to the effect that increased social welfare payments could be swapped for government funding of high technology industries as the Government looks to support silicon chip-type industries-the big growth areas of the 1980s, as he is so wont to express. He is reported in the Australian of 25 March as saying:
This time we may be in the unpalatable position of having to say to these people (on social security): 'Look will you wait for a while'.

Is this the Government's position in relation to social security? I want to know which people will have to wait a while. Is it the poorest in the community? Is it the most needy? Is it those who would have been in receipt of tax benefits, promised falsely in the election campaign? Who indeed? Perhaps Senator Grimes can help us in the course of this debate. People are genuinely concerned about the policies of this Government. We have to be sure of what its policies are and the directions in which they are heading. That is what this Parliament is about and that is why we need answers to these questions.

In acknowledging these matters, Mr Deputy President, I am most pleased to see that the Government has continued the implementation of the family income supplement brought down in last year's Budget by the former Government. Further, we have the retention of the mobility allowance for disabled people, which I think in the Budget debate was acknowledged by the new Minister as being a most worthwhile initiative to help the disabled. He acknowledged a further point in relation to that in answering a question I asked him the other day concerning tax deductibility for disabled people. I hope that the Government will pursue that matter and ensure that its promises are put into practice. Probably the most significant social security breakthrough of all during the seven years of the Fraser Government was the indexation of pensions and benefits. We know that is a substantial cost to the revenue but it protects those who need it most.

It protects those who need the most protection against inflation. The most needy groups in our community, bearing in mind the way in which our income testing system operates, are receiving benefit from that measure. The aged and other needy groups in the community recognise the value of that policy. I hope that the Government will continue the policy and will bear it in mind during its current review. Whilst the Government put up pensions according to the indexation principle in the last month we are committed to a six-monthly adjustment of pensions. Consequently, we look forward to the November adjustment to see whether the former Government's policy will be continued or whether there will be changes.

I draw that point to the attention of the Senate because of the very serious issue of cost. According to the statistics and figures that were presented, I think by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, during the National Economic Summit Conference, it costs something like $900m a year to index pensions and benefits. Is it this Government's intention to raise taxes to pay for that indexation? People are asking these questions. I think we need to know the Government's intentions. As all honourable senators know, the statement of accord with the trade union movement, which was greatly bandied about by Mr Hawke during the election campaign and in the period preceding the campaign, clearly indicates that there is room for manoeuvre with the trade union movement for the Government to raise taxes to pay for increased social security benefits. Will this Government examine that option very closely and raise taxes in such a way as to pay for the indexation of pensions? It is not just the Opposition that is speaking on this matter but also a concerned group out in the community that wants to know these answers. The plethora of confused views emanating from the Ministry is leading to increasing concern on all sides.

The Government has adopted certain measures and I commend it for adopting the former Government's policies. I hope that we can look forward to further debates on issues of this kind as the Government comes forward with its own suggestions for policy improvements. All kinds of matters are likely to need attention. I have been reading some magazine articles in recent days which have quoted the now Minister for Social Security. I am pleased to see that he believes that anybody who suggests that pensions and benefits should be cut should be shot at dawn. I wonder who will be doing the shooting? I am sure that it will be clear that many other options are available to this Government, as I have just outlined, without its having to consider cutting benefits. I have pointed out an option which may well be implemented by the Government as a result of the statement of accord. With the trade union movement we need this information and we need it soon. We need one Minister-presumably the responsible Minister in this place-to make clear the Government's intentions in this area. We look forward to getting that information as quickly as possible. The Government has before it a four-week or five-week sitting program. I think we can look forward to plenty of opportunities to discuss these matters further. But we need some advice from this Minister as to the future direction of the Government's social security policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I came into the chamber this afternoon I was not quite sure what the notice of motion put down by Senator Messner was all about. After listening to him for about 15 minutes I am not much the wiser. I think the notice of motion itself is an incredible one. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MESSNER: To move-That, following the Hawke Government's conversion to the previous Government's economic policies, . . .

Mr Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, has continually harped on the inadequacy of the Hawke Government's economic policies. The second part of Senator Messner's motion, which he did not address much during his speech, I think is also incredible. It states:
The Senate notes the Government's adoption of the previous Government's social security policies, and in particular:
(a) The introduction of family income supplement for needy families;
(b) retention of the mobility allowance . . .
(c) the increase in the over 18 year old unemployment benefit;
(d) the maintaining of the twice yearly indexation of pensions and benefits . . .
of all things and--

Apparently, he would have liked us to have come into government and then to have wiped out all those things so that he could have attacked us. He would have liked us to destroy all those things, none of which we opposed in opposition, so that he could have attacked us. But because of his disappointment that we did not do that sort of thing he has come into this place and said: 'You are not very good anyhow because you have just adopted our policies'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You--

—The honourable senator should just hold on. We listened to the Opposition in silence and Opposition senators should listen to us in silence. Senator Messner also said during his speech that he had some inkling that if I replied to him I might have the cheek to say something about the previous Government's record in the areas of social security and economics. Because he said, 'We do not want to hear what previous governments have done, we want to hear what you have done', I will disappoint Senator Messner and I will talk about some of the things that the previous Government did in the social security area. It is as a result of that Government's policies in the areas of economics and social security that it has only a handful of people on the Opposition benches. It is as a result of those policies that it lost the election overwhelmingly. It is as a result of that that it is now on the Opposition side of the chamber and we are on the Government side.

SPEECH.PARA: When honourable senators talk about neglect and confusion I ask them to consider the previous Government's record in this area. Under the previous Government the number of people who needed welfare assistance rose dramatically and, in many cases, benefits provided by the Government to those people fell dramatically. We sat in this place last August and September and listened to a Budget debate in which we were told that about $1,500m was going to be spent on unemployment beneficiaries this year. On Budget night we were able to demonstrate that it would be at least $200m more than that. A month later we were able to demonstrate that it would be $400m more than that. The then Treasurer eventually had to concede that it was going to be $600m more than that . It certainly will be even higher than that. That is the most recent and dramatic demonstration of the increase in the number of people who need unemployment benefit and social security benefits in general. Those people found themselves on the unemployment rolls because of the economic policies of the previous coalition Government.

I should like to give two examples of how the value of those pensions fell. The real value of the unemployment benefit for single adults-I note that Senator Messner demonstrated a new-found concern for them in his motion-fell by nearly 20 per cent between 1976 and 1982. The real value of family allowances fell by over 15 per cent between 1977 and 1982. In fact, there was a prolonged period during which there were no increases. During the time of the previous Government we saw the abolition of the maternity allowance. During the time of the previous Government we saw the abolition of the automatic indexation of the unemployment benefit for single adults. If we are talking about confusion, where do we get greater confusion than in the treatment of pensions and benefits under the indexation system which Senator Messner also has the cheek to mention in his motion? It was the previous Government of which he was a member which first introduced automatic twice-yearly indexation. It then abolished it. Then, after pressure from the then Opposition and welfare organisations in general, it reintroduced it. All this occurred in one year. How much more confusion can you get in the welfare system than to have that sort of thing going on?

The only serious attempt at improving welfare arrangements generally occurred just prior to the last election when the former Government introduced most of the measures that Senator Messner mentions in his motion and which we thought were to be the subject of his speech. However, since the most important of those initiatives, the family income supplement, was in fact first talked about in this country as part of the Australian Labor Party's 1980 election platform, it is hardly surprising that this Government, which came into power in March when the introduction of the scheme was well under way-advertising had been prepared, the printing had been done and the Department was geared up for its introduction -kept the scheme going. As a form of it was our initiative in the first place is it surprising that we kept it going? Considerable difficulties are associated with the introduction of the family income supplement. I am sure Senator Messner will find some difficulties with it, if he has not already done so. Pensioners, beneficiaries and others will probably ring up and say: 'Why weren't we included in the family income supplement?'. Indeed, this Government, in its review of the family income supplement, will have to look at that question.

The family income supplement has been introduced on a very narrow scale and a very tight means test applies to it. Very complicated administrative problems are associated with administering the family income supplement. The Government will review it to see what we can learn from experience gained in the first few months of the introduction of that supplement. We will see whether we can improve the whole system, particularly for those low income earners who, in the past, have not been assisted much by the social security system. I suggest it is absolute nonsense to imply, for the sake of a debating point on a Thursday afternoon in the Senate, that if we were a proper government which disagreed with the previous government then we would wipe out that benefit which we did not oppose during the Budget.

The reason Senator Messner and his party have been discredited-it is the reason that the previous coalition Government is no longer in government-is that the Hawke Labor Government was able to show during the election campaign that our economic policies presented a real opportunity to get Australia out of the mess left by the Fraser Government. The country was disillusioned with the previous Government. The former Government's most overwhelming contribution to the welfare budget was to increase the number of unemployment beneficiaries, not the number of people unemployed, from 188,000 in June 1976 to the current figure of about 620,000. It is no wonder, with a disastrous economic policy like that-a very large burden was put on the social security budget mainly as a result of the vast increases in the number of people unemployed-that the community got fed up with the previous Government. It is no wonder that members of the previous Government are now sitting on the Opposition benches.

When the election campaign started we were very circumspect about what we were able to promise in the area of welfare. As Senator Messner well knows, changes and reforms in this area are costly. We costed our social security policies at about $420m. I note that the then Treasurer agreed essentially with those costings. But we were aware of several things. We were very suspicious that the economy was considerably worse than this Parliament had been led to believe by the Government. We knew that the stated deficit in the last Budget of $1,500m was nonsense. We knew it was nonsense on Budget night. As the weeks went by it became obvious that it was nonsense. The then Treasurer had to admit that the Budget deficit was going to be about $4,000m. People who worked with us in the economic area sat down and worked out their own figures. They suspected that the deficit may actually be about $6,000m.

We were confronted with the problem that if we got into government we knew we would be faced with a large deficit. We would be faced with the problem of raising revenue and we would be faced with the problem that that would be of considerable difficulty to any government. That is why our promises were not profligate or wild. We did promise that we would restore the level of the standard rate of pensions and benefits to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings . They were almost at that point when we left government in 1975. They had fallen to about 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. We knew that to do that in one hit, as Senator Messner has said, would cost a lot of money and cause considerable difficulty in controlling the economy. We said we would restore those pensions and benefits over the term of the first three years of government . We said we would do it in stages and that the extent of those stages would depend on the state of the economy. We made that promise quite clear. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made that promise and I made that promise. We stick by that promise. What we did not know and what was not known by anyone in this community apart from the previous Treasurer, the previous Prime Minister and, I understand -because the previous Treasurer put her in-the former Minister for Finance, was that the Budget deficit was nearer $10 billion. Nobody in this community knew that but despite the fact--

TALK.START.PARA: —Anybody could have worked it out.

—Senator Townley says that he could work it out. He was a candidate in the election. If he had known that fact it was his duty to let the people of Tasmania know that his government was crook and that his Treasurer was lying to the people of this country. He did not let them know.
—I didn't say I did work it out. I said I could have worked it out.

—If Senator Townley knew about the disastrous situation facing this country he should have come clean in the election campaign. If Senator Townley knew, he was the only person opposite who knew, apart from those I mentioned, because when the figures came out people on his side were visibly shocked at the fact that they were so bad. We made that promise to lift the standard rate of pensions and benefits. We made a similar promise about raising the rate of the unemployment benefit for single people. It had fallen way behind because of the previous Government's vindictive policy of blaming the unemployed and removing them from the indexation of pensions. We said that our first step would be to increase the unemployment benefits for the single unemployed to half the married rate as soon as possible in May. We said that our other promises were to be introduced in the Budget. As a coincidence, essentially the only promise made by the Liberal Party of Australia, made by Mr Fraser in his policy speech, was to do the same thing-to increase unemployment benefits for the single beneficiaries to half the married rate in May. We did it.

SPEECH.PARA: I was sworn in as a Minister on 11 March. Four days later we had a Cabinet meeting and decided to do that. We passed legislation on 21 April. I pointed out in the second reading debate that, in doing that on the first day of the sitting of this Parliament, we in fact completed the Liberal Party social security policy for the last election campaign. Now we will get on with our own. The good Senator Messner is complaining. He introduces a motion into this place that we have adopted the Liberal Party policy by increasing the over-18 single unemployment benefit. Really and truly, if that is the best he can do in criticising our activities in this area--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what your policies are.

—The Government, which I represent, is not, quite frankly, prepared to stand idly by and watch the plight of those Australians who have been thrown by the previous Government, through no fault of their own, into circumstances of hardship. Every welfare organisation, every investigator of the area, every voluntary organisation in this community has been telling the previous Government that the numbers of people in poverty in this country has been increasing, not only from the numbers on unemployment benefit, but also from the increasing ranks of the single parents whose benefits for children have not been increased in line with inflation, whose base rate pension has dropped over the years and whose opportunities for employment have not been there. But all other pensioners and all other groups of the community have been in this difficulty. What we have to do is sit down and work out who are the winners, who are the losers and who are the furthest behind, bearing in mind the fact that we have been left one hell of an economic mess in this community, bearing in mind that we have been left with a Budget deficit which was absolutely unheard of during the election time or at the last Budget, bearing in mind that we will still sit down to work out our priorities and we will still produce a social security program for this Budget which will be far in excess of anything that the previous Government would have done and will show our concern for those who are in greatest need. Senator Messner has the gall to come into this chamber on the first general business day of the Senate and say to me that I must get up and give details in this Parliament of what we are going to do in this area at the next Budget.
—You have four weeks of sittings to tell us.

—Let me compare our policy with that of the previous Government. The previous Government's welfare policy in the last election campaign consisted of three things. It consisted of putting 10,000 young people to work in the defence forces. The defence forces did not want them. Heaven knows what they were going to do there. They were going to decrease the efficiency of the defence forces, yet that was the basis of the welfare problem. The Liberal Party was going to solve the unemployment problem in this country by taking 10,000 of the 600,000-odd persons who were on unemployment benefits and putting them in the armed services. The previous Government did not ask the armed services about it. It did not ask them what they were going to do with these people.
—They were horrified.

—As Senator Tate said, they were absolutely horrified. That is the first leg of the previous Government's policy. In the second leg it was going to provide 150 additional child care centres. Senator Messner suggested that the Liberal Party might increase some of the income limits and raise the single unemployment benefit rate to half the married rate in May. Our objectives included and include: To increase the standard rate of pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings over the first three years of a Labor Government. We recognise the difficulties which are faced by pensioners in particular areas such as the Northern Territory, north Queensland, the north of Western Australia , the outlying areas of South Australia and New South Wales and the west coast of Tasmania by introducing a zone allowance for pensioners and beneficiaries in those areas. We wanted to get away from the discrimination between those on pensions and those on benefits which had come about by the failure to index the single unemployment benefit rate. We promised to do that over the three years of the Government. We also promised expanded child care centres to help those people who are in need of child care and to get over the maldistribution of child care facilities in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: These were the things that we put down in the policy speech, which we believed were achievable and we still believe are achievable. They were the basic things that we thought should be done and the basic things we still think should be done. Whereas we may have had some sort of an idea of how to do those staged improvements in pensions and benefits, we certainly will have to sit down and think abut how large the first stage will be in the light of the extraordinary deficit which the former Treasurer of this country kept from us. But they remain our aims, as does the general aim of freeing the social security system, providing a proper appeals system-all these things are under review-introducing a youth policy to this country, and overcoming the difficulties which are facing young people when they leave school. They find that they have no choice but to get a job, which is very difficult, or to go on to unemployment benefits. In other countries there is a co-ordinated youth policy which provides education facilities, training facilities and everything else. We have all sorts of structural things we want to do about improving the lot of those in women's refuges and those who are running women's health centres.

We have a great number of areas for improvement in relation to Aboriginal welfare which my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is dealing with and we have got to work on these matters. We are getting as much information as we can from our government departments and, where necessary, we have set up interdepartmental committees and task forces to find out what is going on. We have only been in Government for what is essentially six or seven weeks. I put it to honourable senators opposite that we have been more active and have shown more concern for the disadvantaged people in this country than honourable senators opposite did for the seven years of their Government.

The fundamental differences between these policies were underlined in a forceful manner by the electorate on 5 March 1983. One of the crucial problems which faced the previous Government was that it did not understand the differences between its policies and our policies; that it does not understand the direction or the difference between its policy and our policy. Our policy is aimed at improving the lot of the disadvantaged; our policy is aimed at finding out those who are disadvantaged in the community and caring for them; and, above all, it is aimed at changing the system so that fewer people rely on the welfare system than rely on it now. If Senator Messner does not understand that, I suppose that explains why he, as a Minister in the previous Government, is now a shadow Minister in this Opposition. I think it explains why he is going to be a shadow Minister for a long time yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wouldn't bet on it.

—My dear friend Senator Walters has returned to the chamber. She is the greatest example in this place of the fact that whatever happens there are always some things that never change. Some things that never change are the attitudes of the Liberal and National Party members towards the social security system in this country which they believe is, in fact, an area where they should be able to apply a bit of patronage just before elections to fool the electorate that they are concerned. At other times they should do things like they did in 1977, I believe it was, when they dropped twice-yearly indexation and then, in great confusion, reintroduced it. They think they can do such things as introduce family allowances, which was a worthy change, but then ignore them for five years and let them be eroded. They think they can take funeral benefits from people and not cop the difference. Sooner or later-it was not so much later this time-the people catch up with that sort of attitude. I suppose another thing which will never change is the inane standard of interjections we get from Senator Walters. This motion is not worth supporting. It is certainly rejected by the Government. If the Opposition wants us to support motions of concern for the welfare of disadvantaged people in the community, the motions will have to be worded better, be more factual and be more relevant to the situation than this one is. The Government will not support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of this motion this afternoon I must say that nothing that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) said persuaded me to change my mind about the fact that the Australian Labor Party has seen fit to adopt some of the social security policies of the previous Liberal-National Party Government, as Senator Messner outlined earlier. There are five different sections in this motion. In regard to the family income supplement for needy families, I maintain that family allowances are necessary for most single income families in Australia. The single income family is being hit hardest by rising living costs and higher taxation. If we keep the wage pause going until the end of the year, as has been suggested, there is a chance that costs will stabilise. However, if as has been suggested by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), he and the Government are supporting a 3 per cent to 4 per cent increase in wages to appease the unions, it stands to reason that costs and prices must continue to rise and that there will be even more need for a family income supplement, not just for needy families but for all families. I have no doubt that some women feel they need to earn a second income to try to help with costs.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the motion concerns the retention of the mobility allowance for the disabled. During the last session of Parliament I was interested to hear a lady who appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare explaining that this was a very good allowance and how helpful it was for people who had to live in a wheelchair in that it aided them in getting somebody to help them in their home rather than having to live in a nursing home or hospital . So I am glad to know that this mobility allowance for the disabled is worth while.

Paragraph (c) of the motion concerns the increase in the unemployment benefit for those over 18 years old. I have no doubt that the rising costs arguments apply in this case also. It is essential for the unemployment benefit to be raised in this way. I have no doubt that many unemployed would be very pleased to get a job. If we could believe the promise made by the present Government before the recent election that unemployment would soon fall, we could expect many of these over 18-year-olds to be able to get work soon. However, unfortunately we have not seen much sign yet of unemployment decreasing; rather, it is increasing. All I can say is that while such projects as Ben Lomond outside Townsville are being closed down because of Commonwealth Government actions, with the loss of 1,200 jobs, and while such projects as the units that the Japanese want to build at Surfers Paradise are being knocked back because the Government does not agree with Japanese money being used, with the loss of 1 ,000 prospective jobs, I certainly feel there will be need for more money to be spent on unemployment benefits. Much more will have to be spent on them rather than less.

I have said before, and I still believe, that a brains trust should be established to see how the Government could implement a scheme for people to work for the dole. This could be done either by subsidising local authorities or by private enterprise making the dole up to the full basic wage. I feel that this would be a way of absorbing people on the dole into the work force. I always believe that people appreciate more what they have had to work for than what they get for nothing. There is a tremendous amount of money being spent on unemployment benefits.

I come to paragraph (d)-the maintaining of the twice-yearly indexation of pensions and benefits. I suppose one could say that this is a very worthwhile but very costly objective. We on this side of the chamber would like to know how the Government is going to raise the money to do this. Will it raise taxes to pay for the indexation of pensions? I really do not see how it will be able to meet this cost in any other way. I did not hear the Minister explain in his speech exactly how the Government is going to meet the cost of this indexation.

Paragraph (e) of the motion concerns the retention of other Budget family measures. Of course, the family is the basic unit of society and all measures to help the family must be proceeded with. In conclusion, let me say with Senator Messner how pleased I am that this new Labor Government has seen fit to recognise the value of our Government's social security policies and has decided to continue with so many of them.

Whatever it decides to spend and whatever it decides to collect, we will have the deficit that comes from that Budget-nothing else at all. It will have nothing to do with what the Government promised the Australian people during the election. The Government is hiding behind that. Senator Grimes told us that at this stage the Government will sit down to work out who are the winners and who are the losers in the area of social welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: What were honourable senators opposite doing for the seven years they were in opposition? Absolutely nothing at all. The Australian Labor Party's women's advisory group has said to the Labor Party : 'Get rid of the dependent spouse rebate. Those women should be out working. TALK.START.PARA: —What a silly comment. It is inaccurate, apart from anything else .

—It is completely accurate. Senator Grimes has also said that the Government cares for the underprivileged. To date, as I have said, the only thing that Government senators have done is to say in this place that they do not have a policy; that they will now sit down and work out who--
—That is what you say.

—No, those are not my words; they are Senator Grimes's words. I wrote them down as he said them. He said: 'We will now sit down and work out who are the winners and the losers'. For seven years in opposition the present Government did not do anything about social welfare. We, as a government, certainly did. I will outline the things we did. We introduced a full consumer price index increased twice yearly for pensioners. We took the issue out of the political football arena so that pensioners could depend on it. Mind you, wages were not indexed during that time. Pensioners knew that their income would not deteriorate and that the increases would not be used as a political football, to be put forward at Budget time as the Labor Party did. It put it forward at Budget time when an election was close, but not otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: We also introduced the family allowance. We took the allowance away from higher income earners and gave it to the people who did not earn enough to receive the tax rebate for children. We gave women in low income families the family allowance. Yet Senator Grimes stands back and says that we had no concern. We showed a far greater practical concern for the disadvantaged than was shown, or is likely to be shown, by the football tactics of the present Government. Surely for the Government to say that at this stage, now that it is in government, it will be working out who are the winners and losers underlines to people in the community that the Government has no social welfare policy, but it will be hurriedly working one out. We will see which areas of social welfare will suffer . Will it be the dependent spouse rebate? Will the family allowance also be means tested? We will see which families the Government takes it away from and to whom they give it.
