SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate requests the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to initiate a new program for young people aged 16 to 21 years to alleviate the worst effects of unemployment in this age group by:
(a) the introduction of permanent part-time work without penalty in the form of reduced unemployment benefits;
(b) encouraging businesses and unions to co-operate in making at least one work place per enterprise available, worked on a roster basis, for young unemployed people; and
(c) providing many more part-time and full-time educational and training opportunities for unemployed people.

I think this is the first initiative in the new Senate to deal specifically with unemployment, although the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) did mention it from time to time during his comments in the previous debate. It is no accident that it is an early initiative from the Australian Democrats. We stressed heavily throughout the last election campaign that the major problem of this society is unemployment especially youth unemployment, not only for the obvious economic reasons but also because of the enormous social impact on so many young people who finish their education and are then told that society has no work for them and no need for them. They are told to stay at home, presumably to meditate on their predicament. If they use their time to go to the beach, bush walk or anything like that they risk being labelled as dole bludgers, although I am very pleased to find that that word is being used less and less in society.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an overstatement.

—Indeed so. This situation is absolutely intolerable for young people. It is something like road accidents, an intolerable situation to which we have somehow accommodated ourselves. We talk about it endlessly, preferably in general terms, so that we do not actually have to do anything. It has caused unnaturally high rates of illness and mental breakdown among young people. It has also increased the suicide and crime rates. These things are well established by a large variety of authorities. They are now beyond doubt. I suggest to honourable senators, through you Mr Acting Deputy President, that we should not be surprised at that. We should understand that these evil manifestations are intrinsic to the situation. The problem is, of course, urgent because of these things. It is quite possible to ignore or overlook individual tragedies, but by ignoring them we do not remove the fact that they exist and continue to happen or mitigate to any extent the suffering that they cause.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have patiently waited out the various talkfests with which the Government has occupied its time so far. The National Economic Summit Conference was of course useful. It had its values in general terms but I have perceived nothing it has done to solve specific problems in this society which urgently require solution. The other talkfest, the Constitutional Convention, appears to have been a complete disaster and an utter waste of time and public money. However, it is of interest that the Summit promised co-operation and consensus between the unions and employers on our problems. The time has now come for the Government to put those fine words into action and get something done. We appeal to it to tackle the area of youth unemployment immediately and in certain specific directions with which we believe it would not entirely disagree.

The Government has warned the community that it has a hard time ahead of it and that it will be a matter of years before any significant improvement can be made in the rate of unemployment. That is a dismal enough prognostication but, assuming that we accept it-I suppose we have to since, after all, it is the Government which is calling the shots-it then implies an immediate need for special measures to be taken to lessen the effect of unemployment on young people and to give them some greater measure of hope and opportunity within the present economic constraints that the nation faces. This can be done. The means are known. It can be demonstrated and I suggest it needs only the will and organisation to do it. As a Parliament, our task is to encourage the Government to do that. The Democrats' first suggestion is that the Government go to the unions to consult on alterations to awards and conditions of work which will somehow resolve the appalling and chaotic situation which the growing framework of part time work in Australia has reached. We have to get a formalisation of this situation and encourage job sharing in appropriate areas. I hope that the Government will not simply play about with this matter but see that it is dealt with thoroughly so that part time work, which is a fact of life in many areas now, can be better regulated and extended into areas where it is at present actively discouraged.

Recently, I heard of a case-I think most honourable senators will also have heard of it-of a young man who went to work at a surf shop in a State I will not name. He was offered a dollar an hour in cash to work in that place. He was told to shut up and not to say anything about it. His is not the only example of that kind I have heard of. This is going on extensively in our society. It is disgraceful and tragic that young people are now being exploited shamefully in the area of part time work basically because no central authority has got together the idea that part time work is needed in the community, it exists in the community, and it has to be regularised.

TALK.START.PARA: —How old was he?

—He was 14 as it happens. I feel that a Labor Government, for philosophical reasons, would want to do something about these things. But there is the other side of the coin. I will quote from an article which appeared in the Geelong Advertiser, which honourable senators from Victoria would know, on Friday, 22 April, about a Dr Mario Marchesani who was facing gaol because he did not want to pay a fine or pay his former receptionist for hours which she did not work. He was caught at the other end of the scale. He, apparently with her concurrence, gave his receptionist work on a part time basis for between 21 and 30 hours a week for which he offered to pay her. Because of the conditions of her award it was found later that she was due to be paid for the whole working week and he was sued for the balance. He now faces gaol. Both those extremes are a disgrace. They indicate that the Government must intervene in this area as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Part time work is, of course, only an economic palliative. We do not suggest it is more than that. It does not increase the amount of work or income available but it has considerable value as a palliative. In the first place it obviously takes more people out of unproductive and psychologically corrosive idleness and gives them something to do and a better source of income than the dole. A further value is that more people are given work experience. Of course that is the catch 22 situation for so many of our young unemployed. No job is offered them until they have experience but without a job they cannot get any experience . An effective part time work and job-sharing program would significantly increase the number of people with work experience who would be available on a full time basis later as the economy improved. This would seem a rational basis- -

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you examined how much it would cost the business sector to do this?

—I do know that large areas of business would prefer to have that option made available to them. Many small businesses, as the Senate may be aware , cannot really take on another full time person, but if they were permitted to take on a person on a reasonable part time basis they might be able to build up their turnover to the extent that that person got a full time job later. I think that is a very important area of economic expansion that bears thinking about. There is, of course, the additional value that as more people have even a little more money-more than they need for bare survival-the community benefits. All areas of business, initially small businesses, must benefit from the additional spending power.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are well enough aware of the nation's financial problems, which are serious enough, but we urge the Government at least to liberalise extensively the amount of money that can be earned before the unemployment benefit is reduced. We do not think that the present system saves the country money. On the contrary, it applies a very powerful disincentive to people not to enter into part time work and it costs the economy productive effort. If all unemployed people knew that they could get a reasonable additional sum of money without penalty they would do their best, I think, to go out and earn it, and spending power would be better equalised as a result. We would then get some alteration to the highly dangerous effect, now growing in this society, of having a majority-admittedly, it is still a large majority-with high spending power, much of which they do not use but devote to savings because they are afraid of losing their own jobs, while we have an increasing minority of people with no spending power beyond mere survival. This is why, of course, we cannot sell things within our own economy. The more this goes on the worse it will get. Liberalisation of the amount of money that people can earn would help to ease that situation and would, indeed, make a tremendous difference to people 's self respect. I should think that an unemployed married man with children ought to feel that he can earn without a penalty a decent amount of money to provide his family with some of the things that it should have.

The second part of the motion urges measures to encourage the provision in various businesses of one more workplace into which young people could be placed on a roster or part time basis in order to give them work experience. As I said earlier to Senator Messner, many small businesses are at the stage where they cannot afford another full time employee but could use the services of another person on a part time basis. We suggest that the Government recognise this as a situation which has very powerful potential to get more people into work, even if it is only for one, two or three days a week, and to enable people to gain work experience. I suggest that many small businesses would find this useful as a transition period before giving a part time employee, or even another person, a full time job. Businesses would get the chance to build themselves up to the extent that they had such a person gainfully employed. We believe that the current incentives should be continued, but that they should be monitored very carefully to ensure as far as possible that they are not abused. That is not an easy matter, but it is worth more attention.

Another obvious measure open to the Government, but again one with its difficulties because of the problem of revenue replacement, is payroll tax. These State taxes are a positive disincentive to employing people, and we believe that their abolition is a nettle which must be grasped soon. It would be to the benefit of society generally if they were. The basic need seems to us to be for the unions to give some ground and to recognise that while in earlier eras it was reasonable enough to consider work as something offered on a full time, weekly basis, that is something not now appropriate to the society in which we live, and indeed, something which increasing numbers of people do not want. I turn to an article in the Age of 27 April which refers to a study made in New South Wales, interestingly enough, by the Deputy Leader of the New South Wales Opposition, Mrs Rosemary Foot, who raised $60,000 privately to pay for a study of permanent part time work. The article reported one of the conclusions of that study to be as follows:
Permanent part-time work may be preferred by up to a quarter of Australia's work force, . . .

I can believe this, having been into factories to talk with young married women who have children and who are working. They have said that they will work only until they get the washing machine, or whatever they are saving for, because they have husbands and children. It is too much for them to work a full time week and then be expected to go home and look after their families as well. Both they and their employers have told me that they would prefer a regularised part time basis of work whereby a young woman would be trained in a certain job, and continue in that job for a year or perhaps two or three years. Now they tend to leave after a few months and another person then has to be trained. That is uneconomic from the point of view of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are men who would like to do that, too.

—I believe that is so. There are men who would like to do it too and I think that is not unreasonable. Men who want to study, to finish a degree they had never finished, or something like that, might well want to do that.
—Or look after their family.

—Or look after their families. I see that as a very reasonable point of view. There is nothing wrong with it at all. This is an increasing trend for the future. I think that those who do not want to hide their heads in the sand know very well that automation and robotisation will reduce the amount of work available steadily and quite rapidly from now on. We have to ask ourselves: Is this a bad thing? Is it not better that monotonous, manual, hard or unpleasant work should be done by machines? Of course it is better that it should, but we have to adjust to this. One way of adjusting is to allow those who might wish to work less than a full week to do so, and to encourage other people towards the same kind of attitude of sharing the available work. Robotisation and automation ought to increase overall productivity. It is important-indeed, vital-that the community share in this increased productivity in the form of higher rewards.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we need to look away from the present methods of payment and increasingly towards a system of payment based on productivity rather than hours worked. Without that important change we will merely have a community which takes a neo-Luddite view that automation is automatically bad because it reduces the amount of work available. I know that payment based on productivity is not an easy principle to apply. It is impossible in some cases. I am also aware that there are areas in which it will never be possible to use that system. Not only should it be possible in the case of the majority of jobs but it is also urgently necessary for a move to be made in that direction. I think we need a change of thinking among those genuine conservatives in our union movement. There are some genuine conservatives in that movement who I think will have to smarten up their act and think carefully about it.

The third part of this motion deals with the need for more educational and training opportunities. These need to be carefully planned, much more so than in the past. We cannot simply feel satisfied with a re-run of the Regional Employment Development Scheme, for example, although it is easy to be wise after the event. That program had its failings. While it might be very nice for, say, Wombat, New South Wales, to get a new toilet block in its park, I think we should be looking in these training schemes at getting to more positive wealth- producing or wealth-conseving national objectives. In this way they can be financed into the future without being the drain on the community that they otherwise would be. The second issue is that there is very little point in training more people for work areas which are already overcrowded. This is the bugbear of all young people. They ask: 'What shall I be? Shall I be an accountant?' There are too many accountants. 'Will I be a teacher', they ask. Many teachers are on the dole. This is not good. We cannot continue in this manner and think that we are to do anything of any real value. We must make a move towards new areas and provide rationally for them.

I have mentioned before in the Senate the opportunities provided by the new energy industries. I will go over them again because I think they are vitally important. These are genuine new areas of employment which could be easily used. Let us suppose, for instance, that the Government decided to give a really generous tax concession to businesses and householders prepared to install solar hot water heaters anywhere in Australia. That concession would need to be large enough for the extra interest payments incurred by a young family in buying their house to be less than the saving in electricity charges. In other words, a financial incentive would have to be provided for putting in something which is, after all, of value to society and a genuine conservation measure. I predict that a new labour intensive, regionally distributed industry would spring up throughout the nation rapidly and that it could provide as many as 100,000 jobs within two years. If at the same time government training schemes offered young people training in the know-how in that area, the people would be there to do the work.

Is this pie in the sky? Is it impractical? The point is that this is already being done, successfully and efficiently, in a society very like Australia. It has been done for some years and could be done here with equal success. There are no problems and no doubts. We simply need to ask the Government of California for its paper work and send someone over to see how it is done. We could then introduce it in Australia straight away. We would have people at work within a matter of months. We need simply to follow that economic example. I refer to the Californian experience with what is called Solarcal, which is a commission or instrumentality designed to do two things: To encourage in every possible way the development of solar energy in the State of California, and, recognising the fact that the manufacture and installation of solar devices is labour-intensive, to increase employment. This has succeeded brilliantly. In the number of years that the program has been going, it has been enormously successful. In some parts of California, like San Diego county, it is now not legal to build a new house without putting proper solar installations into it. I suggest there are many parts of Australia also where that should be the law. It is in the pure interests of reasonable conservation of materials which cannot be replaced in this world.

Of course, the whole Solarcal experiment is based on an enormously well worked out program of tax concessions, which I think is the key point because this provides people with an incentive. People get something like 55 per cent off their federal and state income taxes to finance this. At the moment the cost of a solar hot water heater is so great that the average young family in Australia will say that it cannot justify the interest it will have to pay on that money when compared with the savings that it will get by not using electric power. While that situation continues, of course, we will not have these installations in sufficient numbers in Australia. Of course, they have a very important bearing on our energy conservation requirements into the future. They are conservational. That is, or should be, a national intention.

The Californian Energy Commission did its homework to a considerable extent-I have seen lengthy documents on this-and found that it was cheaper to have people provide these installations and subsidise them than build enormously expensive new thermal, hydroelectric or nuclear power stations. The Commission found that it was cheaper to subsidise people to conserve energy than it was to build those things. At the same time people are being employed. There has been an enormous increase in employment in California because of this one issue alone. The tax concessions that are given tend to be repaid to an extent by the new employment, by the fact that the people who are newly employed are paying tax and because they are not being paid the dole. I suggest that there would be the same effect in Australia. Documents on this matter from the Californian Energy Commission are available to this Government and, if necessary, I can provide them. I have them all in my files. But I think it would be a good thought if the Government had a look at those suggestions and introduced them in this country fairly soon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only very briefly to the motion of Senator Mason. He has expressed concern about an issue which is of concern, I believe, to all Australians. I think he has illustrated his points with a degree of concern and compassion which the Government shares. The motion seeks to provide a number of suggested solutions to the matter of youth unemployment. I think the solutions he suggests are all matters which should properly be considered by government, but at this stage government is certainly not in a position to say that if one examines the relative economic merits of each of the propositions Senator Mason put forward they would be necessarily the solutions chosen by government. They may be the solutions which would contribute to alleviating some of the problems to which he refers. I quite agree with him when he says that attitudes to part time work in Australia have to change. I think that was one of the desirable conclusions which came out of the National Economic Summit Conference, not specifically in terms of part time work but in terms of changed attitudes towards matters which affected the unemployment level in Australia and the size of the work force in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said in the Senate in the last few days, I think any government which claimed-for example, as the last Government did-that it would provide a cure to unemployment in conventional terms, was making a mistake. That claim did not fool anybody, particularly the electorate. Ultimately the only people it fooled were members of that Government. I say that because a conventional sort of view is still about that if one were to restore the existing Australian economy to the level it was at in 1965 in terms of growth and relative affluence one would, by that process, dramatically reduce unemployment. I do not believe that to be true. I believe it would make an impact on unemployment but it would go no further than that. I want-not in any spirit of criticism of the suggestions Senator Mason made-to make one other point, which I think it is very important to consider, in relation to youth unemployment and that is the fact that by comparison with a number of other countries in the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development Australia has a high youth unemployment problem. But it also has a high youth employment problem, which is a different thing.

For example, in the United States of America some 74 per cent-as I recall the figure-of people in the age group 16 to 22 years of age are engaged in education of one form or another whether it be training, apprenticeship training or in colleges. In Australia the figure is about 22 per cent, as I recall it. In Japan the figure is equivalent to the United States figure. So if one looks at comparable figures of youth unemployment one can see that our position is worse and that in terms of comparable figures of the number of young people in jobs, if this is regarded, as it used to be, as a favourable indicator, our position is better than that of a lot of other countries. We have many young people in work. I looked at the figures late last year and found that 25,000 15-year-old people were employed in Australia. I think 100,000 16-year-old people are employed in Australia. That is a problem which cannot be redressed overnight. One of the election commitments of the Australian Labor Party prior to the last election was a commitment to increase the participation rate in education over three years. The figure was given. I think it was 30,000 additional students who were to be encouraged into post-school education in the next three years. If nothing more, I think that indicates a recognition of one of the basic problems we face in terms of the employment or unemployment of young people in Australia.

As I have indicated, I do not believe that this problem can be solved other than by a combination of policies. Some of the policies suggested by Senator Mason may commend themselves. Everyone in the community has different views about how we should solve these problems. The previous Government advanced one idea in the course of the election campaign. That Government was going to put 10 ,000 young people into the Army as part of a solution to the unemployment problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —For training purposes.
—Senator Chaney says: 'For training purposes'. It does not matter what purposes it was for.
—The Army did not like it.

—I know the Army did not like it. It was an interesting exercise in policy formulation because I heard about it before it was announced. What happened was that there was a meeting of the Tamworth Chamber of Commerce one night to which everyone was asked to come and put their views on what they thought should be done about youth unemployment. I am informed that every eccentric in the Tamworth district gathered together on that occasion, including the former Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair. It was at that meeting that the suggestion came up that the solution to the youth unemployment problem was to encourage people into the Army. That subsequently became a policy matter in the policy speech of the former Prime Minister.
—Are you scoffing at talking to people in Tamworth?

—Senator Chaney is offended by the suggestion. I am not scoffing about talking to people in Tamworth. I am scoffing at their view that a responsible government in this country would make a policy of that order on the run and off the top of its head as it clearly did. When the matter was announced in the policy speech of course it was roundly criticised by experts in both the area of social welare problem of youth unemployment and in defence matters who regarded it as a ludicrous suggestion from the point of view of the Services. That is all I am scoffing at. The only point I am trying to make is that there are dangers in quickly adopting any of these policies without examining the downstream effects-if I can use an expression I have acquired recently-of those policies in respect of other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: So we commend the spirit of Senator Mason's motion which is before the Senate. We agree that the issues he raised should be examined just as a number of other matters should be examined in relation to trying to find a solution to this very difficult social problem. In respect of this problem we have been extraordinarily lucky. The repercussions which might have already followed because of the size of the problem, as yet, have not followed, although they probably will. We commend Senator Mason's views to the Senate and the Government will take them into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) for his warm response to the spirit of Senator Mason 's motion, which the Opposition also supports. The problem of unemployment- especially the unemployment of young people-does need new initiatives such as permanent part time work. We might look at some of the difficulties, in practice , of a roster basis, as set out in the motion, for each place of employment- including having a series of unemployed young people-or look at the actual ambiguities involved in the words 'without penalty' when the introduction of permanent part time work is taken on by unemployed young people. We do support the spirit of the motion, especially the third part that looks to full time-and part time for that matter-educational and training opportunities for unemployed people.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to add that there has been a great deal of discussion following the last Government's initiatives in the area of transitional education. I believe that whilst so many of the State education departments and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority are looking at the structure of secondary schools, transition education should be incorporated within the comprehensive structure of secondary schools. Whilst there will be room for some transitional education in the technical and further education sector, I believe that the schools are letting down young people and school leavers if within the secondary schools comprehensive system there are not these transition programs.

The second and last matter I want to raise relates to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts report on Preparation for the Work Force which was tabled here many months ago. It has been warmly received by many spokesmen in the State education systems, in non-government schools and even in this Parliament. But one matter which bears upon this motion, I believe, has not been fully understood. It relates to the case for restructuring the secondary school system. It is set out under the heading 'A Case for Restructuring the Secondary School System' on pages 32 and 33 of the report, especially in the first three paragraphs. I refer also to the introduction to recommendation 15 (i ) of the report. I want to draw this to the attention of persons such as Mr John Steinle, who has been appointed by the Commonwealth Government and the South Australian Government-I think the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is involved as well-and who is reviewing the structure of secondary schools. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the three paragraphs of the report that I have referred to together with recommendation 15 (i) in order to bring attention to the matter in the debate on this motion.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
A Case for Restructuring the Secondary School System

A criticism of the education system that came through persistently during the inquiry was that secondary schools lack comprehensiveness in the sense that their curricula too narrowly favours those students who are academically minded and who aspire to enrol in post-secondary education programs. The charge has been made that secondary schools are geared to cater for an elite minority, a minority which has been expanding over the years but still remains nevertheless, a minority. To understand the basis of this bias and the nature of the problems faced by secondary schools, one needs to consider the dramatic change in retention rates that has occurred over the last two decades. Less than 20 years ago, about one student in ten who started high school went through to year twelve. That proportion has now increased to about one in three. These higher retention rates have created major problems for secondary school planners.

The original concept of the Year 12 curriculum was to serve that very small minority of students going onto post-secondary studies. However, in successive years, the number of students failing this year of study has grown to be far in excess of those going on to tertiary studies. In the meantime, the original curriculum has persisted. Indeed many argue that the academic bias of Year 12 has expanded to a like bias in Year 10 and 11, thus the burgeoning numbers of students enrolling in the final years of secondary schools have far outstripped the development of more appropriate curriculum and school studies to best serve them.

As a result it has been estimated that about one-third of all secondary school students, for varying reasons, are disillusioned and dissatisfied with their secondary school education. This dissatisfaction has given rise to negative learning attitudes in students as well as problems for schools.
15. Secondary School System

(i) That the Australian Education Council urgently convene a conference between representatives of Commonwealth and State Education Departments for the purpose of drawing up plans for a restructuring of the secondary school system to provide curriculum structures that directly serve school leavers with non- academic outcomes.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

This is an important matter; it is central to the perceptions of Australian foreign policy and it is on the agenda of the Australian Government for decision . I urge that the Senate adopt this motion so that we may reinforce the views expressed to so many of us by people around Australia and by our neighbours in this region and the Government may take note of it. What are the facts about the Vietnamese military occupation of Kampuchea and Laos? Some quarter of a million Vietnamese soldiers occupy the two neighbouring, theoretically independent, countries of Kampuchea and Laos. According to the publication Military Balance, published by the International Institute of Strategic Studies, Vietnam has 170, 000 troops in Kampuchea, being 20 army divisions, two marine divisions and support units; and in Laos it has some 45,000 troops, being three infantry division and support troops. These figures are broadly confirmed by alternative publications, such as Strategic Balance, which estimates there are some 200,000 troops in Kampuchea, and the Far Eastern Economic Review, the widely acclaimed publication in Asia, which estimates that there are 160,000 to 180,000 Vietnamese troops in Kampuchea.

The huge, aggressive military forces of Vietnam are ocupying those two neighbouring Indo-Chinese countries-countries that, for more than 20 years, have suffered warfare, revolution, bloodshed, murder, drought and every kind of tragic circumstance. Why is it that there is such a public awareness of these problems? I believe that there are three reasons why the public is alert to this problem in Indo-China. We may well ask: Why is it that Australians are so interested in Indo-China? We have a natural neighbourliness between South East Asian countries such as the Philippines, Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia and our major trading partner, Japan; with the country with the major population in this region, China; and with our traditional and close ally, the United States of America-or, for that matter, with New Guinea and the Pacific. Why is it that out of this range of countries about us the attention of the Australian people is focused on the problems of Indo-China?

I think the first reason is the tragic division in this country concerning the tragedy of the Vietnamese conflict. It occupied so much of our time and caused a great deal of heart searching and debate and the involvement of our own troops in Vietnam. The repercussions of that hostile, difficult and divided period are still to some extent with us. The second reason concerns the by now thousands of refugees from that area, principally from Vietnam but also from Kampuchea and Laos, who have come to settle in Australia. Tragically, approximately one half of the refugees from that area are at the bottom of the sea because the frail craft that they used to escape the tyranny of communism and the lack of freedom in their homeland led them to take risks which caused their deaths in the sea. But one half of them did make it to Hong Kong, Malaysia, Indonesia, or even all the way to the shores of Australia. There have also been repatriations to free countries about the world.

Those refugees are now an important part of the Australian community. There are Vietnamese, Kampuchean and Laotian communities in Australia. Whilst this is a recent wave of refugees who have settled in Australia there is also a sympathetic group of refugees from Eastern Europe, also coming from communist regimes. The third reason-this is very significant-the Australian public are alert to the problems of this region is the tragic massacres of the people of Kampuchea at the hands of their own Government. The former Pol Pot Government in Kampuchea is notorious in Australia and in all parts of the world for its villainous murder, the genocide, of Kampuchean people. The response of the Australian people was individually, in small gifts, to donate a total of some $ 8m towards direct food and medical aid to the Kampuchean people who were suffering in those years. This was added to by direct grants-in-aid from the Australian Government.

For these three reasons 'Kampuchea' is a household word for the Australian people. We cannot mistake the view of the Australian people. We cannot regard the Australian people as ignorant of this problem in Kampuchea and Laos where a quarter of a million Vietnamese military forces are in occupation. In addition, many Australians have travelled to this region. As an undergraduate I travelled about-partly hitchhiking, partly in trucks, on motor bikes and in cars, on the quite distinctive trucks that are in Thailand, for example-over the Mekong River into Laos and across the countryside in the peaceful days before the wartorn tragedy came to Cambodia, be it at Siem Reap or Phnom Penh. I travelled also in South Vietnam. Since then I have been back several times to each of those countries, but only once to Kampuchea. I am not alone; many Australians have taken a direct interest, not only in Indonesia and Malaysia which are closer to our shores, but also in this part of Indo-China. My brother returned this week from participation in an International Red Cross medical team on the border of Thailand and Kampuchea, where he was a surgeon assisting the Kampuchean refugees . He saw the Vietnamese army and air force attacks on these rather defenceless Kampuchean people, and indeed attacks on Thailand.

Only three and a half years ago, with the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, and Mr Jim Carlton from the House of Representatives I, representing the Senate, went to Aranya Prathet, a town on the border between Thailand and Kampuchea. I observed the refugee camp there and Vietnamese soldiers on the border and the problems as perceived by the Thai people. Delegates from the Association of South East Asian Nations Inter-Parliamentary Organisation are currently visiting Australia. Actually, they are in Adelaide today, in my home city. Last evening members of the delegation were here for dinner-they came from all five of the ASEAN countries-as guests of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. On the agenda of their meetings and in all the ASEAN forums the matter of highest priority is that of the security of the region. They pay the highest regard to the threat that Vietnam poses to those ASEAN countries and to the high priority which the ASEAN countries place on seeing Vietnamese forces completely out of Kampuchea and Laos. So there is wide public alertness to the problems of Indo-China.

What must be done by Australia in response to these problems? There are two clear goals about which there is no dispute at the moment among the parties in this Parliament. Firstly, the Vietnamese forces must completely withdraw from the occupied countries of Kampuchea and Laos. That military force of 250,000 people should go back to Vietnam. Secondly, there should be free elections enabling the Kampuchean people to elect their own government. They should have free determination and should not be interfered with from outside even by their neighbour, Vietnam. The same thing should happen in Laos. Those goals are contained in the policies of the Opposition and, as I understand it, the policies of the Government. But the offending part of the policy of the Australian Labor Party which, I believe, is in contradiction to those goals is to give direct aid to Vietnam even before those troops are withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Humanitarian and development aid. Don't forget the adjectives.

—This aid proposal was adopted by the Australian Labor Party at its national conference in June last year. Set out under a number of heads in its platform is a reference to Indo-China. Point c in the platform under the heading 'Indo-China', states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should resume its commitment to the two aid projects in Vietnam suspended in January 1979.
The aid projects were suspended by the Fraser Government as a direct result of the military occupation of Kampuchea and Laos by the Vietnamese forces. The platform continues:
We should also resume cultural exchanges so as to promote greater understanding between our countries.

The level of any future humanitarian and development aid should be consistent with our United Nations commitments and also should acknowledge our involvement in the Vietnam war and the subsequent need for rehabilitation in the interests of the Vietnamese people.

I am sympathetic with the latter phrases of that platform statement only to the extent that the Australian people and members of the Opposition will not hold against every Vietnamese generation that the regime in Vietnam was an enemy in military involvement in Vietnam in earlier years and consider that it will be our enemy forever. It is our enemy now because it has attacked aggressively a weaker neighbour in Kampuchea and another weaker neighbour in Laos. That is the reason why it is perceived to be an enemy to freedom in that region. The Vietnamese forces, backed by the Soviet Union, are aggressive imperialists in Indo-China, just as the Soviet Union is an aggressive imperialist in Afghanistan and a number of other places in the world that are of concern to freedom loving people in Australia. Vietnam has cast itself in an enemy stance against Australia.

The commitment in the Australian Labor Party's platform is thoroughly objectionable to me, to members of the Opposition and, I believe, to the great majority of people in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard extracts from five recently published editorials that relate to this matter.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
THE AUSTRALIAN
Thursday, 7 March 1983
AID TO VIETNAM IS MISPLACED CHARITY

It is entirely honorable for Australia, as one of the countries which sent soldiers to Vietnam, to want to help the long-suffering Vietnamese people. But if we were to give aid in the present circumstances our charity would be misplaced and would harm the prospects of peace in South-East Asia.
There are at present 160,000 Vietnamese soldiers in Kampuchea. If Vietnam is ready to pay for an army occuping someone else's land, it has forfeited the right to be subsidised by other nations.

Labor's opinion that by giving assistance to Vietnam we shall wean it from the Soviet bloc is not borne out by experience. The thousands of millions of dollars given in credits by the West to Poland led to no loosening of the Warsaw Pact. According to Lenin, ''the capitalists will sell us the rope with which we shall hang them''. There is no good reason why we should give Vietnam the rope with which to hang the Kampucheans.

Perhaps the most successful chapter in recent Australian foreign policy has been the achievement of good relations with China. China's opposition to the invasion of Kampuchea has been unequivocal. It would be tragic if our friendship were to be damaged by our continuing with the proposed aid.
THE AUSTRALIAN
Thursday, 5 April 1983
AID TO VIETNAM IS AID TO AGGRESSION

Those optimists who expected that the American withdrawal from Indo-China would be followed by peace and reconstruction must have had their remaining hopes dashed by the latest events on the Thai-Kampuchean border.

The much-maligned and seemingly discredited domino theory has acquired belated respectability. It is now obvious the Hanoi Government is committed to obtaining undisputed control over the whole of Indo-China and that it is prepared to risk hostilities with its non-Communist neighbors in order to achieve that ambition.

The danger of Vietnamese imperialism is recognised not only by Thailand but by the Association of South-East Asian Nations as a whole. Australia's relations with ASEAN are central to our foreign policy. While there is probably little we can do to help Thailand in the present confrontation, we should, at the very least, not subsidise Vietnam's military operations on Thailand's border.

If the Federal Government carries out its apparent intention to send economic aid to Hanoi, we shall not only be helping the aggressor but damaging our own vital interests in the region where we live.
THE AUSTRALIAN
Monday, 18 April 1983
SECOND THOUGHTS ON AID TO VIETNAM

The visit of the Chinese Prime Minister offers the Federal Government the opportunity to strengthen an association of considerable importance to this nation. If, however, the government perserveres with the ALP policy of giving economic aid to Vietnam, irreparable damage could be done to our future contacts with the world's most populous nation.

Not only China but all of the members of the Association of South East Asian nations are opposed to the usurpation of Kampuchea and fear that even if it secures its domination of Indo-China, Vietnam's imperial ambitions would not be satisfied.

Mr Hawke and Mr Hayden must be well aware of ASEAN's anxiety that the Federal Government should not proceed with its apparent intention to send aid to Hanoi while its soldiers continue their uninvited occupation of Kampuchea.
The prospect of a breach with such a significant, and so far friendly, association of neighbouring nations should be enough to give any but the most dogmatic government cause for second thoughts.
To antagonise simultaneously ASEAN and China would leave us almost entirely isolated in our region.
THE CANBERRA TIMES
Thursday, 7 April 1983
PROVISO FOR VIETNAM AID

The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, said before the election that a Labor Government would resume the aid (to Vietnam) which was cut off by the Fraser Government in 1979 in retaliation for the Vietnamese invasion and occupation of Kampuchea and the Vietnamese policies that were causing a rush of ''boat-people'' refugees to Australia.

It could well be a promise that Mr Hayden and the Government may wish to reconsider. Aid is definitely premature at this stage, given Vietnam's continued occupation of Kampuchea, its present aggression on Thai border territory and reports from credible observers of atrocities by Vietnamese forces in Kampuchea.

If the Labor Government cannot condone the invasion and occupation of Afghanistan by the Soviet Union, of East Timor by the Indonesians, of the Falklands (briefly) by the Argentines, it certainly cannot condone Vietnam's forceful occupation of Kampuchea, nor its current military action on Thai territory against refugees, in which a number of Thais have been killed.
THE COURIER MAIL
Tuesday, 19 April 1983
VIETNAM AID A HOT ISSUE
The Federal Government is wise to postpone a commitment of aid to Vietnam until after consulting allies, neighbors and important friends like China.

Mr Hawke's assurance of consultation should go beyond discussion with allies and neighbors . . . he should test the feeling also of the people of Australia. Not only will he find most of Australia's friends and allies against Vietnam aid , he probably will find most Australians against it too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I believe that these editorials are directly representative of the views of the Australians people. When honourable senators read them as part of my speech they will see that they speak for themselves. But in contradiction to those views the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, has gone to each of the ASEAN countries in turn to try to sell them the Australian Labor Party's policy, which I think he only half believes himself. The Government should note those misgivings and the misgivings of many people in its ranks in the Senate and in the House of Represenatives. The Government should use the response the Foreign Minister gained from the ASEAN countries to deny that so-called binding platform of the Australian Labor Party. When the ALP at its conferences adopts many planks in its platform some concessions are made to sectional interests within the Labor Party.

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. The honourable senator can have no knowledge of the internal operations of the Australian Labor Party, nor can he have knowledge of what is in the mind of the Foreign Minister with regard to the progress with which ALP policy will be implemented.
—That may be so but no point of order is involved. That is a point for debate.

—In my view a number of Trojan horses and hostages are built into the platform of the Australian Labor Party. They are the policies of a sectional group of the Labor Party, principally sponsored by the Left. Aid to Vietnam is one of them. It is an embarrassment to many members of the Australian Labor Party. I am urging members of the ALP to reject that platform and to become more responsibly representative of the Australian people in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: A little earlier during the debate Senator Tate interjected and said that the ALP wanted to give only civil or humanitarian aid to Vietnam before the Vietnamese military forces withdraw from Vietnam. I oppose the granting of even civil and humanitarian aid because it would directly allow a diversion of Vietnamese resources from civil uses, such as agriculture or hospitals, to be used instead in the massive costs of the occupying armies in Kampuchea and Laos. The diversion of resources would be directly enabled by Australian aid. That is the principal reason we oppose it. It is also misplaced charity. I know that Senator Tate and other honourable senators would say: 'We are called by higher ethics to love our enemies'. I am not altogether wanting to neglect that view myself but we are also called to love our friends. If we were to love our enemies-the Vietnamese backed by the Soviet Union in this aggressive stance- could honourable senators opposite tell me whether that would be consistent, for example, with giving direct aid to a belligerent aggressor against even Australia? Would that be an excuse for doing so? It would be misplaced charity to give such aid. Did Australia give aid to Turkey at the time of Gallipoli? Did Australia give aid to Japan when we were seeking to relieve New Guinea, Malaysia or the Philippines in the Second World War? Did the Australian Government give any aid payments to Indonesia in the 1960s when Indonesian armies were in the full thrust of confrontation against Malaysia? I do not believe that we did. Charity was not misplaced then and it ought not to be misplaced now.

Why then does the Government feel bound to execute ALP policy? It is because it has to watch for the left elements within the Labor Party at large and within the chambers of the Parliament. I put it to honourable senators that that is no ground at all for abandoning responsibility towards Australia, our ASEAN neighbours, Japan, China, the United States of America or, indeed, the great majority of countries in the United Nations that originally were opposed to the Vietnamese occupying armies. They do not support any such aid to Vietnam in the present circumstances. The time for such aid will come when those forces are directly withdrawn and not before.
Today, following Mr Hayden's visit to the ASEAN countries the Prime Minister of Japan, Mr Nakasone, is visiting those countries. Yesterday he was in Singapore. The Age of today reports in this way:

Mr Nakasone's firm endorsement of the strategy by Australia's closest neighbours in the region, to induce Vietnam to withdraw its forces from Kampuchea, is expected to put added pressure on the Labor Government not to resume aid to Vietnam unless Hanoi is prepared to make substantial concessions over Kampuchea.
He has spoken out strongly about it. So have all the other Foreign Ministers of the Association of South East Asian Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Japan has got a pretty good record in South East Asia! Ask Senator Sir John Carrick.

—I know that Senator Tate is referring to the unenviable record of Japan but do not let us hold that against Japan for ever. Let us regard history in its right perspective. No one in Australia condones the terrible actions of Japan at that time. But do not let us hold that against the argument put forward by the properly elected Prime Minister of Japan. He made responsible statements in 1983 about this region. It is not as a result of any encouragement from our neighbours that the Labor Government wants to give aid to Vietnam. They are all urging Australia not to give aid.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known that the Chinese Premier, Mr Zhao Ziyang, came to visit Australia. It was an important visit to this country. He is the highest ranking Chinese person ever to visit Australia. The matter which the Press reported as being the most important item on the agenda of discussions between Mr Zhao Ziyang and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs was the question of aid to Vietnam. Premier Zhao Ziyang does not want that aid to continue. He does not want it to be a block to a good, practical and, I believe, healthy relationship between China and Australia-two vastly different countries in size and in political and social structures. The relationship between Australia and China has grown in the last 10 years to be of importance to us and, I believe, also to China. We ought to express concern in this debate not only for the consequences to Japan and China but also, principally, for the consequences to our nearest neighbours. We will alienate the ASEAN countries-our immediate neighbours-if we go ahead and give such aid. Are we going to brush aside those relationships? Are they not of importance to the Australian Government?

Of even more consequence is the fact that the people of Australia will be affronted and alienated if such aid is given to Vietnam in these military circumstances. I happen to be one Liberal senator who has spoken out in this chamber for five years with a view to seeking the Australian public's understanding of the overseas aid goals of the Australian Government. I have spoken about the need for Australians to see the importance of development assistance to the countries in our near region. If this aid is given to Vietnam in spite of the military circumstances involved, I am convinced that many Australians now and in years to come will say that it is offensive to them. They will try to blacken any kind of legitimate and wholesome development assistance to the countries in our region. I do not want that to happen. I also do not want the Vietnamese people, the Kampuchean people and the Laotian people who come to settle in Australia to be alienated from the Government of Australia. We should not put on them during their resettlement process the terrible burden of being associated with an Australian Government that is giving direct aid to the Vietnamese people so that the Vietnamese can divert their resources to the military occupation of their neighbouring countries.

This is a matter of very direct concern not only to our distant neighbours, China, Japan, the United States and our near neighbours in ASEAN and the Pacific , but also the Australian people. People from those countries form part of our community. Another reason this is a very real concern is that on 17 February 1979, as a direct result of the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea and Laos, the Chinese directly invaded the northern boundary of Vietnam. Eventually they withdrew but only after many weeks of bloody fighting in which there was loss of life on both sides.

The international community was disturbed at the dangerous situation of two strong countries in the region directly fighting each other. I remember that a quite different situation applied when I lead a student delegation to China in 1968 during the cultural revolution. In 1968 the Chinese said to us: 'The Vietnamese and Chinese people are as lips and teeth; they are so close together' . Ten years later that situation had been reversed. In my view they had gone back to the more traditional, centuries old situation where emnity existed between these direct rivals. That hostility between China and Vietnam has not abated. In fact, it has grown. In recent weeks there have been further hostilities and loss of life on the northern border of Vietnam. Part of the reason for concern is that the earlier invasion by China was called the first lesson to Vietnam for its military adventures into Kampuchea and Laos. The question is raised: Will there be a second lesson? Will the solidarity, the close alliance that China offers to the Kampuchean Government in exile-or I should say the Cambodian Government in exile because, as I understand it, that is how it wishes to be known-bringing even more threats of violence, hostility, difficulty and danger to that region? If Australia goes ahead with direct overseas aid to Vietnam it will exacerbate all of those hostilities. It will make the relationship between China and Vietnam all the worse.

If honourable senators opposite were to visit Kampuchea or Laos how would they face up to the ordinary people of Kampuchea or Laos when they ask: 'Why are you giving aid to Vietnam which has occupied our countries with such hostility and presented us with such difficulty, suffering and oppression? Why is the Australian government giving aid to that country?'. That question will not arise if the aid only goes to Vietnam after there has been a proper withdrawal of all of those troops.

Honourable senators opposite should ask themselves this question: 'What kind of explanation will I offer to the ordinary people of Kampuchea and Laos if the Australian Government goes ahead with such a tragic decision and gives aid to the enemy of freedom in Indo-China?'. We of the Opposition will not identify ourselves with such a decision. We will seek to strengthen the alliances that have grown between Australia and the peoples in this region. We will seek to reassure the people who have settled in this country from Kampuchea, Vietnam and Laos that we have no part whatsoever in the decision of the Government. Today I have genuinely tried to be charitable. Only one section of the Australian Labor Party won this platform with which the ALP is now landed.

TALK.START.PARA: — Well, you're wrong.

—Senator Tate says that I am wrong. Apparently all elements of the Labor Party support this platform. The responsibility for this action lies on all their heads, not just on the heads of their left wing members. I ask honourable senators opposite to urge their Government not to go ahead with this decision and to change its policy. I urge all honourable senators to support the motion that is now before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before resuming debate on the matter I might, just for the record, mention that the Opposition had proposed to continue with the debate on the previous item and had a number of speakers ready to speak on it. There were some small misunderstandings and alternative arrangements were made between me and the two Whips. The Opposition is simply honouring that arrangement which was made on the run. I wish to acknowledge the situation of a number of Opposition senators who had expected to speak on that matter this afternoon. They will welcome the opportunity to resume debate on the matter of aid to Vietnam, a matter which is, I am sure, of great interest to the Australian people and to a number of honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already had an opportunity to speak on the motion which is before us and which relates to the various papers and statement which have been put down by the Government with respect to the National Economic Summit Conference. I do not wish to recanvass all of the points which I have made in previous debates, but I do welcome the fact that we have had in the Senate, both through the agency of the Opposition bringing on a matter of public importance and through the Government bringing forward the statement for consideration, the opportunity to concentrate on the very large issues and problems which Australia faces at the moment.

In the previous speeches which I have made this week I have concentrated on what I have seen as the essential decision which this Government faces in the short term; that is, what it should be putting before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with respect to future wage increases through the centralised wage fixing system which it is said the Summit endorsed. It was of course the publicly stated intention of the previous Government to come out from the freeze through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There are a number of public statements to that effect. To that extent there is a similarity between the procedures which are to be followed now and the procedures which would have been followed under the previous Government. The previous Government had made it clear that it proposed to seek an extension of the wages pause to a full year. That was always its intention and what it urged on the Commission last year. There was unanimity that there should be a wage freeze for at least six months and the question of an extension of the freeze was a matter which would have come before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in any event.

I have already acknowledged what I see as the very valuable contribution of the Government in achieving a better framework for economic debate in this country through the Summit by publishing a great amount of Government information which has not previously been available, by making some very forthright statements on the relationship between wages and employment, by making forthright statements on the state of the economy and by providing a venue for some very significant Australian businessmen and for business and trade union organisations. I think there is a better public understanding of the difficult decisions which have to be made and of the trade-offs that there are between wage increases and levels of employment.

Of course, as Senator Button made the point yesterday and as indeed I made the point in putting this matter of public importance forward, there are a whole series of policies which are relevant to employment. There is no single area of government decision and government submission which is of more importance than the area of the views which will be put before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission by the Government over the coming months. What was put before the Conference by this Government, and what was put before the Conference and supported by most, if not all of the business participants, was that a great deal of restraint in wages was central to restoring profitability and hence investment in Australia, that it was central to restoring competitiveness for Australian industry and that it was central, therefore, to increased employment in Australia.

Again at an earlier time this week I dealt with the reasons why there are some restraints-or why some people seem to think there are restraints-on the ability of Government to urge a continuation of the wages pause through to the end of this year. I do believe that industrial relations factors bear heavily upon the Government. These are reflected I think very clearly in the contribution which the Labor Premier of Western Australia, Mr Burke made, where he quite squarely put his Government's view that wage restraint would best be served by an adjustment of wages in the second part of 1983. He quite firmly put the view at that time that some adjustment this year was necessary and that is in the light of the industrial reality.

I repeat that if it is a fact that because of trade union attitudes it is not possible to exercise the degree of wage restraint that the Government put forward in, I think, scenario C then we still have some way to go down the track towards an acceptable consensus which will serve the interests of the unemployed in Australia.

I turn very briefly to the second leg of the objection which is to continued wage restraint at the level which I think many contributors were suggesting at the Summit; that is, the question of the hardship of those on low incomes. I have already dealt with that. I merely wish to add the point which I should have mentioned before; that is, that when one looks at the hardship of people who are on earned incomes which have not been adjusted for some time, one has to compare that with the hardship which is suffered by those who are pitched out of employment and on to unemployment benefit. I think that the much greater hardship is suffered by those who are unemployed. The question of hardship of those who are in employment ought to be looked at, not in terms of trying to stand against what Senator Walsh I think has acknowledged is necessary-which was some reduction of average real incomes in this country-but looked at against the alternative which faces some people, which is unemployment.

I would also like to comment on one other point which has struck me during the debate on the Summit here in the Senate. A number of comments have been made about the comparative couth of the Economic Summit and about the fact that the Parliament might learn something from the civilised discourse which took place at that time. I think that all of us who are concerned about the institution of parliament would have noted those comments and wondered to what extent we should take them into account in the rough and tumble of debate between the Government and the Opposition. I say to the Government that I accept that that rough and tumble is part of the necessary stuff of democracy, that we cannot get to the point where there is simply one single view which is embraced by all or we have given away a very precious part of democracy in Australia.

I say to the Government that there does appear to be marked contrast in the way Government Ministers respond to points which were made very forcefully in the Summit and which were agreed to by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with a warm ' Thanks Bill' or 'Thanks Jack' or 'Thanks Rod' as they resumed their seat and the rather more critical responses that I and my colleagues have received in this place. I do suggest that there are perhaps some issues which are of genuine difficulty for the Government as they were difficult for our Government. I do not for a moment suggest that the difficulties of Australia have suddenly emerged. They were difficulties that we were facing and to which we were having real problems in finding solutions. I think that an exchange between us is one which can be at a level which perhaps might give more public confidence to the process here and which might also lead to a growth in the sort of consensus in the community which is apparently the wish of this Government; it is certainly its expressed wish.

I have only a few minutes to go. I will mention something else which I think has been overlooked in debate so far. I would like to congratulate the Australian Council of Social Service for a number of elements which it put before the Conference. ACOSS in a sense was a lone voice speaking for those who the Opposition said were largely unrepresented-those who were not part of the trade union movement, of the business community or of the Labor Party. I think it endeavoured to put the interests of those unrepresented people before the Conference. I was particularly pleased to see that it was prepared to face up in its submission and through the words of Mr McKenzie to the reality that to bring about the sort of income redistribution that it advocated required the imposition of taxes. When I was first Minister for Social Security I complained that ACOSS was very prone to pointing up the need to have very large increases in social security expenditures and large increases in income redistribution without ever identifying the fact that some would have to lose in that process. I think that in the interests of a realistic political debate in Australia it was very proper and highly desirable that ACOSS should have put its views on tax reform as well as its views on income redistribution. It is an essential part of the process. If we are to move to a more realistic welfare debate and a more realistic income debate in Australia the sort of honesty which ACOSS adopted in its submission on this occasion is something we wish to see emulated by all participants.

I also wish to acknowledge the range of income factors which were brought out particularly well by Sir Roderick Carnegie in his contribution. He pointed out that the total cost of employing people may be up to twice the wage rates which are actually paid, because of the various factors he mentioned-taxes on employment, the cost of workers compensation and the extended holiday provisions which apply in Australia. These are matters which both the Opposition and the Government must grapple with if we are to do something about Australian labour being priced out of the market. We all want increased standards for all Australians. We all have to accept that some hard decisions are part of achieving those increased standards. I hope that the debate in this place, as in the Summit, will lead to a better appreciation of what is required of policy makers, of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing ministerial statements on the National Economic Summit Conference. I welcome the opportunity to speak to these papers. I would like to take up the point that Senator Chaney made when he referred to the mood and the general situation in Australia at the moment. I must take Senator Chaney back over the last seven years. I have to do that because, although Senator Chaney in his dulcet tones is perhaps trying to change the mood, the Australian people well remember the activities of his Government. He must accept responsibility for the sort of thing that happened, particularly in this chamber. Until a few moments ago Senator Sir John Carrick was in the chamber. Senator Sir John Carrick on many occasions has given us the benefit of his little homilies on deficits. What we did not know until after the election was that stealthily the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, was squirrelling away a monstrous deficit for this country. Of course, he saddled the new Labor Government with special problems because in one sense he summed up the style of the Fraser Government. We lived with the Fraser Government for seven years and I think the matter deserves to be adequately treated.

SPEECH.PARA: The significant thing is that the Labor Government has changed the style and nothing is more symbolic of that attempt to change the pace in politics in Australia than the National Economic Summit Conference. The fetishes of the Fraser Government will not be placed on the Australian people. We will attempt to plan the future. We will try to bring the organisations of Australia together to see what can be done to face the economic crisis that the Labor Government has been left with. It is significant that the Summit was organised to bring together national and State organisations of capital and labour in the most positive manner. The most important thing is that the style of this Government is an attempt to be positive.

In referring to the mood of Australia, Senator Chaney has to realise that only last year the stamp of the Fraser Government, with divisiveness being the order of the day, was on this country, Indeed, Senator Chaney on several occasions had to dirty his hands as part of the Fraser Ministry. I say that very deliberately because only last year in this place Senator Chaney had the carriage of a typical example of the style of the Fraser Government. I refer to the Social Security Amendment Bill 1982 which proposed to disqualify spouses of strikers from receiving the unemployment benefit. That legislation summed up the style of the Fraser Government. The then Government attempted to take the unemployment benefit from the spouses of people involved in industrial disputes despite the facts that only 16 per cent of disputes last longer than five days, only 8.9 per cent of all strikers are involved in disputes that last longer than 10 days and only one per cent of disputes last more than 20 days. The Fraser Government was not concerned with the money; it was concerned with scapegoating. That was the style of the Fraser Government and that is what the Hawke Labor Government is attempting to change. We are trying to prevent the division in our society which was so much a part of the seven years of the Fraser Government.

Last year we were threatened with another convulsion in industrial relations. This was an attempt to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to introduce voluntary unionism and to withdraw the powers of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to award preference to unionists. This was very much part of the Fraser Government's program. In this case we were saved by the activities of an excellent Senate select committee. We were prevented from having the pre- election sham that the Fraser Government planned by attacking the trade union movement and forcing industrial disruption, as would have happened had that legislation been passed by the Senate. That involves a very significant description of the Fraser Government. A person by the name of Viner was the Minister in charge of those two pieces of legislation to which I referred. Mr Viner was a complete product of the Fraser era. Mr Viner set about following this disruptive path and it was only when he was completely unacceptable at the time that Mr Fraser was facing an election that he was replaced by Mr Macphee.

The importance of dwelling on this for a moment is that there are two lines in the Liberal Party. Last year the line was that of Mr Viner, who represented the backwoodsmen of the Liberal Party and the National Party. On the other hand, there was Mr Macphee and his supporters. The Viner line was for the law of the jungle. The whole range of initiatives that he and his supporters took sought to take Australia back to enterprise unions and a whole range of other things which would have disrupted industrial relations in Australia. Honourable senators might ask why I am raising these things. The significant thing is that some of those people are still here. Mr Viner has gone by virtue of the Australian people and Mr Fraser followed him soon afterwards. Unfortunately some of the people guilty of the actions of that Government are still here-Mr Howard in particular. This person who has a credibility gap in relation to industrial relations or economic matters is still with us. That is the problem. It is serious because this morning's Australian Financial Review, shows that the problems to which I referred last year are still with us. An article at page one of today's Australian Financial Review states:

Although it has begun the first major parliamentary session of the Labor Government by attacking the operations of the prices and incomes accord, the Opposition is still divided between adherence of a decentralised system and those who would like to develop an alternative centralised approach to that of the Government.
That appears despite what Senator Chaney has just said to us. The article goes on to refer to a joint meeting of the Liberal and National parties this morning. It states:
. . . the issue was sent to an all-party committee after no senior frontbencher could lay claim to there being an Opposition wages policy.

The scene is now set for months of manoeuvring between the decentralists, led by the Shadow Treasurer, Mr Howard, and the centralists, headed by Employment and Industrial Relations spokesman, Mr Ian Macphee.

The same people are leading the Opposition who, if they had continued in office, would have destroyed the unity of this nation. The same people are attempting to divide this country at present. The same people are guilty in the eyes of the Australian people.

In the last few days we have heard some excellent maiden speeches, particularly by Government senators. I am reminded of my maiden speech in the Senate, in which I quoted from the National Times. It is pertinent to contrast the Summit Conference and the record of the Fraser Government. The National Times, commenting on the August 1977 Budget of the Fraser Government and referring to Mr Fraser, stated:

He has set himself a target of sharply changing the balance of power in our society by diminishing the power of the unions and setting out to redistribute the national wealth up the salary scale to those whom he believes are the productive members of our society.

The National Times described the Budget as one that could 'endanger the stability of the country'. It went on to say that the Budget was a 'declaration of class war'. I believe that that particular quotation summed up the policies of the Fraser Government and once again pointed to the differences that exist between the Labor Government and the Government led by Mr Fraser. At the Summit the trade unions, for the first time in seven years, were drawn into that process. The trade unions can compare this experience with the decision making processes of the Fraser Government. There was no consultation under the Fraser Government when the Prices Justification Tribunal was emasculated; no consultation when $55 a month was added to home loan repayments; and no consultation when it slashed allocations to the States, forcing them to cut back on services. Another aspect is the situation of spouses of people involved in industrial disputes. The erosion of the social wage by the Fraser Government through cost increases in the health, welfare and education areas has cost families at least $30 a week. This was done by a Liberal government, the members of which talked-Liberal members probably still talk-about family life. No government did more to disrupt family life than did the Liberal-National Party coalition when it was in power. People suffered tremendously during that time. During the Summit speakers described the tremendous debit we now have with regard to unemployment and suffering in this country.

Not only the unions are concerned at present. The Summit demonstrated that there is a change of view throughout the business sector of this country. That is particularly so in the small business sector. This was reflected in the recent elections. In July last year a spokesman for the Bank of New South Wales, a significant conservative organisation in the community, stated:

Here in lies a great weakness in monetarism: It is not always apparent when to jump off the bandwagon of high interest rates. The problem of staying on board too long might already be evident in the United States.

That statement reflects one of our problems. The previous Government had a religious fervour for monetarism. There has been a public airing of arguments by the wets and the dries in the Liberal Party. But at the time of the election this year we had a dank, dismal mess. That is the inheritance the Government has received after seven years of Liberal-National Party Government. Of the speeches made by prominent business people at the Summit the problem was best summed up by the late Sir Keith Campbell. Referring to a significant view held by business people, he said:
