We agree that the Government's economic approach should now be based on a strategy to fight unemployment and inflation simultaneously. The economic and social implications of our unemployment are devastating. Clearly it must be the top priority of this Summit.

Sir Keith Campbell, speaking as a very respected businessman, summed up the acceptance of wide sections of business in Australia that there is a need not to follow the false policies of the Fraser Government that have created such hardships in this country, but to follow a balanced, sane policy. That is the program of the Australian Labor Party. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that almost every speaker at the Summit Conference emphasised the importance of unemployment as a social evil in this country. The speaker from the Australian Council of Social Service at the Summit Conference, to which Senator Chaney has just referred so properly in such favourable terms, was Mr Bruce McKenzie, who said:

The proper role of government in a democracy is to ensure equity and fairness through its political institutions and expenditure. The challenge to each of us here this week is to develop social and economic measures to ensure that all Australians have the opportunity to participate in our community.

That also sums up the change of style that is more than just the mood of the Press. The Australian people have had a change of style, reacting to a positive government in contrast to the seven dismal years of the Fraser Government. I must say that I have a preference for the trade union point of view that, at first, was so successfully put together with the Australian Labor Party, in the document which is the basis for this discussion. It is most important that we look at the broader range of issues, not just the wages and profit nexus. I refer to one of the contributions made at the Summit by my colleague Mr Fred Peterson from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and also a respected national official of the Clothing and Allied Trades Union. He pointed out something that I think is of concern to the Senate-that is, the severe structural problems in the Australian manufacturing industry. On behalf of the ACTU he proposed a number of remedies to the relative decline of traditional industries which is of great concern to me in my State and which, I believe, should be of concern to everybody in Australia because of the employment content of these industries. Mr Peterson referred to the erratic focus on tariff that we had under the Fraser Government. As I said earlier, we had plenty of statements, but absolute confusion in regard to the overall pattern that businessmen might expect to follow.

One of the complaints of business people in this country is that under the Fraser Government we did not have an agreed position. We did not have consistency or national industry. No State government or local government organisation could plan ahead because the Fraser Government was a government specialising in elections and in recession. It did very little else to help the Australian people except create an air of expectancy about the next election. Mr Peterson also referred to something that I believe needs great attention, that is, the need for an industry development policy with wide supports in this country. It is absolutely essential if we are to regenerate manufacturing industry in particular. I agree with the reference that he made on behalf of the ACTU to the need for a dynamic producer goods sector in our economy.

Once again I take the theme that Senator Chaney finished on when he referred to the need to consider the differences between the Summit Conference and what normally happens in Parliament. I remind honourable senators that at the Summit we did not hear what we heard for seven years from the previous Government, that is, that strikes are killing the country. That is the one-sided approach that has been the hallmark of the Liberal and National parties. They have blamed wage and salary earners for the crisis that has developed in this country. I would deal with this to remind people that the concentration on strikes by the Liberal Party over seven years presents a false picture when we set about to examine the problems of this nation because it does not even represent factually the hours that are lost from production in this country. I have said this before; nevertheless, it is still necessary to assert the other factors that cause the loss of man hours, person hours, or whatever the proper non-sexist word is for the time lost by the men and women of Australia because they are not able to work.

The reality is that individual industrial disputes are a minor problem. To begin with, lost production due to deaths and injuries on the job cost over $ 100m a year more in 1980-81-the last year I have figures for-than did industrial disputes. There were 300 deaths. I was very interested to hear the maiden speeches of two Labor senators because both referred to the loss of hours caused by strikes compared with the loss caused by industrial accidents. I have used these figures before but I refer to them again because they give Australia's problems their proper perspective. I refer to the estimated costs of strikes, unemployment, absenteeism, injuries and fatalities, in the year 1981-82. Industrial disputes were estimated to cost $403m. Injuries and deaths were estimated to cost $526m. absenteeism was properly estimated to cost $5,929m and the cost of unemployment, on the official statistics, was estimated at $9,713, 000,000. Industrial disputes represented 2.4 per cent of the time lost. Injuries and deaths represented 3.1 per cent, absenteeism represented a shocking 35.7 per cent and unemployment represented 58.6 per cent of man hours lost. The wastage caused by the number of people unemployed is the inheritance of the Labor Government from the Fraser Government. That is what we are setting out to change and what the Summit significantly set out to change. It is significant that one of the major issues we are concerned about arising from the Summit that the Government is acting on immediately is occupational health and safety, which I assert has been an area neglected by the Liberal and National parties. They have been completely obsessed with the emotive issue of trying to blame the individuals involved in industrial disputes for the crisis.

I refer to an example which has been used in other places. In changing the climate of debate, I think we have to look to the ways in which other countries deal with problems of making an arrangement with the trade union movement that is both principled and proper and understand how the trade union movement and the Australian people can participate and be more directly involved in the process of government. The Hawke Government has taken steps, as is very clear in the Senate chamber, to give more information to the people. The Summit was the first of a series of acts to demystify the position of government and to allow people to be involved in the process of government. I am interested in the experience of the Austrian Government because it is a country with vast numbers of people which has had a relatively stable situation for many years. It is significant that an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report makes the point that it is inconceivable that the Austrian Government would make decisions without consulting the partners in Austrian business. Even the reference to people being partners is in sharp contrast to the way in which the Australian trade unions over the seven years of the Fraser Government were neither consulted nor dealt with in such a way that they could reflect the views of their members and try to change the state of the nation.

I refer to some of the positive aspects of the ACTU accord with the Labor Party that I believe are most important for the Government to give priority. The ACTU accord contains the elements of an industry policy. One of our problems is that we need a national economic planning mechanism in which the prices and incomes structure has a defined role. We need, as is being proposed by the ACTU and the Government, an industry level sectoral council which will be fully integrated into a national economic planning structure with a reformed Australian manufacturing council. This will give meaning to councils. People will be able to have a say. I participated in the councils of the Fraser Government. They were one day jaunts. People throughout Australia went to meetings of councils with a small staff servicing them and at which very little could be done effectively. This is another change that the Hawke Government will bring about as it is aware of our need to have a proper industrial policy.

It is also proposed as a result of the ACTU accord that an appropriate tripartite consultation at specific industry level be conducted and developed over time. That is terribly important. It is in contrast with the piecemeal approach of the Fraser Government, an approach that was made worse by the procession of Ministers who had responsibility in the vital areas of industry development. In addition, it is proposed that corporate consultation on a tripartite basis will supplement the other machinery to ensure total consistency in the planning process. The planning mechanisms will reflect the priority decided upon through widespread consultation.

The Summit represents a qualitative change from the past. It represents a move to growth from the recessionary policies which were synonymous with the Fraser Government. I think it was well summed up by my colleague Senator Ryan in her contribution to the Conference in her capacity as Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. She said:

For many women and young people the recession arrived long before the more privileged sections of the community were aware of it. The threat-and the fact- of unemployment has been present for many of our young people and for women for almost a decade.

Senator Ryan was drawing attention to the fact that the Labor Party is aware of the suffering that has been occurring. At the Summit we recognised the existence of this suffering. We recognised that the reduction of unemployment and the creation of employment is a priority and have shown it in this symbolic way. I commend the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Ministers for doing that. We now move into a positive phase in Australia and we can soon bury the memory of the destructiveness of the Fraser era in Australian politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Childs, who has just resumed his seat, has not been here for very long and has forgotten how Australia squirmed under the Whitlam Government between 1972 and 1975. It is all very well to criticise the Fraser Government's efforts over the last seven years but I think it is fair to remind the Senate of the catastrophe that occurred under the mismanagement of the socialist Whitlam Government from 1972 to 1975. That big spending Government-the socialist Government-leaned upon Australia to such a degree that our inflation rate reached something like 18 per cent and unemployment levels reached a record height up to that time. I am always interested to hear members of the Australian Labor Party talk about deficits. Again, they forget that the Fraser Government inherited a deficit of about $4 billion from the Whitlam Administration and was able, over a considerable period , to reduce inflation to 9 per cent or a little less. It was able to bring Australia back on a quite significant course of development. A $9 billion deficit, if that is the figure-I am not quite sure what the accurate figure would be but that is what I have been led to believe--
—Go and ask Mr Howard.

—That is all right. The big spenders of the Labor Party were telling us when we were in government to increase the deficit. We increased the deficit last year. The Labor Party has forgotten that in November the Fraser Government provided the people of Australia with tax relief amounting to $1,570m and increased social welfare payments by about $1.2 billion. The Labor Party advocated big spending. We tried to relieve the tax pressures at the time, hoping that that would encourage people to spend more, buy Australian and so on, and thereby help our economic situation.
—What would $4 billion in 1975 mean in today's terms?

—That is the point. That 1975 figure of $4 billion, in Labor Party terms-it is the party of big spenders-would probably now be of the order of $15 billion. I would like members of the Labor Party to remember that over the next year or two, for as long as the Australian people are prepared to put up with their administration. They will witness the efforts of Mr Hawke, the new Prime Minister, who, when he was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, presided over the greatest number of strikes in Australia's history. His philosophy was: 'Grab what we want for the Australian workers by direct action. To hell with conciliation and arbitration'. I detected in the words of Senator Childs some disparagement of the idea that industrial disputation is insignificant in Australia. Certainly, the situation has improved . I want to refer now to the National Economic Summit Conference presided over by the new Prime Minister with his new look hair do. His performance at that time reminded me a little of a latter day political Liberace. Nevertheless, let us give him credit for the fact that he gathered many people together in the House of Representatives chamber to give them a chance to demonstrate their concern and put forward their views as to what ought to be done with respect to the Australian economic situation. Only three or four speakers at the Conference paid some attention to industrial disputation and the effect that it has on the economy. I do not think sufficient attention was paid to that matter. I heard the Queensland Premier mention it and I think Sir Roderick Carnegie made a passing reference to it. I believe that it is very important for the Government of Australia to recognise what demarcation disputes have done to wreck the confidence of our international partners and those countries which wish to trade with us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite incredible to me that a situation is allowed to persist whereby an argument between two waterfront unions in Australia can tie up our exports for three or four months. These disputes tie up the imports of goods from other countries and seriously jeopardise businesses and industries throughout this country. More particularly, it is quite incredible that we allow that situation to persist to such a degree that the Japanese Government is now turning to countries like Brazil, South Africa and Canada for their raw materials and for other goods that hitherto we were providing in far greater quantity. The people of countries such as South Korea are eating more and more meat. It is our fifth largest trading partner, the second largest in Asia, and it is now saying: 'We would love to buy all our meat and all our raw materials for our industrial development from Australia but we cannot rely on it'. So what happens? Japan is cutting down on its purchases of coal, iron ore and so on, and turning more and more to other countries. That is a disastrous situation, one that I think was understated at the Economic Summit Conference and one with which we have to come to grips.

I have said for 10 years that we ought to have an essential services Act. I drew the former Government's attention to the legislation that was introduced and invoked by the Queensland Premier with some success. I do not agree with all of the aspects of that legislation but at least the bones are there. At long last, after 10 years, the Fraser Government decided that it would introduce essential services legislation in the Parliament to protect the workers of Australia from irresponsibility in areas which could quite easily paralyse the nation. I refer to areas such as the petroleum industry, the power generating industry, communication and the waterfront. We, as a Commonwealth Government, have the powers, under section 51 of the Constitution, to take action and to introduce laws that will provide adequate protection not only for the industries in Australia and not only to ensure that our overseas trading is conducted with a minimum amount of disruption but also, more importantly, to protect the interests of the Australian workers. I might say that the Labor Party has no great record in the area of protecting the interests of the Australian workers. Any government that is worth its salt looks to the average citizens of Australia , the fair dinkum Aussie workers, to try to give them the support they need. I was upset that the Economic Summit Conference did not attempt to come to grips with that important question.

I agree with what Senator Childs said concerning industrial accidents. I think the honourable senator from Western Australia made a good speech regarding health hazards and so on in industry. I agree that governments have not come to grips with that important aspect and they should. I believe the Liberal Government should have to come to grips with that problem and I believe that the Labor Government ought to too. I will give any support I can to any moves that will attempt to prevent loss of work through industrial accidents and illnesses which are a result of the environment in which some workers have to work.

I think we have to look at the matter of industry unions in Australia. I did not think I would say that 10 years ago. But I recognise, having regard to the success of industrial relations in countries such as Japan and, perhaps, West Germany, that Australia could take some cognisance of that matter. We ought to reduce the number of trade unions in an attempt to overcome problems and to make easier communication and consultation with employers and the trade unions with respect to the conditions under which they work. I think the whole Conciliation and Arbitration Act ought to be scrapped. We ought to start again.

On one occasion I talked to one of the arbitration commissioners and I was quite vocal in my condemnation of the way demarcation disputes are allowed to affect the welfare of Australian workers not involved in a dispute. I think that is a responsibility the ACTU ought to adopt in the interests of our economic recovery. It ought to be the one to say what jobs a seaman and a merchantman guild member ought to do. I think that would be a constructive job that the ACTU Disputes Council could take up. Having made the judgments, having made the decisions and having solved the problems between the unions I think the unions then ought to go about their jobs and if there is any messing around from there on the laws of Australia should be made adequate to deal with them. The commissioner said to me: 'We cannot do anything with demarcation disputes because the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is insufficiently framed to give us the necessary powers to deal with them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's crazy.

—It is crazy. My colleague, Senator Kilgariff, agrees. I believe that we have a very important job to do in that area and I will continue to work to the best of my ability to see that something is done about it. I wish the Labor Party a lot of luck in recovering the lost ground that it claims the Fraser Government has caused. But as I said initially having regard to the successes we were able to achieve over those years, having regard to the deficit that was left to us by the Labor Party--
—It looks like petty cash compared with the one you are leaving behind.

—We should have regard to the international scene and the pressures that were brought upon us and to people such as Senator Walsh who is not going to do anything about developing our uranium industry. I will have a bit more to say about that matter at some other time. Senator Walsh might say that it is an uneconomic industry. That is a lot of nonsense. In one country alone-South Korea-there are three nuclear power stations and that country has a program to increase its numbers of nuclear power stations to about 14 over the next decade. There will be an increasing demand for that--
—Japan, an extra hundred.

—And Japan, an extra hundred. One can talk to people from Western Mining Corporation. They will say that we have to be in that area to provide ourselves with a future market. Even though the prices at the moment may seem to be a little lower than they were, they are going to be significant.
—Did Western Mining say that about Jabiluka too?
—You would not really understand the problem at all.
—Order! Senator Jessop, would you please address the Chair and, Senator Walsh, would you please stop interjecting like that?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your protection. I know you will protect me from the ravages of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) who is sitting opposite. I just want to point out that it is nonsense to suggest that the nuclear industry is uneconomic. I believe that the sooner we get stuck into that industry and provide certainly 30,000, 40,000 or 50,000 jobs-probably 100,000 jobs- the better. If the Government is going to honour the promise of providing 500,000 jobs within the next 12 months the sooner it gets into developing the uranium industry the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite refreshing to hear Senator Jessop, who has just resumed his seat, advocating at least a form of industrial democracy. I look forward to hearing his thoughts on this matter again when I hope it comes before the Senate for a full scale debate. I do not think the honourable senator is seriously saying that the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as a peak organisation, should tell its individual members what to do. But I do believe that at least the honourable senator is beginning to have a glimmer of understanding about the way in which workers should be consulted about their working conditions. I look forward to the day, and I am sure all my colleagues do, when it is possible for individuals to have that sort of control over their working conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that the Premier of Western Australia, the Honourable Brian Burke , made quite an impression at the National Economic Summit Conference. He has already been quoted by Senator Chaney. I would also like to quote Premier Burke who, on the second occasion he addressed the Summit, made reference to the fact that what he had been hearing from the employer representatives and other people who were themselves employers seemed to convey to him that they were advocating that Australian workers should be required to work double the hours they currently work for half the pay, that all penalty rates should be abolished and that Australia should seek economic recovery through flooding the Asian market with cheap manufactured goods.

I do not recall hearing anybody advocate, however-I sat through most of the Summit-that it would be desirable for Australian workers to possess the purchasing power of the average Korean or Malaysian. This points up what I believe to be a weakness in the position of almost every captain of industry who spoke at the Summit. I must observe that the content of much of what they said, if not the style, was very similar to what we have been hearing ad nauseam over the last seven years of Fraserism. There is a distinct tendency to tunnel vision , a luxury which is denied to the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to this Government and even to the voluntary organisations which were invited to participate or to observe at the Summit.

The industrialist who bemoaned the cost of labour generally-he was representative of many-and the cost of penalty rates in particular, will sell fewer car tyres, or whatever he happens to produce, if the incomes of his employees are reduced. In my State the tourist industry-it is quite a good example because, of course, it is another user of tyres-will be the first to suffer if workers in Western Australia lose their annual holiday loadings. The Confederation of Australian Industry in Western Australia is currently seeking, before the industrial commission in that State, to have this entitlement abolished from Western Australian awards. Some 90 per cent of travellers in Western Australia are Western Australians. The tourist trade, already in the doldrums, will be drastically affected if workers go on leave without that precious extra few dollars-in most cases much less than an extra week's pay.

The employers' case that more workers will be employed, by small businesses particularly, if holiday loadings are abolished is blown sky high when one calculates that one worker's annual wage will not be saved unless 70 workers lose their loadings in the year in question. It is surely obvious to the least sophisticated of economic analysists-amongst whom I count myself-that, unless demand is maintained or increased, money so saved by employers will not be used to employ more workers. Quite apart from considerations of equity and justice, the surest and quickest way in which to maintain and stimulate demand is to ensure that the householders with the lowest incomes maintain their purchasing power. The economists' argument is based on the fact that such households are forced to totally expend their incomes in order to purchase luxuries such as food, clothing and shelter-to quote my friend May Hobbs! High incomes, those about which the industrialists know best, are often invested here or overseas in ways which generate no employment except for accountants and corporate lawyers manipulating money markets and stock exchanges.

Very few women are in such positions or controlling such empires. The Summit meeting demonstrated clearly how poorly women are represented at the decision making levels of government, private industry and the trade union movement. Few people watching the Summit on television and seeing Jan Marsh with the ACTU delegation but not hearing her speak would know of her tremendous contribution to the ACTU's case. We assume that there were many such gifted women providing the research, ideas and logistical support for the industrialists and State government delegations. These women were unseen and unheard. At least our Government contributed the one woman speaker, Senator Ryan, whose performance, as outstanding as ever, could only marginally substitute for the vast amount of crucial information, based on the experience of 51 per cent of the population, which women are ready, able and willing to contribute to such a debate.

The two observing women's organisations-the National Council of Women and the Women's Electoral Lobby-represented women competently and appropriately but they were not invited to speak. The National Council of Women has decades of history and something like 600 organisations affiliated within Australia representing one million members, Australian women, and international affiliation to non- governmental organisations accredited with the United Nations organisation. The Women's Electoral Lobby-the other women's organisation at the Summit-which is just 11 years old, brings in a new generation and new initiatives which are bearing on old, entrenched problems. These groups and many others have seen some significant changes over the last decade, changes engendered principally in response to economic developments-the opportunities for women to begin to control their own and their families' security and destiny. This being the case, should not these women have contributed to the debate?

The Government has given early recognition to the place of women in Australian society by returning the Office of Women's Affairs to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. One of the first duties of this office, newly restored to its rightful position, was to prepare an excellent paper as background to the Summit. For those who are interested, this paper-I do recommend it strongly-is numbered NESC G1 addendum 2. I believe it is the definitive statement of March- April 1983 of the position of women in the Australian economy. The opening of this document makes these points:

1. This paper takes as its starting point the need to pursue economic recovery and equity simultaneously. If economic problems of the past are not to recur, recovery needs to be based on new and more productive activities and on maximisation of skills.

2. Women have the potential to contribute to economic recovery through participation in new high skill, high productivity enterprises and by enhancing the economic security of their families. Women's earnings, particularly in low income families, are essential to strengthening consumer demand.

As I pointed out earlier, these are the families who spend the whole of their pay packet every week; those are households, in Frank Crean's phrase, are one week's wage off destitution. The paper from the Office of Women's Affairs continues:

3. Unemployment and underemployment hamper women's ability to contribute: unemployment is higher for women than for men; many women working part-time would prefer full-time work; most of the hidden unemployed are women. Our segregated labour market confines a great many women to low paid, low skill, low productivity occupations often in sectors which are contracting in the face of new technology. Yet for women, as for men, marketable labour force skills are the best defence against poverty.

4. Labour market bias against women results in economic insecurity for them and their families. This lack of economic security will characterise any recovery not based on equity. It will also add to the welfare bill.
5. Measures to promote sustained economic recovery consequently need to be directed to improving women's contribution through paid employment.

Women's incomes in relation to men's have improved over the last decade but still women remain disadvantaged. Only about 25 per cent of women work full time and though women constitute a much greater percentage of the national labour force than that the rest are working part time. The average number of part time hours worked is 15 and the average award wage rate for women currently in Australia is in the vicinity of $5.50 an hour. In 1981 women received, on average, only 76c for every dollar earned by men. Wives of high income men are less likely to work than those of low income men. However, we all know of families where there are two incomes of doctors, two incomes of teachers, perhaps an income of a nurse and an income of an engineer. Those families are in the minority and in the vast majority of families where the wives are working the total incomes are low. There may be two or three incomes in those households but in very many cases they are insufficient to maintain a dignified standard of living. In the event that women did not work there would be all those extra families living in poverty. Those households in which the husband earns less than $10,000 per annum, on average, include wives whose income is highest as a percentage of the husband's-between 40 per cent and 70 per cent.

In 1981 60 per cent of pensioners and beneficiaries were women. In June 1981 women comprised 66 per cent of age pensioners, 100 per cent of widow pensioners- of course-31 per cent of invalid pensioners and 95 per cent of supporting parent beneficiaries. Women know how to make small incomes stretch to their utmost. Women should be consulted by governments and by organisations generally.

We have heard a little more lately than we usually do about international conventions. One has been attracting quite a lot of attention; that is, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. I was delighted to hear my colleague Senator Reynolds refer to it yesterday in her maiden speech, on which I congratulate her most sincerely. It is a very extensive convention. It is based on the Declaration on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women, which had its genesis in 1945 among the very first meetings of the United Nations. The Declaration was discussed internationally by women's organisations of all sorts. It has been advocated very clearly and very definitely by all non-governmental organisations associated with the United Nations. It culminated in a convention which was presented at the time of the mid-decade conference for women held in Copenhagen in July 1980, at which time a number of nations became signatories to Convention. The Convention will be ratified by Australia very soon, we hope. It goes to 50 Articles, as most conventions do, covering a great deal in its 50-odd Articles, but I draw one aspect to the attention of honourable senators. Article 7 of Part II states:

States Parties shall take all appropriate measures to eliminate discrimination against women in the political and public life of the country and, in particular , shall ensure to women, on equal terms with men, the right:
(a) To vote in all elections and public referenda and to be eligible for election to all publicly elected bodies;
(b) To participate in the formulation of government policy and the implementation thereof and to hold public office and perform all public functions at all levels of government . . .

I think that at the time of the Summit Conference the point was sufficiently made that this great deficiency existed and that women were not being consulted. It seemed to me, observing the Summit through the week, that that was a great tragedy. The opportunity was not being made available for an enormous amount of information about women's place in the Australian economy to be put before all those people attending, many of whom, I am sure, with the best will in the world , are completely unaware of the facts and figures which are included in this Summit document, which is only a precis of all the information that is currently available.

The final outcome of the Summit-its communique-made an impression upon women, and most of it was favourable. The women who observed the Conference for various organisations-not just women's organisations-were a great deal more aware, I believe, than most of the males and most of the members of the Press who were observing, of one part of the accord with the trade union movement which received very little discussion. That part is of absolutely crucial importance to women. referring which refers to the social wage. I should like very briefly to talk about some the ways in which awareness of the social wage changes the debate quite considerably from one which concentrates on wage rates, penalty rates, productivity, hours worked and the relationship of those elements to the level of the standard of living. For example, the introduction very soon of a universal medical insurance scheme will make a great deal of difference to the incomes of many households in this land. One element which has created more hardship than any other over the last few years, I believe, is the necessity for a family with children-people at risk-to take out private insurance for their medical and hospital benefits. Medicare will be of great assistance to the low income families to whom I referred earlier.

The ability for women, particularly, to be retrained in order to seek employment to maintain their sense of security, the standard of living for their families, their own skills and their own contribution society is absolutely crucial. The availability of good quality community-based low-cost child care is of crucial importance to this society and to those women to whom I have referred who seek to be independent or at least to add to the standard of living for their families. The cost of housing, a matter about which the Government is very determined to take prompt and effective action, is of crucial importance. Also, the adequacy of housing, the size of houses, the siting of houses and the planning of housing and communities are of crucial importance. These are matters that the trade union movement looks to the Government to implement so that the actual wage-the actual amount in the weekly pay packet-is not the only determinant of the standard at which a family is able to maintain itself.

In summarising what happened at the Conference the women commented that they welcomed the return to centralised wage fixation, which protects the workers with the least bargaining power, amongst whom women predominate. They commented that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should be encouraged by all parties to use every opportunity of eradicating inequalities in rates for women's and men's jobs.

Mr Deputy President, I think most of us are now aware of the fact that there is technically-theoretically, perhaps I should say-equal pay for work of equal value in Australia. But in practice this is not so when the work that women customarily do is valued much more lowly than the work which men do. To make comparisons between the value of jobs that women and men customarily do apparently has been too difficult to be tackled. When we see the worker with the skills required, say, to be employed in a child care centre and the worker, say, employed to work on a road gang putting down bitumen and we are able to compare the value of those two jobs, I know which in my book would be valued more highly . I also know which is currently valued more highly and who of those two workers has the opportunity for overtime and shift penalties and has the greater job security.

The women at the Conference deplored any suggestion of a blanket extension of the wages pause which would further harm low wage workers, the majority of whom are women. At the time the wages pause was introduced a number of awards were lagging quite badly behind the increase which had flowed from the transport workers' increase, or the metal workers' increase, or whoever got there first. Guess who were the last on the line and who did not receive that $14 or $19? In effect, the wage pause for these people is just an extension of this wage cut, and that is how it has affected these workers. It is sincerely hoped that the Prices Surveillance Authority promised by the Government will have significant effects on the maintenance of living standards. In accordance with the stated aims of this Government, we hope that women will be represented on this authority.

We also sincerely hope that the Economic Planning Advisory Council, which is currently being developed, will include women. We hope that the groups which have been promised places on that Council-the trade unions, consumers, governments and the welfare sector-will ensure that women are included in all their delegations. In addition, we believe that a place should be established on EPAC for at least one woman who has expertise on issues affecting the position of women in the paid work force, in the home, in the community and in the taxation and welfare systems. If honourable senators think that is a tall order I know a dozen women who could do it very easily. I think women generally have welcomed the commitment to significant government expenditure on job creation schemes in community and capital works programs. We hope that women of all ages will be given equal access to job and training opportunities in both areas. Once again, we have the comfort of the policy of the ALP and the awareness of our Ministers. We believe that private employers involved in both job creation and growth should be requested to adhere to the same principles of equality of opportunity. We look forward to the introduction of anti-discrimination legislation which, in the majority of cases, will make this mandatory.

It was suggested that funding priority should be given to community services which have the capacity to provide economic stimulus to depressed regions, improve the quality of life and contribute to the social wage. An example of how this can be done is where a regional centre needs child care facilities. This may in the first instance require a new building. It will need to be staffed and maintained. The people who work in that facility will be spending their wages in that area. The women who are able to have their children cared for, in many cases will take the opportunity to retrain and further their education. The level of education and the standard of living in that area will be enhanced in dozens of different ways.

There was considerable discussion at the Summit and prior to the Summit, about the fact that some Australians were having problems in tolerating the needs of the disadvantaged in the sense that amounts that were being allocated by Australian governments for social security payments of various sorts were really reaching extraordinary heights. In a speech which was extremely well accepted by the voluntary organisations and many others at the Summit, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, showed that Australia is comparatively miserly in expenditure on social welfare. Our social welfare expenditure, as a proportion of gross domestic product, places us fourteenth amongst the 17 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. I, and others who think as I do, do not consider that Australian society has any genuine problem in meeting the needs of the disadvantaged. In fact we believe that very many people would be quite happy to see more of their tax dollar go to alleviating the very real disadvantage that increasingly we see around us every day. We felt that it was a very encouraging sign to see discussion taking place about the relationship between the provision of public sector services and taxation levels. I believe also that many people would welcome a genuinely progressive taxation system which increased the quantum of public funds necessary for economic recovery.
Clause 43 of the Summit communique states:

Given the high levels of unemployment the Summit agrees that the basic rights of women should be recognised and protected and that the move towards greater equality and independence for women should be encouraged. There should be equal access to job creation programs, to employment, training, retraining and education and measures designed to break down occupational segregation and discrimination.

I believe that this will be one of the high priorities of the Australian Labor Government. The initiatives that are now under way are palpable evidence that the Hawke Government is moving along the correct road to achieving, in the long run, economic recovery for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a danger for those who wish to discuss a media love-in like the National Economic Summit Conference in that if one points out what was not covered and what problems are left behind if one is not careful one sounds like a worthy citizen lecturing a lynch mob on the merits of trial by jury. To avoid any possibility of that happening I would like to start by referring to what good came out of the Summit. There were many good aspects. It would by churlish of us not to say so. The first thing-perhaps in some ways the most important-was the getting together of government, employers and unions over a period of four days to get to know one another. This can do nothing but good for our future economic relations. The possibility of problems being solved by a personal telephone call rather than a confrontation in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with lawyers present can do nothing but improve the possibility of better industrial relations in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Summit also saw-I think it was accepted by all-the tight linkage between wage increases, unemployment and inflation. That is a very important acceptance, if the acceptance is genuine. There was also an agreement-I think a very proper one-that the wages pause not only should apply to wage earners but also should cover salaries, dividends, directors' and professional fees. That is also proper . It is quite unreasonable to expect one section of the community alone to bear the whole brunt of an economic restraint policy. There was also agreement to return to centralised wage fixing. I think that was inevitable but there are dangers and problems there-a point I will come to in a moment.

I think it was also agreed-it was fairly clear-that we must tackle unemployment and inflation together. I think that is right. For structural reasons in this country-although in theory it works-in practice if one tries to tackle inflation , the power of the monopolistic unions can force wage increases out of the community when they are in no way justified by the profitability of the business concerned. That makes difficult any attempt to tackle inflation and unemployment merely by control of the money supply. We have to tackle wages, unemployment and inflation as a package. Recognition and acceptance of that-if there be acceptance-is very important for the future of this country.

I deal now with the amount of information that the Summit put out. That was good. I wish that we in government had done more of it ourselves. The scenarios of the consequences of various movements in wages and so on are the sort of information that other countries customarily provide their management and unions . I think we should have done it in the past. I am glad that the Government did it at the Summit and I hope that it will keep on doing it. Finally, there was a general community awareness of the difficulties that we are in and the problems we have to face-difficulties caused by the simultaneous collapse of the three props of our economy: The first was the collapse of primary industry, through drought. This has now fortunately been largely relieved although it will be some time before farm incomes are back to a reasonable level. The second was the collapse of commodity prices around the world, which caused great difficulties for our mining industries in particular. The third was the very great loss in our manufacturing industry because of the explosion of wages regardless of the profitability of the manufacturing firms that pay them. These three things happened together and they have caused serious damage to our economy. It will take a national united effort to overcome these problems. They are the good things that came out of the National Economic Conference.

I should like to turn now to some of the problems. The first point I wish to raise is that it was not, in any sense, a representative gathering. It was representative of big government, big unions and big business. The Conference cannot and must not be allowed to assume the role of this Parliament. Acquiescence in policies by that group must not be a substitute for acceptance by Parliament. This type of rule by sectional interests-big government, big unions and big business-was the centrepiece of fascism. That is what fascism was . We must never allow that sort of group to take over the role of Parliament. At that Summit Conference where were the women? Where were the handicapped? Where were the pensioners? Where were the unemployed? Where were those interested in national defence? Where were the Aborigines? Where were the migrants? Where were the consumers? Either they were not represented at all or there was only token representation. We must never accept the idea that a meeting of powerful groups in the community is in any way a substitute for a national parliament. As one example of the way in which agreement between powerful groups can damage the community and damage unemployment prospects let us look at the effects of penalty rates. I was interested to note that Senator Giles, touched on this in her speech, but she did not seem to grasp the problem at all. The fact is that penalty rates destroy jobs.

I remember that I raised this matter a few years ago with a managing director of a big firm which owned hotels and motels. He said that he had done a calculation and had found that if all penalty rates were abolished it would only reduce the cost of a room by 60c. I said that I was not the slightest bit surprised. I was surprised that the amount was so high. I had stayed in its motels a number of times and as far as I am aware they provide no out of hours services of any description. The reason they do not is that they cannot economically afford to do so. The jobs of people who might have provided out of hours services, weekend meals, late night suppers and that sort of thing, had all been destroyed. The other point I must make here is that this is a cosy deal between the employers and the unions. Employers do not mind having to pay penalty rates; they do not have to pay them if they do not provide the services and they do not as long as their rivals cannot provide them either. There is a cosy deal between management and unions. The deal provides benefits for those in work at the expense of those people who are not in work. That is the danger of this type of Summit, representing sectional interests rather than the interests of the whole community.

There was a very skilful presentation was made at this Conference. I must say that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did a superb job. He called on the Australian Council of Trade Unions as the representative of the employees, the workers. He called on the senior people in the ACTU to speak on behalf of the whole trade union movement. Admittedly, so far as employers were concerned, he invited representative employer groups. He also invited 14 other individuals and he nominated them to speak. Naturally they gave an impression of differences of emphasis and, in some cases, differences of principle whereas the union movement gave an impresson of agreement and solidarity. That was not a true impression. One only has to look at what has happened since the Summit. I have a report of a recent remark by Mr Gallagher, who was present at the Summit but who was certainly not called upon to speak. Mr Gallagher said: 'It does is show people where Hawke stands, right alongside the employers'. I find that remark of Mr Gallagher's very surprising, by the way. He said that no one should be surprised about that. Mr Gallagher described Mr Hawke as a kid playing with matches and said that his comments would not thwart the shorter hours campaign in the long run. Mr Gallagher said that he noticed that Mr Hawke never said that prior to the election and that 'even now he only says it in the coward's castle'. I take it that he was referring to Parliament. Another participant, Mr Ivan Hodgson of the Transport Workers Union, said: 'I do not recall agreeing to wage restraint at the Summit'. He went on to describe the Summit as a public relations exercise . I agree with Mr Hodgson in part but I do not like his statement that he did not recall agreeing to wage restraint. The point I am trying to make is that at the Summit, through good stage management, the union movement appeared to be united. The ACTU appeared to be in control. We know-I hope the public now knows if it did not know before-that that is a total misrepresentation of the true situation. The ACTU is a toothless tiger.

What was not considered at the Summit in any detail? The first thing that was not considered with any sympathy was the situation of the unemployed. Certainly some comments were made about the seriousness of the problem. But the scenario adopted by the Government and the trade union movement in relation to future wages policy-despite the disagreement of the employers-promised no improvement whatever in the rate of unemployment in the next three years. One scenario; the so called Scenario C, which imposed a very high degree of wage restraint, was the only scenario which showed a reasonable growth and a reduction in unemployment. That scenario was implicitly rejected by the Government and the trade union movement. If we are going to get anywhere in solving our economic problems we must recognise that the 90 per cent of people who are in employment must make some sacrifices-they will be temporary sacrifices but they must make them-in order to provide a reasonable chance for the 10 per cent of the people who are out of work to gain employment. That was a clear failure of the Conference. It was supposed to be about jobs, jobs, jobs but it never really tackled seriously the problem of how these jobs are to be provided.

The second matter which received no consideration at the Summit, although one would have thought it was very relevant to a national economic summit conference , was the effect of industrial disputes on our economy. We are a great overseas trading nation. More of our gross domestic product goes in overseas trade than, for instance, is the case in Japan, which is a country that we usually think of as being very dependent on overseas trade. The effect of our strike record on our overseas trade is nothing short of catastrophic. We are universally regarded as an unreliable supplier. When options are offered people do not buy from unreliable suppliers. Senator Childs quote some statistics which were curious, to put it mildly. One of the problems with these sorts of statistics is that, for example, a strike of key workers in transport or in power generation might appear as 100 man days lost-10 men on strike for 10 days. But the consequence of that strike might be that a whole industry or a whole State is brought to a standstill. What has to be looked at when dealing with industrial relations is this: What is the consequent effect on the Australian economy? I think that anyone who pretends that the results are not serious is deluding himself.

There was no consideration at the Summit of the impact of technological change. Technological change is hitting us now. I will give the Senate one example. In 1954 the proportion of the work force which was in primary industry was 15 per cent. It is now 8 per cent. That figure probably has plateaued. In 1954 the proportion of the work force in manufacturing industry was 39 per cent. It is now 27.5 per cent and inevitably will fall further. We must not look at the problem of trying to prop up employment in manufacturing industry because we will not do it. We must look at how these people can properly and usefully be absorbed into tertiary industry.

One of the problems we have to tackle-among many other probems-is penalty rates . No consideration was given at the Conference to non-wage costs-the effect of workers' compensation, payroll tax, holiday pay and so on. All these things impose nearly as much cost on employers as the wages themselves. At present the Builders Labourers Federation wants a wage increase of $40. It says that it will forgo a wage increase of $40 in favour of a site allowance of $40 a week. This sort of manipulation of our system and the very high on-costs we have is a real deterrent to our economy and to our employment. There was no consideration of what has been happening to profits in recent years. Profits as a percentage of the gross non-farm product were 15 per cent in 1980, which is probably about right. They are now down to under 12 per cent, a drop of at least 25 per cent. This is disastrous for new investment. From new investment comes manufacturing efficiency and from manufacturing efficiency come new jobs.

We must, as a matter of urgency, get profits back to a realistic level. This was not tackled at all at the National Economic Summit Conference. Worst of all, there was no real agreement on wages. The employers-perhaps rather weakly-agreed to return to centralised wage fixing. I do not think in practice they had much alternative, but for this agreement they extracted no promises as to what should be done to make centralised wage fixing work properly. Centralised wage fixing by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was what got us into our problem in the first place. If we are going to go back to it we must see that we do not gallop over the old battlefield again. We must get some parameters to make it work properly. The Summit, on all the key issues about wages, merely agreed to refer them back to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There was no agreement, for instance, on how long the pay pause should last, though the only scenario that showed the possibility of a reduction in unemployment suggested that the pay pause should last well into the next year. It is evident that it will end in some way later this year. But there was no agreement at the Summit on that issue. There was no agreement on the method of indexation of wages-not only what proportion of indexation one gets, but also who decides what the index is.

There are many justified criticisms-I have not got time to go through them now- of the consumer price index as an appropriate index for the adjustment of wages. That was not tackled. It should have been. But most important of all, there was no discussion of what one did about comparative wage justice and the flow-on, whereby enormous damage has been done to our economy. Powerful unions, perhaps in the oil industry, pick on one industry which can afford to pay and then what they have managed to gouge out flows right across the whole industry to all sorts of areas which cannot afford to pay. This is a key area in any system of centralised wage fixing. It was not tackled at all at the Summit. The really important thing for this Government is how it speaks at the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission when these matters are decided and what it says. If it wishes to be regarded as an honourable and respectable government it must not speak on behalf of the trade unions alone. It must speak for the whole community . That is vital to our economic recovery and I suggest to the survival and prestige of this Government.

To return to my first point, there is no doubt at all that the Economic Summit was a public relations success. Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, was an extremely successful entrepreneur of that Summit. As someone has said, across the distance of war he is doing fairly well. He has ditched all promises he made during the election campaign, which is exactly the technique used by Mr Wran in New South Wales and Mr Cain in Victoria. Mr Cain in fact kept one promise which was very unwise-he ditched all the others. This seems to be a standard technique and insofar as nearly all the promises were damaging or foolish I think that is definitely an improvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —We may have medicare.

—We have not got it yet. I am talking about what the Prime Minister has done so far and not what he will do in the future. That is a really different issue. He has also implemented planned increased benefits for the unemployed. I think he deserves credit for that. He has walked back as fast as he possibly can on the subjects of East Timor and Vietnam. I think as soon as he can he will walk back on uranium mining. These are all improvements. This shows that he has some wisdom. I do not know how long he will be able to get away with that. He is now very worried about the size of the deficit and very properly so. But while he and his party were in opposition they were always urging us for a bigger deficit. Now at least they have realised, I hope, the consequence of it and they have set up their own razor gang to prune government expenditure. That is all good. In fact, if one looks at what he has done so far-not at what he is doing in the future-one sees that he has been behaving rather like a Liberal Prime Minister. I hope he does not follow-I do not mind if he does, I suppose- the lines of Mr Lyons and Mr Hughes, two former Labor Prime Ministers who found their associates intolerable and left them and joined us, but that might happen.
—Would you have him?

—I do not know. We will have to think about that. It is not my decision anyway. My point is that so far in what he has done it is difficult to find much to which to object. The Economic Summit was, on the whole, quite a success. I do not think the left wing of his party will be able to continue carrying on like this. We will find much to criticise-much doctrinaire work will come from him. What I think he will stand or fall by will be what attitude he or his Government takes before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which will decide the essential future of the wage system in this country. The attitude taken by the Government will be crucial. I hope on that occasion it will speak for Australia and not for a sectional group. If it speaks for Australia he will have our support. I do not think it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded of a situation which has developed over 20, 30 or 40 years unchecked as a result of the philosophy and a style of government which this country came to accept as the normal. This was the Menzies style of government, the laissez-faire style which is known these days as the lay-back style-just let everything happen, no planning, no real co-ordination, no indications to commerce or industry as to which direction the nation is likely to take or that the Government would like it to take, but just allow things to eventuate as they will. Of course we are very fortunate because our destiny was determined by the great wealth and riches which were part of this land when we first came to it.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the 1960s and early 1970s things started to go a little bit haywire. The Government was changed and a Labor government came into power with all of the instant solutions that it felt this country needed. It endeavoured to apply those instant solutions immediately again without any real consideration for long term planning but rather just to move into trouble spots and try to resolve those trouble spots with no consideration for the long term or even medium term impact of the solutions that it was applying. Many of those solutions turned out to be band-aids which peeled off pretty quickly.

As a result of those two styles of government we entered into the 1970s which brought with it great economic problems for the whole world and not least of all for this nation. As a result of everybody then searching for scapegoats, we were to become a nation torn apart, a nation which was led by people with political objectives and very little else. We survived the 1970s. We barely looked like surviving the 1980s until there arrived on the scene either a brilliant politician even surpassing the mastery of his predecessor the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, or a great statesman. We are not too sure which of those he is. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is a great leader in prospect, provided he matches the reputation which he has set for himself in the media and in this Parliament up until now. I said 'in this Parliament' because his greatest performance to date was in this Parliament but at the National Economic Summit Conference conducted in this Parliament. But let us give credit at this stage because I think it is too early to criticise the potential output of that Economic Summit and its consequences. Let us acknowledge that it has the potential to be the first step towards the reconciliation of this nation and towards bringing the warring parties together. The parties which had been driven apart for political expediency were at last brought at least into the one arena with the one agenda and with the one common objective-to rescue us from the potential economic morass into which we were about to sink. It is fair to suggest that the Chairman of that Summit, the Prime Minister, made consensus seekers out of historic enemies. They sought solutions for the nation and not just for themselves, as had been the practice of most of the participants. They reached understanding and an awareness of each other's problems. The result was that the concept was condoned; a concept, I remind honourable senators, which was envisaged by Senator Chipp-and not by him alone-with remarkable foresight. When discussing the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill he said that the Government should take urgent and comprehensive measures to stimulate the economy, restrict imports and call a national conference to begin the process of long term co- operative indicative planning. This is the mark of that Conference. It has established a climate which will allow long term indicative planning to come about. Of course, that was anathema to previous governments, which felt that they had to clasp to their bosoms the forecasts and the actual situation of the economy and not reveal it to anybody outside the Parliament or the Government.

I would like to refer specifically to the contribution made by the Confederation of Small Business Organisations of Australia which, despite Senator Teague's reference yesterday to the absence of any representation by the small business sector of the economy, was represented by Mr Don Gibbons. I believe he made a very valuable contribution not just to the debate but to the whole process. The group he represented reflected probably one of the broadest cross-sections of the Australian community. Small businesses are not just one industry group, one commercial group, one sector of professionals or one sector of employers or employees; they consist of not just men, not just women and not just young people. The whole broad spectrum of people concerned with the productivity of this nation is represented by the small business sector. I believe, therefore, that Mr Don Gibbons represented the view of probably the widest cross-section of people in this nation.

Let me just refer to a few points made by Mr Gibbons and comment on some of them, because I believe they need to be highlighted. He said that his Confederation accepted the need for wage stability, wage predictability and wage adjustments related to productivity and to the real consumer price index, and he even hinted that automatic indexation based on an agreed formula would be acceptable. I suggest that it would be appropriate for us to look at plateau indexation, because it is obvious that all of us will have to tighten our belts; and those who can most afford to pull in their belts a couple of notches should be the people who make the greatest sacrifice at this stage.

I suggest further, whilst looking at the overall economy, that one of the great beneficiaries of a surge in consumer demand would be the small business sector and that there is a need to stimulate consumer demand to get that surge going through the purchasers, the consumers. That is the greatest need for small businesses. There is not much point saving a few cents here and maybe a dollar or two there in costs if at the end of the line nobody has a dollar in his fist ready to purchase the goods or the services. It would be a stimulus not just to small business but to the whole economy. Mr Gibbons also made reference to an acknowledged need to stabilise wages and prices. Certainly he referred to the need for a sunset clause in any such surveillance system, but there is no doubt that there was acquiescence in some compromise, some solution, which said: 'We are prepared to pull our weight provided everybody else in the economy will do the same'. There was a recognition of the need for pump priming even though it would lead to a heavy Budget deficit; and in the short term this was considered to be acceptable.

I would like to touch briefly on the self-expressed need for the small business sector in particular-although this was not said by Mr Gibbons, I believe the inference is there-and the large business sector as well to embark on a massive upgrading of their management skills. I think this has to start from the top. As a management consultant, I can assure honourable senators that the day has gone when top management imposed management training of junior executives in the hope that something would happen. Management training is desperately needed at the top, particularly in medium sized companies-companies which have grown out of a family enterprise, where the original entrepreneur, developer or builder of the company has outgrown his or her capacity and needs management training either at his or at the next management level. The acceptance of that need for management training is paramount because to send people to a training program and then to let them try to survive the old management processes which are endemic in an organisation is no way to go about the task of getting management upgraded. I am certainly conscious that most executives today, particularly those at the top- the entrepreneurs and the proprietors-are working 60 and 70 hours a week. However, they need to find a few more hours in which to upgrade their skills so that they may increase productivity, increase the job satisfaction of the people who are working with them, increase output and help to improve the environment in which people live.

Let me touch again on a couple of factors that the Confederation of Small Business Organisations referred to. They are pointers which, if this Government is willing to take them on board, can give a fairly rapid injection into the economy, which would result in a stimulus going probably right across the board. I will suggest a couple: Getting rid of restraints on tourism would be almost as easy as the stroke of a pen. Just a couple of changes to awards and to regulations would make it possible to inject a real boost into the tourist industry. I do not mean that we should hit the tourist industry by getting rid of penalty rates; rather, let us get behind the tourist industry which obviously knows its problems far better than this Government-or any government. Let us help to develop that industry which has the greatest and fastest potential for growth in this nation.

Let us inject funds into the housing industry, but let it be on a planned basis . What the housing industry suffers from almost as much as it suffers from high interest rates and the difficulties that arise from constraints on the economy at the moment is the shocking record of planning for the housing industry that this nation had had over decades. The housing industry is the first to acknowledge that point. It may not accept the responsibility or blame for it, but it certainly recognises that the peaks and troughs that come about through bad planning or lack of planning serve no useful purpose. The peaks bring into the industry the riff raff, the ratbags, who destroy the reputation of the industry and make it virtually impossible for people to survive in it. Of course , the troughs result in the very good people-the excellent tradesmen, the good managers and the good builders-moving out of the industry. They do not have to live in it-they can move into alternative industries. Better planning and a more even economic approach, and more even stimulus to the housing industry in particular, would make a huge difference, not just to the short term but to the long term economic future of the industry and the nation.

It has been said before-I am not ashamed to say it again-that one of the ways that this Government, with an injection of funds, could create instant employment is to decentralise employment opportunities, in particular through local governments. I know a few people will shudder at the mention of the Regional Employment Development scheme. The thought of revisiting the REA scheme is anathema to some people. But I am not afraid to suggest that there were great virtues and benefits in the RED scheme. In my opinion, the RED scheme, properly managed and handled, even now could be of benefit to this nation. I believe it is that type of program which could give an instant stimulus to the economy. One of the difficulties, as expressed by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, is the over-regulation for individual enterprises and, in particular, the effect that has on their competitiveness. I stress again, as I did yesterday, the effect that this has on small businesses, compared with large businesses.

One of the great, thriving industries in this nation is the lobby industry. I have said in public previously, and maintain, that if the skills, the persuasive abilities, of the people in the lobby industry were converted to marketing and exporting our goods overseas the country would be far better off. But instead of using their persuasive and marketing skills to persuade others to purchase our goods, much of this skill is used here in Canberra to try to persuade governments to provide added protection, benefits and relief which allow companies to compete unfairly with others. One of the things that small business would love to see would be a gradual whittling away of the regulatory controls established by all levels of government and statutory organisations on small business enterprises.

I will touch on one aspect of the National Economic Summit Conference which came through as great initiative which was embraced by all and which has been a plank in the platform of the Australian Democrats, literally since the day we were formed. I am delighted to say that it was the subject of the very first policy paper which was agreed to by our members. I believe that was so primarily because of the inclusion of this factor: The need for this country, led by this Government, to have long term indicative planning, not just for itself but for all organisations-industrial, commercial and every other kind of organisation and enterprise in this country.

We have barely survived without long term indicative planning. We need it now, not just for economic recovery but because we are entering, economically, the great unknown. We are entering into an economic future for which there are no precedents. All of the economic gurus of the world, from Friedman through to Galbraith today, are unaware of the path that is likely to be successful for any government from now on. It is difficult enough for those who manage and direct our enterprises in this nation, but if the limited information that is available is hidden from those decision makers at the top of commerce and industry, it becomes an impossible task for them to plan.

I am delighted that the proposal for the Economic Planning Advisory Council has come forward. It needs to be expanded, but it should not be given more than it can digest at stage one. We would like to come forward some time later this year with some expansion proposals for that body or perhaps for an alternative organisation which could go beyond the terms of reference of EPAC. I guess the reason that this needs to be stressed now is the shudder that went through me and many other concerned Australians when it was learned that one of the significant Ministers in this new Government was denied an opportunity to present a paper which will have a significant impact on the future of this nation. I refer, of course, to the paper which was to be presented by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, and which was denied an airing at the Summit Conference. As far as I can gather, his paper has been buried by the Cabinet and it is still hiding it.

That is tragic because if all we are going to do is to solve the problems we have today with solutions which will last a few weeks or months, that is no long term solution which will benefit this nation; that is likely to lead us into even more dangerous areas. I hope that very shortly the Government releases the paper that was to be presented by the Minister, Barry Jones, and allows the whole nation to see some of the problems that lie ahead. I am quite sure, having heard the Minister speak on many occasions, that he offered potential solutions for the long term problems.

Other items of great concern to the Australian Democrats, and I think to most people, came out of the Summit Conference. They include an agreement by most parties, certainly by those representing small business-this came out as part of the communique-that artificial schemes for tax avoidance and evasion must be removed. This is a great step forward because out of that group of representatives of many significant areas of this nation a change of attitude towards tax avoidance as well as tax evasion evolved. The change of attitude arising out of the communique and conference notes, as I read them, has been this: Let us stop this game of tax avoidance. Let us recognise that the tax avoider is not a smart operator, somebody whose skills should be admired, somebody that one condones or somebody whose advertisements in the Australian Financial Review one looks at a couple of times and wonders whether one will get in touch with that person to help one a little bit. Tax avoidance is now considered by most people in Australia to be anathema.

I believe that we have changed from what was for decades, if not centuries, the attitude of the people of France, that how to avoid or evade, whichever one prefers, paying one's taxes, which one is entitled to meet, was the great sport of the nation. A new Australian attitude recognises that if one steals a dollar in tax avoidance one is stealing it from one's next door neighbour, from somebody who is unemployed or from somebody who is less able to cope than oneself. The thieves in this game are the people who can afford to pay tax. They are stealing it from those who cannot afford to pay. I think that the people of Australia have woken up to that principle and are now willing to say, 'Right, let's get hold of these people and not only make them pay their taxes but also treat them for what they are. They are criminals. They are stealing from others who cannot afford to lose these benefits.'

I believe that the agreement by the Summit to improve the equity and efficiency of the Australian taxation system is, again, indicative of the attitude of all parties that it is no longer acceptable to deny officers, staff and facilities to the Australian Taxation Office and regard tax as something which does not really count. We have seen the evidence that a few millions spent in the Taxation Office can bring to the Government hundreds of millions, if not thousands of millions, in tax revenue which would otherwise have been avoided. That is an investment which everybody now recognises is justifiable.

Senator Giles touched on the reference in the communique to the need for us all to give to women basic rights, recognition, protection and to move towards greater equality and independence for women. I simply endorse both the reference in the communique and the comments made by Senator Giles who, in my home State, is recognised as a champion of women's rights. I believe that we will see a revolution in the Parliament as a result of the increasing representation of women, a revolution not just for women's rights but for the rights of all people who until now have been denied equal opportunities. It becomes a very significant factor when included in that group is just over 50 per cent of the whole population of the country.

The other group which has been denied and is still being denied not only representation but also economic wellbeing is the young people of this country. They are the ones who have copped it as a result of the economic decline. They have become the scapegoats. It is a very sad reflection on the Parliament and the people who have put down the policies which have allowed the greatest unemployment to occur amongst the young, and as a result, to bring about the potential for a whole generation of young people growing up disenchanted not only with the nation, the economy and the system but also with their own peers, some of whom have jobs, others who are unable to get jobs.
