As was suggested at the Economic Summit Conference we need imaginative policies and programs based on the involvement of young people at all levels of the community, not just moves that are imposed on them. We should confer with young people and not just the employed or the sons and daughters of people who are fortunate and who are able to articulate easily. We need to have the patience and the understanding to talk to those who have been denied educational opportunities and who are currently the real sufferers of our economic decline. That takes patience and tolerance which I hope this Government is willing to exercise.

Finally, I touch briefly on the need expressed at the Summit Conference for educational training and retraining for the nation's present and future wellbeing. This is an urgent need and will obviously result in long term benefits above all else as it takes hold of the great investment in the greatest resource that this country has-our people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a report in the Canberra Times today. I would have raised this issue in Question Time if circumstances had allowed me the call. There is not a great deal I want to say. I raise this issue in order to obtain some indication by the Government of whether it has been drawn to the Government's attention and whether it has any thoughts on the matter. The front page article in the Canberra Times has a caption reading, ' Memorial dome to be blocked'. There was a series of photographs with the story of present views of and from the Australian War Memorial and pictures of a model of some proposed alterations to the entrance foyer and the effect they would have. I think everybody would agree that the Australian War Memorial is one of the best regarded buildings in Australia and, for the many tourists who come to Canberra, one of the great impacts of Canberra is the view of the War Memorial from Parliament House and vice versa. Not only are they good views, but also there is a very symbolic linking of those two buildings. I think many people have quite profound thoughts on the subjects of war, democracy and parliament when they visit either of those buildings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian War Memorial is, of course, an extremely meaningful building. Its design is very particular and a very special one in Australia. The great feature of it is the Hall of Memory which has a large and very splendid dome which, as one approaches the Memorial, appears to be framed between two pillars. The story in today's newspaper points out that it is proposed that the facade of the entrance be substantially raised by building a new foyer on to the building. The effect of this will be to block the view of the part of the Hall of Memory one sees from outside and the dome as one approaches the War Memorial. Another effect will be to block completely from inside the vista across to both this Parliament House and the new one under construction. I am sure that many Australians and, in particular, many Canberrans, will feel very concerned about this.

I visited the War Memorial this morning to see the plans and to discuss why they were necessary. Without doubt there is a need at the Memorial for a new foyer and the facilities that will go with it, such as information services, a new bookshop and some other facilities. However, the structure that is to be built is extremely high. It is to be made entirely of glass but at this stage it is not clear what sort of glass will be used. Whilst there is a suggestion that from the Hall of Memory one will be able to see through the glass to Parliament House and still have that extremely symbolic vista linking the two buildings, I doubt that that is very likely. I had hoped in Question Time today to ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, who represents the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in this chamber the following question : Is the proposed height of the foyer extension really necessary?

I am aware that very lengthy and extensive discussions have been held among those who speak on behalf of the War Memorial, the National Capital Development Commission and the Government. I am also aware that even now scaffolding is being erected, so the alteration will begin very soon. However, whilst there is no hint of there ever having been any secrecy or anything untoward about these alterations, I think it is likely that the public at large were unaware that this was likely to happen. I refer in particular to people outside Canberra who have not visited the War Memorial recently and received whatever advice might have been handed out there in regard to these alterations.

I would like an assurance from the Government that it will-if it has not already done so-look at this matter very speedily to determine whether it is necessary for those alterations to be so high. As I understand it the purpose of the glass structure and the height is essentially to let in light. If it is necessary for the structure to be so high, just how sure are those responsible that it will be designed in such a way that it will still be possible to have substantial views of the vista across to Parliament House? Finally, I emphasise that I have raised this matter not because I think people like to stand and look at nice views. In addition to the emotional experience of being in the very splendid and very impressive Hall of Memory, it is really a quite emotional experience to leave it and to appreciate the vista and the link between the two buildings.

I urge the Government to pay some attention to this matter because I believe the War Memorial is a building that Australians feel about very deeply. Regardless of whether they or their loved ones have ever been involved in war, it is nevertheless an extremely symbolic building for all Australians, one which is regarded with great respect as well as affection. I think all Australians would want to be assured that nothing will happen there, for whatever worthwhile reasons, which will detract in any way from its symbolism or its effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally I would not rise to discuss matters which were raised in debate in the course of the day but Senator Teague made some suggestions concerning the policy of the Australian Labor Party towards Indo-China which to me were a personal affront. He attributed a motivation to those of us who supported that policy and indicated that we had a complete lack of grasp of the total situation in Indo-China. I feel compelled to reply to some extent on the same day to the charges-that may be too strong a term-or the caricature of our stance made by him. Our stance towards Indo-China is, of course, determined by a policy adopted at the ALP's national conference in July 1982. I think it is important to note several elements in that policy. One paragraph reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia should support policies which would result in the independence of the three Indo-Chinese countries, based on democratically elected governments.
It goes on:

The Government should resume its commitment to the two aid projects in Vietnam suspended in January 1979. We should also resume cultural exchanges so as to promote greater understanding between our countries.
The policy states further:

The level of any future humanitarian and development aid should be consistent with our United Nations commitments and also should acknowledge our involvement in the Vietnam war and the subsequent need for rehabilitation in the interests of the Vietnamese people.

In that latter part of the paragraph which deals with support for humanitarian and development aid there is an acknowledgment explaining the genesis of our concern to provide aid to a people impoverished after decades of continuous warfare which ravaged the lives, the countryside and the economic support structures of Vietnam. Insofar as Australians participated in that saga of continuous warfare in Vietnam, it is not surprising that there is a widespread feeling within the Australian community, and certainly within the Australian Labor Party, that there is a corresponding responsibility to help restore that country's economic structure and so provide a better life for its people. That is why Senator Teague's charge that this resolution represents some factional point of view within the Australian Labor Party or the Australian community is so far removed from reality.

Mr Deputy President, I think you will agree that I am not often portrayed as a creature of the Left, though Senator Teague may think I am, at the mildest, a dupe of the Left in this regard. I prefer to think that I am simply one of those many thousands of members of the Australian Labor Party who, recognising the sufferings and deprivations of the Vietnamese people, want to alleviate those sufferings to a small and modest extent. One has to keep in mind that we would be providing only a modest amount of humanitarian and development aid. Only a very small drop in the ocean would be provided towards alleviating the deprivation and suffering in which the people of Vietnam exist. It would not be of a character or type which would allow the Vietnamese Government to choose to forgo certain projects in order to continue to occupy Kampuchea. The disparity in the sums involved is such that it makes that argument absurd. The idea that Australian aid would help to prolong Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea is ludicrous.
It is a fact that the part of our policy which speaks of providing humanitarian and development aid cannot be implemented in isolation from that other part of our policy which states:
Australia should support policies which would result in the independence of the three Indo-Chinese countries, based on democratically elected governments.

Insofar as the continued occupation by Vietnamese troops of Kampuchea hinders an act of self-determination by the Kampuchean people, it is incumbent upon us to seek a way or a means for conditions to emerge which would facilitate the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops and allow that process of free self- determination. Hence-and this is not acknowledged or recognised by Senator Teague-the continuous round of discussions by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, with various leaders of the Association of South East Asian Nations in recent weeks and with the Chinese Premier, which will end in the final week in June when he will have a conference with the Foreign Ministers for ASEAN countries and visit Hanoi.

This is not occurring because we have any delusions that Australia can play some role as mediator in a conflict which involves so many actors from the world stage, including the super powers. It is hard to think of any other small nation not immediately involved in the conflict which so manifestly is vigorously attempting to express its concerns for the sufferings of all the ordinary people throughout Indo-China whose mode of life-indeed their very life-is threatened and disrupted, whether they be refugees fleeing to Thailand, people within Kampuchea trying to re-establish some normalcy of life after the barbarous and genocidal excesses of the Pol Pot regime, or Vietnamese whose only experience for a lifetime has been to live in a war-torn economy.

It is not my intention to expound at length on this issue but it must be clear that the timing of any resumption of humanitarian or development aid of modest proportions will be the decision of the Government, as with all ALP policies. The earlier or later timing of that aid will not be made in some alleged response to either the Left or the Right. It will be made at a time and at a level when it serves the realisation of our whole policy towards Indo-China. As I said, that policy embraces the goal of independence for Kampuchea, Laos and Vietnam. That manifestly requires the withdrawal of any outside armed forces. Insofar as we also have as a goal the provision of humanitarian and development aid to all the peoples of the region, it is our hope that these goals can be pursued simultaneously and concurrently. I am sure that that is the wish of all decent, compassionate and concerned Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in the chamber to hear the comments made by Senator Martin about the Australian War Memorial and the possibility of the dome of the Memorial being blocked to view by some architectural-if I can use that expression-alterations which were referred to in an article appearing in the Canberra Times. I am not well informed about the topic but--
—And the additional point that the view through to Parliament House from the Hall of Memory will be blocked.

—Yes, I am not well informed about the matter but I have now read the article appearing in the Canberra Times and I am pleased that honourable senators in this place are concerned about the aesthetics of vistas in Canberra. I merely want to say that the views expressed in the article appearing in the Canberra Times, having been pointed out to the Government and further comments having been made by Senator Martin in the Senate tonight, have been noted. Also we have noted the views of the Director, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, who says that he has been assured by the National Capital Development Commission that the dome will be visible from the Stone of Remembrance. I think this covers only one of Senator Martin's points.
